TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it part of the Prime Minister's One Nation policy that we tug the forelock in Asia and apologise for our Constitution, our flag and our values? What does the Government believe it will achieve in Mr Keating demeaning our heritage and in demonstrating his prejudices in terms of the Australian identity and abandoning the right to take account of human rights behaviour in disbursing Australian taxpayers' money as aid?

—The Prime Minister has nothing at all to apologise for for the way in which he conducted himself on behalf of the Australian Government and the Australian nation when he was overseas. His trip was an admirably successful one and demonstrated in a very dignified and very effective way the kind of contribution that Australia can be expected to make to the region in the future as, indeed, it has done in recent years. It did a great deal to cement the bilateral relationships between Australia and Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. From all the feedback that I have had, that was exactly the way in which the trip was regarded by all the key people in those countries.

PARA.TAB: There is no question of diminishing Australia's stature by raising, as Mr Keating did, the question of Australia's identity in the region. This is an issue that many Australian Ministers, including myself, have raised on a number of occasions in a number of forums right around the Asian region because it is crucial to our future—one directed towards securing effective engagement with Asia—that we both perceive ourselves to be part of this region and we be perceived by others to be part of this region. It is an entirely legitimate issue to raise in that particular context of how we present ourselves to the region and what kind of identity and what kind of image we present.

It is not a matter of washing dirty domestic political linen in an overseas context, which is something for which the Opposition parties were absolutely notorious when in government. It was not a matter of Mr Keating doing anything as crude as Dr Hewson in Papua New Guinea—formally presenting an Australian flag to Mr Namaliu with an accompanying comment that he was not going to be doing anything thereby to diminish Australian authority and responsibility. That was a crude and undignified incursion of squalid domestic politics into an international sphere.

What Mr Keating did was raise the issue a couple of times quietly in his discussion with officials. He did not raise the issue of the flag publicly, except in answer to a question at a forum of people in Indonesia when, in response to a specific question, he gave a specific and frank answer—no different to the kind of answer that he has given on a dozen occasions on this issue in Australia. There was nothing new in what he said. That answer was greeted with fascinated attention by his audience and, indeed, a storm of applause when he had completed it. He made the point very effectively indeed.

On the question of aid and human rights, we had a pathetic attempt a little while ago by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to try to carve out some separate high moral ground distinct from the Australian Government by suggesting that so far as the Opposition was concerned human rights should be the fundamental criterion which applied in determining whether aid was directed to particular countries. When we look at his text further, it becomes absolutely apparent that Dr Hewson's position on this issue is no different from that of the Australia Government, which is that this issue about the conditionality of aid needs to be treated on a case by case basis, having regard to the nature of the human rights incursions that are involved and whether or not they represent a deliberate act of the executive government concerned.

There is a very obvious difference, for example, between the Tiananmen situation, which was a deliberate act of state policy which justified a withdrawal of Australian aid; the situation in Burma, which represents, again, a deliberate act of state policy at the highest levels and which again justified a withdrawal of aid; and the situation of the Dili massacre last November which on nobody's analysis involved a deliberate act of high state policy directed from Jakarta. That is the kind of case by case judgment we make. There are many other examples that one can offer.

Of course it is the case that in other aspects of aid delivery we do take human rights questions very closely into account. In the design and the construction of particular programs and projects we take human rights issues, like the role of women, into account in the formulation of policy. We take very much into account the effectiveness of aid in aiding and abetting the victims of human rights discrimination in the way in which aid is delivered.

So there are many ways in which human rights principles, foreign policy and the policy of aid do intersect. It is just a squalid, politically motivated nonsense to claim that there is some significant difference in the way in which the Government and Opposition respectively approach these issues. So, if the Opposition were a little bit more honest and a little bit more consistent about these matters, it would have a lot more credibility in the eyes of the community of Australia than it does at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister is saying that the purpose of Mr Keating's demeaning statements in Asia was to cement relationships, I ask him more specifically: how are our relationships with Indonesia cemented by Mr Keating apologising for our Constitution, our flag and our values?

—It is not a matter of anybody apologising to anyone about anything. It is a matter of making the point that we would better project ourselves, arguably, were we to present a different set of images to the world than a set of images that are directly and immediately associated with our colonial past.

PARA.TAB: May I say that from my own experience of many discussions on these sorts of issues around the region, both in years past and more recently since this issue has been raised, I am in no doubt whatsoever of the absolute accuracy of Mr Keating's perceptions about the utility of such a change in terms of the way in which we would be regarded around the region. It is not a matter of anyone, in the absence of the issue being raised, having any particularly strong views about it. But it is certainly a matter of people responding very favourably, very warmly, very positively and very understandingly to the kind of policy change that Mr Keating is suggesting, which may present to the region a very different face of Australia from that which we have had in the past with assistance from the forelock tugging grovellers who are lined up opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of concerns raised at yesterday's annual general meeting of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries about the threat to Australia's car industry from second-hand Japanese imports? Is the Minister aware of figures showing a dramatic fall in new vehicle registrations in New Zealand as a result of imported second-hand cars from Japan? Can the Minister confirm the Government's intention to act to protect the Australian passenger motor vehicle industry from second-hand imports?

—I made an announcement to the Senate about this matter on 3 December last year. Since that time there has been some lobbying about the issue. Let me set the matter in its proper perspective. Senator Foreman has asked me about the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries. The Federal Chamber did meet here in Canberra yesterday. I met with it, together with the Treasurer. I think four Opposition spokesmen, including Dr Hewson, also met with the Federal Chamber.

PARA.TAB: The Chamber and the industry are united in the view that imported second-hand cars threaten the future of the automotive industry in this country. The crucial question about the automotive industry in this country relates to the issue of tariffs generally. The Government's policy, which was announced in March 1991, was based on a report of the Industry Commission after a complete inquiry which recommended phasing down to a 15 per cent tariff by the year 2000. It is only the Opposition that sees fit to depart from a recommendation of the Industry Commission in respect of this matter.
The Federal Chamber is also aware of the Opposition's blind allegiance to the dogma of zero tariffs and the fact that it would spell an end to car manufacturing in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a wimp, aren't you?

—Senator Alston interjects with his new found virility that I am a wimp. Those people on the other side of the House have to decide why every car manufacturing country in the world with the exception of Germany protects its automotive industry.
—You ask Jac Nasser what his problems are and you won't hear him mention that.

—The Opposition has to ask itself that question; we will come to that in a minute. The Opposition claims that zero tariffs will not be a problem because Dr Hewson will wave a set of magic wands and wipe out the structural impediments to international competitiveness overnight.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston has been vocal about Mr Jac Nasser, the President of Ford. Mr Nasser has to live in the real world and he says that that is plain wrong. He told the Australian Business magazine this month that the car manufacturers would still be uncompetitive if Dr Hewson could fix all the things that are within this country's control. The supplementary question about that is `Why?'. The answer to that question is that automotive industries around the world depend on volume and we do not have sufficient volumes in this country to have a fully competitive automotive industry. We may get there, but we are not there yet. That is something which I think the Opposition ought to take account of. The Opposition has to find its model for this zero tariff proposal somewhere and it cannot find it anywhere in the manufacturing world in respect of automotive manufacturers. The Opposition is a special breed all of its own.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a special case—a basket case.

—Senator Alston is a special case all right. We know where he ought to be: in a straightjacket. Dr Hewson will have nothing of the real world. Speaking on television, he said that zero tariffs would lead to a bigger and more dynamic car industry. That is a statement which emanates probably from some academic tutorial room and has nothing to do with the real world. The Opposition's views on these subjects come from an academic tutorial room or from a woolshed economics book in the hands of somebody like Ian McLachlan.

PARA.TAB: Even if the Opposition's policy would lead to a bigger car industry, it would not be in Australia: it would be in some other country. The reason for that is that investment decisions in Australia in respect of the automotive industry are dictated in Detroit and Tokyo, and those investment decisions will not be made if there is not an appropriate regime for the automotive industry in this country.

In March last year the Government announced tariff arrangements for the industry which will see a phase down in protection to the year 2000. It accepted the recommendations of the Industry Commission report. It is a real challenge to the industry to meet the additional competition from imports which it will now face as a result of reduced tariffs. The phase down in tariffs was decided at a time when the Government did not envisage large scale imports of second-hand vehicles from Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —You tried to keep them out with non-tariff barriers.

—Just as they do in the United Kingdom. At least we are up-front about this. A flood of these imports would be an intolerable additional competitive pressure. Those who advocate such imports—and there have been some pathetic attempts to do that—say they would create work for Australians fitting new tyres and new seat belts in second-hand imported Japanese cars. That company will spend $37,000 a month on fitting seat belts and tyres to these cars. That is what is said.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, because it has been adopted by interjection, that is the Opposition's view of what industry policy in this country ought to be about—a few Australians in screwdriver industries working for overseas industries in this country. That is not what it is about. This Government is committed to a manufacturing base for the automotive industry and the components industry. That industry is now exporting from Australia for the first time in 30 years. Last year its exports were worth $1.1 billion. It is not an industry based on changing tyres and adding seat belts.
This problem arose across the Tasman in New Zealand. It arises in New Zealand, the United Kingdom and Australia because we have right-hand drive cars.

TALK.START.PARA: —Send them out to anti-dumping.

—That is how much Senator Panizza knows about dumping. New Zealand faced this problem earlier than we did. In 1986, before second-hand Japanese car imports took off, new cars accounted for 94.95 per cent of registrations in New Zealand. In 1991 that figure had dropped to 48.5 per cent and in a big overall market new car sales were down by 20,000 in 1991 when compared to 1986.

—I am drawing to a conclusion, but sometimes one has to provide a long answer and, indeed, repeat it from time to time so that the Opposition has some hope of understanding it.

PARA.TAB: If one could translate the 20,000 reduction in new car production in New Zealand into the Australian market—and I agree that it is a speculative exercise—it would represent something like 80,000 to 100,000 cars. —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen reports of statements by the Leader of the Opposition that the coalition is investigating the New Zealand system of replacing awards with individually negotiated employment contracts because `that type of approach is worth considering'? Has he seen later reports that Mr Howard is backing away from his Leader's policy in favour of one in which employers and workers can agree to remain within the award system? Is the Government considering either option in its forthcoming reform of the system? Further, what protection from exploitation would either option give to individual workers?

—We are not considering any policy moves of that nature. We do not share the Liberal Party vision of turning Australian workers and Australian wages policy into the poor white trash of Asia. We believe in a wages policy which is based on high skill, flexible workplaces and training and which will lead as a basis of that to a highly skilled manufacturing sector.

PARA.TAB: I have seen the remarks of Dr Hewson in New Zealand and the qualifying remarks of Mr Howard—who is these days increasingly, I must say, a bitter man—which are scrambling to try to put a human face on the stark realities that Dr Hewson is talking about for Australia: the stark reality that he intends, if he gets the chance—and I do not suspect he will—to introduce into this country the New Zealand system of employment contracts.

What that means is that the Industrial Relations Commission is abandoned. What that means is that the award system that has served Australians well in having an independent umpire determine minimum rates of pay and conditions of employment for Australian workers is abandoned and set aside. What this system means is that the national wage case, which corrects wages for economic adjustments over time, is set aside, abandoned and no longer occurs. What this system, the Hewson system, means is that once again we would see the spectacle in this country, as we did during the Fraser years, of a government making war on that section of the Australian community that happens to be members of trade unions. We do not intend to support any of those changes.

What Mr Howard has said is disingenuous in the extreme. He has said that the Opposition would retain the arbitration commission where both parties agree to do so. That means that where an unscrupulous employer agrees not to do so, that unscrupulous employer has the power of veto and, therefore, the worker in that situation has no access to the Commission. That is disingenuous. It pretends that somehow or other the Opposition supports the Commission system by the use of smart lawyer-like language, but the intent is to encourage employers to veto access to the Commission, veto access to the umpire, and prevent there being fair determinations made in particular circumstances.

I think the remarks of Mr Howard have to stand exposed for what they are. While he has tried not to endorse the policy of his Leader, Dr Hewson, nonetheless he is pursuing under the clothes of a more human face the same pernicious policy in industrial relations.

This is all in stark contrast to what the Premier of Tasmania has been saying over recent days. Over recent days Ray Groom, the Liberal Premier of Tasmania, has indicated that he supports working with and through trade unionists to resolve industrial disputes. He supports the Industrial Relations Commission. What he has also said is that he does not intend to drag Tasmania down the New Zealand road; he does not intend to drag Tasmania down the New South Wales confrontationist road; and that he intends to encourage APPM in that particular dispute to come to the bargaining table and negotiate properly and fairly with its workers against whom it has taken unilateral action. For his pains, Premier Groom has been attacked by the H.R. Nicholls Society and asked to desist.

I conclude my remarks by calling on Dr Hewson and Mr Howard to support Premier Groom; to tell the H.R. Nicholls Society to butt off out of industrial relations, to get out of the scene; to renounce their ideological driven agenda; to get off the New Zealand road; to get off emulating the confrontation of New South Wales; and to support the pragmatic, realistic approach of Premier Groom and help him solve a practical industrial relations problem which has economic implications for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Prime Minister accept that the 1988 bombing of the Pan Am flight over Lockerbie which killed 270 people is overshadowed in its scale by the tragedy of East Timor where tens of thousands of people have died under Indonesian rule and—in view of Senator Gareth Evans's earlier answer—under the high government policy of Indonesia which lays claim to East Timor against the wishes of the East Timorese people? Secondly, does the Government endorse the recent decision of the United Nations Security Council to impose sanctions on Libya for refusing to surrender two citizens suspected of the Lockerbie bombing? Thirdly, if so, how does the Prime Minister rationalise this support while simultaneously refusing to take the relatively small step of linking aid to Indonesia with its shocking human rights performance in East Timor?

—This question would be more appropriately addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I shall refer to a couple of the points raised by Senator Coulter. The Government has strongly expressed its concerns about events in East Timor. I believe that the Prime Minister had very constructive and positive discussions with the Indonesian Government about some of the long term problems of East Timor which in part may have led to the massacre which occurred in Dili last year.

PARA.TAB: The Senate will recall that Senator Evans went specially to Indonesia to discuss this issue after the events in East Timor. I was in Indonesia a little before Senator Evans and discussed these issues with representatives of the Indonesian Government. I think I can say with a fair degree of confidence—I believe that Senator Evans would agree with this view—that, as a result in part of representations made by countries such as Australia, there was a much more genuine inquiry by the Indonesian authorities into the Dili massacre than we believed might have taken place at the time at which it occurred.

I refer to the Prime Minister's visit to Indonesia. The Prime Minister raised with the Indonesian Government not only Australia's abhorrence about the events in Dili last year but also issues relating to poverty in East Timor, the role of the Indonesian army in East Timor and the question of whether there could be some mutual consideration between Australia and Indonesia of poverty alleviating programs in East Timor which would help the population in the longer term.

In so far as the Lockerbie disaster is concerned, I understand that Australia has indicated a position in relation to the United Nations Security Council resolution. I understand the debating point in Senator Coulter's question, but I am not sure whether there is an appropriate analogy between the United Nations Security Council resolution against Libya in respect of terrorism internationally, leading to the Lockerbie disaster amongst other things, and events which took place in East Timor. That does not for a moment limit our expression of concern about events in East Timor which, I believe, has been very eloquently put to the Indonesian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister's reply indicate that the deaths of Americans, Scottish people and others who were on that Pan Am flight are considered as far more important, for perhaps racist reasons, than the rights and the self-determination of the East Timorese people?

—I slightly resent that supplementary question. No, it does not indicate that at all. One really has to be straining the imagination and have a mind overheated with incredibilities to believe that my answer meant that. There has been no United Nations Security Council resolution in relation to Indonesia since 1976. It is not appropriate for a United Nations Security Council resolution on one issue to be put together with a totally different issue, about which this Government has been consistently and vocally concerned.

PARA.TAB: The following documents have been endorsed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (responsible for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade), the Minister for Administrative Services (responsible for the Australian Protective Service), the Attorney-General (responsible for the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation) and the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (responsible for the Australian Federal Police and the Protective Security Co-ordination Centre):

A. REPORT ON THE INCIDENT AT THE IRANIAN EMBASSY ON 6 APRIL, 1992

The Government was seriously concerned at inadequacies in the official response to threats to the Iranian Embassy in Canberra on Monday 6 April 1992 which led to a violent incident involving injury to persons and considerable damage to property. Ministers, as a consequence, directed departments and agencies to prepare a full report on the incident in the context of Australia's obligations to protect its diplomatic community and the protective security measures which are maintained to provide that protection. This report contains the conclusions reached by officials in reporting to Ministers about the incident.
Australia's International Obligations
2. The international legal regime obliges Australia to take all appropriate steps to give special protection to diplomatic and consular representatives and missions in Australia
3. These obligations arise from the—
. Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations
. Vienna Convention on Consular Relations
. Convention of the Prevention and Punishment of Crimes Against Internationally Protected Persons, including Diplomatic Agents.
4. These obligations include the requirements
. to take appropriate measures to prevent any attack on the personal freedom or dignity of diplomatic agents while in Australia for the purposes of performing their functions;

. to take appropriate measures to protect the premises of a diplomatic or consular mission and the private residences of diplomatic officers and administrative and technical staff of a diplomatic mission against any intrusion or damage and to prevent any disturbance of the peace or impairment of the dignity of such premises; and
.should protective measures fail, to apply the full force of the law to obtain the arrest and bring to trial offenders.

5. Australia has enacted legislation establishing a statutory basis for the provision and enforcement of this special protection. This legislation creates particular offences in relation to offences against missions and members of missions. Moreover, Australia maintains special protective measures for the diplomatic community in the form of the guarding and patrolling of premises of missions and other buildings, and (for members of missions who are at high risk) police escorts. These are important special measures which supplement the general protection the diplomatic community enjoys through the existence and enforcement of the general criminal laws within each jurisdiction in Australia, and the general preventive measures such as immigration barrier controls which are maintained to protect Australia from acts of politically motivated violence. Certain diplomatic missions maintain their own security arrangements, eg United States, Saudi Arabia.

6. Around 1500 offices and residences within Australia are occupied by diplomatic and consular staff, including honorary representatives and trade and other officials. Of this total there are 725 premises in the ACT, 397 in New South Wales, 117 in Victoria, 42 in South Australia, 60 in Western Australia, 59 in Queensland, 17 in the Northern Territory and 22 in Tasmania. Particular measures have been implemented for high-risk missions: Israel, Turkey, and (since the 6 April incident) Iran.

7. General and specific threats against diplomatic and consular representation in Australia are constantly assessed and responded to. The APS, over the last eighteen months, has responded to some 300 demonstrations and other significant security incidents involving the diplomatic community. The PSCC has, over the last twelve months, formally requested and received about twenty five threat assessments from ASIO about diplomatic security in addition to information provided during day-to-day consultations and during regular and special coordination meetings.

8. The cost of the protective arrangements funded by DFAT amounted to $6.34m in 1991; $4.34m has been budgeted for 1991-92, but this will be exceeded. Substantial additional costs are incurred by other agencies including the AFP, State and Territory police forces and intelligence bodies in meeting the Government's diplomatic security obligations.
Responsibility for Security of Diplomatic and Consular Missions
9. The responsibilities of departments and agencies for diplomatic and consular security under current arrangements are as follows:
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is responsible for the security of diplomatic and consular missions, in accordance with Australia's international obligations.

.The Protective Services Co-ordination Centre (PSCC), a branch of The Federal Justice Office within the Attorney-General's Department, is responsible for inter-agency coordination of responses to threats or incidents and for the development of appropriate consultative machinery and the provision of coordinated advice to Ministers.
.The Australian Protective Service (APS) is tasked by DFAT on a fee for service basis to provide static guarding and mobile patrols for the protective security of diplomatic premises.

.State Territory police are responsible for community policing: in the ACT this responsibility is met by the Australian Federal Police (AFP). ASIO is responsible for the provision of threat assessments.
Events of 6 April: Chronology of Events in Australia

10. The following chronology of events covers the period from before the lodgement of a request for increased protection by the Iranian Embassy in the early hours of Monday, 6 April, to the statement by the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Kerin, deploring the incident, at 1745 on 6 April.

0244First wire service (AAP) report of attacks on Iranian Embassies—in Bonn, The Hague and London—inserted into newstrack system. This information was retrievable from the newstrack system subscribed to by ASIO, DFAT and AFP.

0254Iranian Embassy staff member telephoned APS with advice that a serious threat to the Embassy existed. He explained that the Embassy had received reports of attacks by unknown people on Iranian embassies around the world, stated that the Embassy had received a threatening telephone call, and requested any protection that was thought to be necessary.
0315APS instructed its two nightshift mobile patrols to carry out patrols of all Iranian Embassy locations at least every 20 minutes.

0329APS telephoned the Iranian Embassy to advise of the protective security measures that had been introduced. The Embassy stated that the Iranian Foreign Ministry had instructed all missions to seek enhanced security.
0333APS held the first of several discussions with AFP, during which details of the phone discussions with the Iranian Embassy were relayed.
0350AFP directed its patrols to include Iranian Embassy locations.
0630A further AAP report suggesting a pattern of attacks on Iranian Embassies throughout Europe and North America.
0830AFP discussed the situation with ASIO ACT Regional Office which initiated standard procedures except that it did not notify Central Office or arrange for the PSCC to be notified.

0840APS advised DFAT of the Iranian request for assistance and the increased patrols already in place. APS suggested extra staffing or resources, meaning by that the posting of a static guard. The responsible DFAT officer, on the information available to him, did not think that it was necessary to post a static guard.

0845Further AFP/APS discussions, during which the AFP asked whether a static guard would be provided and was advised that DFAT did not require one. This was followed by increased APS and AFP patrols, which took place during the remainder of morning.
0930AFP sought an early meeting with Iranian Embassy to discuss increased security; following discussion with the Embassy, a meeting was arranged for 1300.
1000ASIO Regional Office contacted Asio Central Office which instituted standard action except that they did not notify the PSCC.
1140APS made last patrol past the mission before the incident and no problems were noted.
1145AFP made last patrol past the mission before the incident and no problems were noted.
1207AFP notified of incident at Embassy and request for urgent assistance at the Embassy, which was provided with subsequent involvement of APS.
1213AFP arrived at Embassy.
1215APS arrived at Embassy.
1235DFAT advised of incident.
1315APS advised PSCC of incident.
1340Initial arrests of persons subsequently charged over incident.
1745Statement by the acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.
Events of 6 April: Conclusions

11. Ministers directed senior officials of responsible departments and agencies to investigate what went wrong and report to them. Mr Peter Kennedy, Deputy Public Service Commissioner, assisted with aspects of this process.

12. Officials found that the major reason for the failure of protective procedures was that critical information was not communicated promptly enough or in sufficient detail to the right people to trigger appropriate responses, and that as a result the decisions made and actions taken by those to whom information was provided, in the event, were either insufficient or inappropriate. Particular conclusions were that:

. The Iranian Embassy gave timely advice by speaking to the APS at 2.54 am on 6 April, in accordance with standing guidelines to diplomatic missions, of a possible threat to their security. The APS responded to this advice by increasing patrols and by advising the AFP at 3.33 a.m. They did not advise DFAT until 8.40 am, nor did they advise the PSCC.
. The AFP responded by increasing patrols from 3.50 am. They did not advise ASIO until 8.30 am nor did they advise the PSCC.

. News accessible by 2.44 am from the international wire service AAP (subscribed to by DFAT, ASIO, and AFP) included information that Iranian embassies in a number of western countries had been attacked. This, coupled with the initial Iranian Embassy request for additional security at 2.54 am, suggested the possibility of a coordinated campaign worldwide against Iranian diplomatic representation.

. Officers in some agencies became aware during the morning of media reports of attacks on Iranian Embassies. Nobody in any of four agencies aware of the request from the Iranian Embassy (APS, AFP, DFAT and ASIO) advised the PSCC, and thus initiated the process of coordinated consultation on the need for increased security.

. The AFP contacted ASIO about the advice from the Embassy and about a media report of attacks on Iranian embassies overseas, but spoke to the ACT Regional Office rather than Central Office. Although the Regional Office took action on the information it was not passed on for some considerable time to Central Office.
. In spite of the contact with the AFP, ASIO did not recognise, either by internal decision or outside request, the possible need for advice to other agencies and departments.
. The APS, while it did fully pass on to the AFP the information it had received from the Iranian Embassy, did not provide DFAT with all relevant information in its possession.

. DFAT did not give sufficient weight to the information and advice provided by APS suggesting a static guard. In this context, DFAT did not have information from its own sources nor had it accessed information from any public sources on the gravity of the threat.
. Nobody in possession of the information about the request from the Iranian Embassy made a written report on the content of that information to any other agency.

13. The officers involved have been counselled concerning the deficiencies in the handling of the threat information. Any question of disciplinary proceedings is a matter for the relevant Secretaries and Agency Heads.
Action in Response to the Incident

14. The AFP and APS responded immediately to the incident and follow-up action included upgrading protection of Iranian Embassy personnel and property including the residences of Embassy staff. The AFP and ASIO initiated prompt investigatory action (10 arrests have been made).

15. The acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Kerin, issued a statement in which he condemned the attack and expressed the Government's sincere regrets to the Iranian Government and the Iranian Embassy. He said that the Government would ensure that all necessary action would be taken to prosecute the perpetrators and would pay for the damage in accordance with Australia's obligations relating to the protection of diplomatic premises.

16. In response to officials' conclusions about the events of 6 April, Ministers directed departments and agencies to take steps immediately to correct the deficiencies identified in the arrangements and procedures relating to the security of diplomatic and consular missions. The measures which departments and agencies adopted to correct the deficiencies are set out in Document B.
B. PROCEDURES FOR DIPLOMATIC SECURITY

Departments and agencies have reviewed their arrangements and implemented changes designed to overcome deficiencies identified in the light of the 6 April incident. These changes include action to define more clearly the roles of agencies as they relate particularly to diplomatic and consular protection.
Pre-existing Arrangements
2. The essential features of the arrangements in place before 6 April have been:

. With respect to information and intelligence handling, all Commonwealth agencies inform ASIO, and State/ Territory police forces where appropriate, of information relating to known or possible acts of politically motivated violence. ASIO in turn advises appropriate agencies of any information relevant to them. The PSCC advises relevant agencies both Federal and State of changes in the counter-terrorism level of alert.

. With respect to the notification of terrorist incidents, the relevant police forces advise PSCC and ASIO. The PSCC begins the coordination process by advising members of the Special Interdepartmental Committee on Protection Against Violence (SIDC-PAV) and appropriate members of the Standing Advisory Committee on Commonwealth/State Co-ordination for Protection Against Violence (SAC-PAV).

.With respect to the security of diplomatic missions, missions notify either the AFP or the APS of any immediate threat to their safety requiring urgent response. In the case of less immediate threats, missions address their concerns to DFAT. (Missions, including that of Iran, were briefed in 1990, and again in 1991, on these arrangements.)

PARA.TAB: Concerning immediate threats, the AFP and APS advise DFAT as soon as possible, as well as ASIO. The AFP determines the appropriate community policing response and DFAT assesses whether or not additional APS protection might be necessary and if so authorises additional measures.

All SIDC-PAV members consult with PSCC on the need for a coordinated response, and the PSCC where appropriate commissions a threat assessment from ASIO. PSCC may also convene a special meeting of relevant agencies.

ANSWER.PARA: . A number of missions supplement the protection provided under these arrangements with their own guarding arrangements and by installing security systems.
Improvements to Procedures
3. Changes which agencies have introduced to make these procedures more effective include the following:
PSCC

. Additional training and development activities will be introduced for all departments and agencies to ensure that all officers involved in the coordination process maintain their familiarity with national security arrangements.

. Responsible departments and agencies have been reminded of the requirement for them to notify the PSCC of any information which suggests that a threat to a diplomatic mission's security may occur and the National Anti-Terrorist Plan and supporting documentation is being amended to clarify procedures and responsibilities.
APS
.Procedures have been revised to ensure that APS regional offices quickly pass information concerning potential threats not only to relevant police (State/AFP) but also to DFAT, ASIO and the PSCC.
.Improvements have been made in internal methods for recording information concerning potential threats to missions and for distributing written advice by facsimile to other agencies.

.Should there be a disagreement over the adequacy of measures taken in response to a threat, officers who are more senior will be consulted at any time and, if required, the established consultative arrangements will be activated through PSCC.
.A review has been initiated with DFAT as to the need for possible additional security measures at particular missions and residences.
AFP

.Procedures have been revised, including those which ensure that the national office of ASIO, rather than the ACT Regional Office, and the PSCC are advised of incidents or potential incidents concerning missions.
DFAT
. Improved internal consultative arrangements have been established to ensure wider and more timely consideration and action in response to a threat to a mission.
.The need to maintain contact with diplomatic missions to obtain access to any further advice and to advise of decisions taken has been stressed in the revised procedures.
.Procedures for the recording of information received and action taken have been improved.
.Improved arrangements have been made to ensure 24 hour contact in Canberra on issues relating to diplomatic security.

.Closer monitoring of the inward wire service has been instituted to ensure that responsible areas of the Department are alerted to overseas events which may lead to threats to diplomatic missions in Australia

. Issues arising from the 6 April incident have been drawn to the attention of overseas posts, which have been reminded of the particular need to be alert to developments overseas which may have implications for the security of diplomatic and consular missions in Australia.
ASIO
. Arrangements have been made to accelerate the communication of information from regional offices to the appropriate intelligence branch in ASIO's Central Office.
. Procedures for the monitoring of media reports of terrorist incidents have been changed to speed up the passage of reports to intelligence branch desk officers.

. Procedures have been revised to ensure that advice of a threat to a mission, and where appropriate an assessment of the threat, is routinely distributed to other agencies. In particular, procedures will ensure that PSCC is advised of all threats to diplomats and diplomatic missions.
C. REVIEW OF EXISTING ARRANGEMENTS AND PLANS REGARDING COUNTER TERRORISM

The Government considers that the inadequacies revealed by the incident at the Iranian Embassy constitute grounds for examining existing plans and arrangements in relation to counter-terrorism, based upon a detailed review by all relevant agencies of their procedures.

2. Mr Michael Codd, AO, who until recently was Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, has been asked to conduct the review of existing plans and arrangements, including the security of foreign diplomatic and consular representation in Australia and the protection of Australian and visiting foreign office holders, in accordance with the following Terms of Reference.
Terms of Reference
3. The review (to be completed by 25 May 1992) will evaluate the adequacy and appropriateness of existing procedures and identify options for refinement or improvement, with particular regard to:
. decision-making processes provided for in existing plans and arrangements;
. responsiveness of decision-makers and timeliness of decisions;
. threat assessment processes and the management and timely monitoring and dissemination of relevant information and intelligence;
. resources available to the counter-terrorism and diplomatic protection functions;
. dissemination of plans and procedures, and training in their implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report on the incident itself makes it clear that no one agency or department was totally responsible for the failure to adequately protect the Iranian Embassy. The fact is that they all bear some degree of responsibility for what happened. The key conclusion of the report on the incident is expressed in a single paragraph as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the major reason for the failure of protective procedures was that critical information was not communicated promptly enough or in sufficient detail to the right people to trigger appropriate responses, and that as a result the decisions made and actions taken by those to whom information was provided, in the event, were either insufficient or inappropriate.

The critical task now is to ensure that the deficiencies that were shown up by the handling of this incident are corrected to minimise the risk of any repeat. Each of the agencies and departments involved has reviewed its procedures and acted to improve them. The second of the three documents that I tabled today details those changes.

PARA.TAB: In addition, Ministers consider that the inadequacies revealed by the incident at the embassy do constitute grounds for examining existing plans and arrangements in relation to counter-terrorism generally, based on a detailed review by all relevant agencies of their procedures. Mr Michael Codd, AO, who, until recently, was Secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, has been asked to conduct such a review of existing plans and arrangements, including the security of foreign diplomatic and consular representation in Australia and the protection of Australian and visiting foreign office holders. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Research and Technology in Tropical Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the significance of the recently announced study into research and technology in tropical Australia to be conducted by the Australian Science and Technology Council? Is the Minister aware of recent criticism of the study? Can he assure the Senate that the study will go ahead as announced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will, and I am delighted to say that it will. Any efforts that can be made and directions that can be adopted which will focus further attention on northern Australia are very welcome so far as I am concerned. ASTEC is the Commonwealth Government's principal source of policy advice on scientific and technical matters. This particular reference came directly from its report last year entitled Research and Technology: Future Directions. The report underlines the importance of tropical zone research and technology as a critical area of economic and social benefit to Australia, the only economically advanced nation in the world that has a very high proportion of its land mass in the tropics.

PARA.TAB: There is increasing interest in tropical science technology and development, and ASTEC believes that Australia has the potential to become a world and regional leader in tropical zone products and processes. Australia possesses expertise in areas such as biotechnology, especially in agricultural and forestry applications, medicine, including pharmaceutical products, and food processing. The challenge is to apply this expertise more effectively in tropical areas and to realise the potential for significant economic returns.

ASTEC concluded in its report last year that this unique opportunity for Australia to exploit its natural competitive advantage in tropical agriculture, medicine and technobiology has been neglected. The Government took this advice and commissioned the study. Preliminary consultation suggests that this study is timely, and I already know from personal experience—having been approached by a number of people already in the Northern Territory—that this matter has become a matter of wide interest to the scientific and research community in northern Australia, which has already approached me about making submissions to the inquiry.

Of course, the Federal Opposition has attacked the study. The shadow spokesperson for northern development, Senator Tambling, issued a press statement claiming that the Federal Government was neglecting development in favour of such studies. I assume that this means that he would have the Government ignore a specific recommendation from ASTEC; of course, this study is based precisely on that recommendation. A paragraph from his statement says:
I am sick and tired of millions of dollars in taxpayers funds being wasted on reports which deliver nothing to Northern Australia in return.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not sure how Senator Tambling feels today on this issue because Senator Tambling has an extraordinary track record of not having fixed positions on any of these issues and, in fact, of doing a very great job of talking out of both sides of his mouth at the same time.

PARA.TAB: On the sixteenth of last month in a radio interview in Townsville, Senator Tambling claimed that the north Australian economic development strategy was also `a waste of money'. The statement was issued prior to a meeting he had on the same day with the James Cook University researchers who are actually conducting the study. On the following day he was quoted in the Townsville Bulletin as saying:
I have changed my mind. There is some very comprehensive work being done.

I can assure the chamber that this study will go ahead and I am confident that it will be widely welcomed—I already have indications that it will be—by the scientific and technological researchers who already work in northern Australia.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs. Is the Minister aware of the recent study commissioned by the Victorian Industrial Supplies Office, and reported on in the Melbourne Age, which indicates that each $1m of imports saved creates 30 person years of employment, $280,000 in taxes and charges for all levels of government, $255,000 in direct consumer spending and $231,000 in welfare expenditure savings? In light of these figures, is the Minister prepared to stop all further tariff cuts, including the proposed tariff reduction for sugar, and to use tariffs strategically, that is, to provide time and resources to boost our import replacement capacity through specific incentives, to protect regional industries and to protect workers and their families, even when it becomes necessary to phase out over time certain industries and to redirect resources?

—I have not read the particular study done by the Victorian Industrial Supplies Office. After several years as a Minister, I have read a number of reports of that kind. There is no doubt that calculations which may or may not be right can be made to present that particular picture. While I accept that they may be partially true, I disagree with many of the premises on which those studies are based.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler essentially asked whether this Government will not proceed with its announced tariff reduction for sugar in July of this year. The answer to that question is no. He asked about a wide range of other tariff reductions and whether we can somehow strategically use the tariff system to advance the special sectoral interests of the Australian industrial community and so on. I do not believe that we can do that. I do not believe that there are valid intellectual reasons for seeking to do that.

The assumption in the question is that tariff protection—the question contains the word `protection'—protects jobs. The fundamental flaw in that argument in a contemporary world is that the thing which reduces jobs in particular industries and diverts them into other industries is changes in technology, not artificial tariff protection. If we look at the major changes in job and employment patterns which have taken place in Australia in the last few years, they are essentially due to changes in technology, not to changes in tariff protection.

For years of high tariff protection in this country industries such as the motor vehicle industry kept losing jobs. The industry lost more jobs under the Liberal Government, which had enormously high tariffs in the motor vehicle industry, than it has lost under this Government's motor vehicle plan. There are reasons for that: it has become inherently uncompetitive and lazy. A whole range of behavioural considerations follow for industries which are protected by high tariffs.

It is the same with the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. We cannot establish industries in this country which can compete in labour intensive activities with the countries to our north. We cannot compete with $8 a week wages without tariffs. That would send the average worker, the average employee, in this country broke. But with a system of tariffs which help direct industry into areas in which it can compete by quality, fashion, design or particular characteristics related to raw materials and so on we can achieve positive results.

The answer to Senator Spindler's question is that tariffs are not a solution to regional policies or any of the other things he mentioned. There may be other things which are and ought to be solutions, but not tariffs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not seem to address the nub of the question, which is whether he is prepared to use tariffs in the short term to permit other incentives to be applied. Perhaps he could tell us whether he is prepared to apply other incentives to make industries more competitive while in the short term we do protect jobs when we have an unemployment level of one million?

—We have an unemployment level of one million because there has been a serious recession in Australia, just as the level of unemployment in the United Kingdom is four million and there are very substantial levels of unemployment in the United States, Canada and elsewhere. This is because of a recession, not because of tariffs. The worst thing we could do for this country now is to say, `We will reverse policies on tariffs'. That is what the Opposition did when it was in government. It increased tariffs during its period of government in a vain and desperate search to create jobs. It had neither the wit nor the intelligence to go about it in another way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Tate in his capacity as Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and also as the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is the Minister aware of the welcome to life baby planner product guide promotion? Does this type of promotion comprise Australia's commitment to the international code for the marketing of breast milk substitutes?

—I am aware of the welcome to life planner. The departments concerned do have quite grave concern about certain aspects of the information provided. Australia is committed to implementing the principles of the World Health Organisation international code on the marketing of breast milk substitutes. I know that Senator West, as a very highly qualified nurse, would know of the nutritional value of natural breast feeding techniques.

PARA.TAB: The planner highlights the benefits of certain products only. It certainly does not provide comprehensive information about infant health in the first year of life. The planner does not discuss in appropriate terms the advantages of breastfeeding to infant health. The information it does give on breastfeeding is selective and incomplete. The text focuses on the mother's needs for commercial nutritional supplements and avoiding stress without a balanced discussion on the mother's and infant's needs. Additionally, the planner promotes in one or two cases self-diagnosis by mothers and use of over-the-counter pharmaceutical baby products without stating that professional diagnosis and advice should be obtained.

Following consultation with the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Brian Howe, I have directed the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to develop a set of proposals to monitor the adoption of the WHO code in Australia. We expect that that examination will be finalised within the next three months.

There is another aspect which I think is also of great concern to this chamber, in particular, given its concerns with the privacy issues. Welcome to Life is also running a competition for pregnant women through the planner. The competition entry form requires entrants to disclose details of their address and telephone number. I understand that this information will be used by the Roy Morgan Research Centre to build a database of pregnant women. This information, I understand, will be used for research purposes and possibly also for commercial purposes such as direct marketing.

This raises privacy implications for the women who enter the competition. The competition entry form does not indicate that the personal information collected on it will be used to build a database and the possible uses to which that information will be put. In my view, whenever personal information is collected from an individual, that individual should be made aware of the purpose of the collection.

I understand that there are international guidelines on the protection of privacy relating to such commercial transfers of information. I believe that those who have organised this particular so-called competition in conjunction with this planner should understand their obligation to take account of those international guidelines and, indeed, the concern in the Australian community concerning privacy issues. It is not simply a question of governments ensuring that there is not an interchange of information between government departments and agencies. There is a similar concern in the community about information being passed between private organisations and particularly—

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation should not allow for it.

—The Senate did pass a privacy Act which supplemented the initial control of government departments to ensure that information on the provision of credit, for example, was not made available to insurance agents and real estate agents. That shows and reflects the concerns in the general community.
