TALK.START.PARA: —The 1 April edition of the Green Left newspaper carried an article by a Peter Chiltern concerning so-called raids made by the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Taxation Office upon the offices of the Unemployed Workers Union in Launceston on 19 March. The article makes a number of observations about the way in which the so-called raid was conducted, including that police allegedly refused to provide any reason for the raid and an allegation that the operation was regarded by police as a fishing expedition. Not to put too fine a point on it, the article seeks to leave the impression that the operation was a vindictive, politically inspired act taken without good cause. The article then goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the UWU was set up in the late `70s, it has made some powerful enemies in the course of its work for unemployed people, says Bartlett.
Bartlett is an organiser of the UWU whose home, it is alleged, was also raided. The article continues:

`Hatred of the UWU is particularly venomous in some sections of the Labor Party. . . They have never forgiven me for my part in publicly humiliating Brian Howe, then minister for social security, during his visit to Launceston during the last federal election campaign.' Tasmanian Senator Michael Tate, minister responsible for the Federal Police, is also known to bear a grudge against the union, says Bartlett.

The clear implication in the reference to me is, I believe, to suggest that, in my capacity as Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police, I was somehow knowingly involved in the conduct of this investigation in furtherance of a longstanding grudge I am said to hold against the UWU.

PARA.TAB: I categorically reject any such imputation upon my character and upon the way in which I discharge my ministerial functions. I did not become aware of police activity in this matter until the operation on 19 March had been concluded. I have received preliminary legal advice that the comments contained in the Green Left newspaper about me amount to a gross defamation of the most serious and substantial nature. In addition to making this statement today, I have also instructed my solicitors to write to the Green Left newspaper seeking an immediate and complete retraction of the serious reflections upon me contained in the article.

QWN.TITLE: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 April 1992 I was asked a question by Senator Panizza concerning the Western Australian black spot program. On 2 April Senator Lees asked me a question concerning voluntary work by unemployed persons and on the same date Senator Harradine asked me a question concerning AOTC headquarters. I undertook to obtain further information and I have done so. However, as the answer in each case is lengthy, I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate the answers in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Land Transport has supplied the following answer to the Honourable Senator's question:

The Western Australian Government has submitted its 1991/92 program of black spots for consideration. However, the Minister for Land Transport has indicated to the Western Australian Minister for Transport that the program will not be approved until Western Australia has met the requirements of an agreement reached with it in 1990.

The Black Spot Program introduced in 1990 was conditional upon States and Territories agreeing to introduce a range of road safety measures. The same conditions were negotiated with all States and Territories. Although the Western Australian Government agreed to do this, a number of important measures have yet to be passed by the Western Australian Parliament. In particular these include:
.05 Blood alcohol concentration limit
zero blood alcohol limits for drivers of heavy vehicles, dangerous goods and public transport vehicles
national uniform speed limits
speed limiters for existing trucks and buses manufactured after 1 January 1988
zero blood alcohol limits for the first three years of driving for drivers under 25 years of age after they obtain a non-learner's drivers licence
a minimum period for a learner's permit of six months.
Legislation has been before the Western Australian Parliament on some of these issues now for almost two years.

The Minister for Land Transport has indicated to the Western Australian Government that he will not approve the 1991/92 program until the requirements of the agreement are met. These are extremely important initiatives which will help improve the safety on Western Australia's roads. They will also bring Western Australia into line with traffic rules in all other States and Territories.
In 1991 road fatalities in Western Australia rose by 5.6 per cent against a national reduction of 9.3 per cent.

In his "One Nation" statement the Prime Minister announced that an additional $70 million would be made available for black spots in 1991/92 and 1992/93. $25 million of this will be allocated during the current financial year. Western Australia's allocation from these funds is $7.7 million, of which $2.5 million is to be allocated in 1991/92.

The Minister for Land Transport requested the Western Australian Minister for Transport to submit projects for this "One Nation" Program by 31 March 1992. No projects have yet been nominated by Western Australia.

On 2 April 1992, Senator Lees asked me a question about the number of hours of part time voluntary work that could be undertaken by unemployed people who met their obligations under the job search activity test.
I said I would make inquiries from the Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett, and provide an answer when the Senate resumed in 2 weeks.
The Minister has provided the following answer to the question.

Job Search and Newstart Allowances are usually paid to unemployed persons who are available for and actively seeking full-time employment. In some cases they can be paid to persons doing other activities with a vocational orientation, such as training or voluntary work.
JSA/NSA recipients may do part-time voluntary work (part-time is defined as under 20 hours per week) provided they can show that they continue to meet all the requirements of the activity test.
Full-time voluntary work must be approved by the CES in all circumstances and is limited by the Social Security Act according to the individual circumstances of the client.

PARA.TAB: JSA clients aged 16-17 may do up to a maximum of 20 days voluntary work each calender year.
JSA clients aged 18-54 can do full-time voluntary work only if the client resides in a remote area and there is no locally accessible labour market or vocational training course.
JSA clients aged 55-65 (male) or 55-60 (female) may do up to a maximum of 65 days in any calendar year.
For all Newstart Allowance clients there is no limit on voluntary work provided the voluntary work is included in the Newstart Agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to find the correct balance between opportunities to participate in voluntary work and the commitment to seek proper paid employment. Voluntary work can provide experience, skills and contacts in the labour market but a client's main objective must be to obtain paid work.

DSS and DEET are looking at revising the rules relating to full time voluntary work, particularly to allow greater scope for the 18-54 year old JSA clients to participate in approved voluntary work and retain entitlements to JSA.

PARA.TAB: AOTC has an extremely large number of very small operating centres throughout Australia, performing such functions as fault reporting, customer billing inquiry, customer ordering, operating services etc. These small centres often with only a few staff, are proving to be inefficient as volume of work presented to these centres is often uneven and the flexibility of such small centres is limited.

AOTC has advised that advances in technology together with improved processes and methods, and the need to reassess its organisational structure, have resulted in its Consumer Division being able to merge administrative functions across the country, replacing the former state-based regional structure. For example, South Australia and the Northern Territory will combine and the ACT will form part of country New South Wales.

It is expected that the savings achieved through reducing the regions in the Consumer Division from fourteen to nine larger ones will lead to greatly increased efficiency, lower prices, and improved customer service.

AOTC has assured me that rationalisation of staff in Tasmania will be reviewed carefully before any final decisions are made and that all the current Consumer Division customer-based activities will remain in Tasmania to ensure that Tasmanians receive the same quality of service as other Australians.
Specifically, I have been advised by AOTC that:
it is not proposing to shift Consumer Division employees to Victoria, but is contemplating reducing the work force in Tasmania over the next three years;

that also over the next two to four months the Consumer Division will be reviewing its administrative processes in order to achieve significant improvements in its responsiveness; AOTC expect that this review will result in a reduction of approx 30 jobs in Tasmania; and

in addition there will be an ongoing review of the operations of the Consumer Division aimed at productivity improvements. AOTC estimate that this review is likely to identify around 270 additional jobs in Tasmania which may become surplus as the Consumer Division looks to rationalise its operations and confine its operating centres into larger and more effective teams.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion relating to the Australian flag.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absolutely essential that the Senate has the opportunity today to reaffirm its support for the existing national flag in view of the appalling behaviour of the Australian Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Never before in the history of this country has an Australian Prime Minister gone offshore and denigrated the Australian flag in the way that this Prime Minister has, for base domestic political purposes and nothing more.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating went to Indonesia with a planned program to denigrate the Constitution, the flag and the heritage of this country because he thought it could serve him some domestic benefit back here in the home constituency. Never before has an Australian Prime Minister behaved in that way: gone to a foreign country and talked down our Constitution and those symbols of Australia that are important to so many Australians and under which Australians have died. The Prime Minister did this for his own domestic political purposes. In some way—and beyond the competence of most—he believes, in Senator Evans's terms, that that is the way to cement our relationships within this region.

Mr Deputy President, can you imagine former Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew coming down here and talking down his national symbols? He came here occasionally and gave us a bit of advice; but we would never hear him talking down Singapore. Can you imagine President Suharto doing that—he who had to listen to what Mr Keating said to him in Indonesia? Can you imagine Prime Minister Mahathir of Malaysia coming here and talking down the Malaysian heritage? Of course we cannot imagine that, because no prime minister would do that. No prime minister worth his salt would embarrass his country in that way. But Mr Keating did so, as I said, because he thought there would be some benefit for him back home.

Mr Keating believes in some way that the identity of Australia is confused and that the way to clarify that identity is to change and rewrite our history in many ways, to change our heritage, to change our flag, to change our constitution, and that then, somehow or another, we will have a different Australia. Can honourable senators think of anything as naive as that—that we can in some way abandon our past and become something different?

In many ways we can be proud of our history. What have we got to be ashamed of? Why do we need to go offshore into Asia and apologise for our past? Of course we do not need to do that. We only need to do it if we think we are going to get some domestic political benefit out of it. Mr Keating has not only embarrassed Australia; he has ridiculed us in front of the nations with which we should be building real relations for the future. I wonder what they think of us now in those terms—Australia demeaning itself in coming to them and apologising for its past.

What Mr Keating should have been doing there was building our relationship, particularly in terms of our economic and trade interests. He could do that by concentrating on getting the domestic trade agenda in order here; getting micro-economic reform in place so we can get domestic costs down, so that our producers and traders can be competitive. He then has the opportunity to go up there and build real bridges and, upon those, to start building a relationship in which we can understand each other's culture and history better than we have done in the past.

What did I say—`Understand each other's culture and history'? We do not have to change ours in some way to believe that we can win a cheap point within the region. We should be going there proudly referring to our flag and its history. What was wrong with starting life as a British colony? Why should we be ashamed of that? Why should we go to Indonesia to apologise for that? Mr Keating believes that we should in some way go and apologise for our past when there is nothing we have done to be ashamed of at all.We ought to be able to stand proudly behind that flag, which reflects the geography of Australia, its location in the world and its historical past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is it not the case that Senator Hill is addressing the procedural question for the suspension of Standing Orders, rather than the substantive issues involved, has only five minutes to do so, and has not yet uttered a procedural word?
—I think he is moving towards it.

—No—on the point of order, Mr Deputy President. What I am seeking to demonstrate is why it is necessary for this Senate today to reaffirm the Australian national flag. It is because it is immediately in the light, on the first sitting day after the Australian Prime Minister has travelled abroad and embarrassed this country as he did. That is why it is important that this matter be dealt with today. That is why it is a matter of urgency. That is why I hope the Australian Democrats will, on this occasion, recognise the urgency and the importance of the issue and support this suspension motion in order that we might debate the substantive motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Forelock tuggers of the world unite! What a tirade we have just been exposed to from Senator Hill, and what a lot of pulpable nonsense. If members of the Opposition really thought that this matter was one of urgency, they would have moved an urgency motion, or an MPI. If they thought it was a matter on which the Government deserved censure, they would have moved a censure motion. They come in here with a limp little motion of support, affirming the existing national flag. That is something we can do or not do, as the mood strikes us, at any time. This is not something that demands that the business of this place be suspended in order to enable that to occur.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) has simply not even begun to discharge any kind of obligation to persuade this Senate as to the need for a motion of this kind being moved at this particular time. The issues that he wants to address he raised in Question Time, and I think he was given a sufficient answer in Question Time. Maybe he needs another answer. Let me offer it to him.

There is nothing in the nature of an apology for Australia's history in the remarks that Mr Keating has been making either here or overseas; there is nothing in the nature of an assault on the Australian Constitution; there is nothing in the nature of an assault on Australian pride or nationhood in what he is doing. He is raising entirely legitimate questions about the state of our symbols in the context of our future—our future as a nation and our future in the region. It is an entirely legitimate subject to raise.

The issue was raised, in equally interesting terms, in Canada in the mid-1960s. It generated an equally strident debate, spread over several years, involving very rowdy Party discussions and very comprehensive assaults on the integrity of the Government of the kind that we have heard today. In the result, a new flag was adopted by Canada in 1964 which has done immense things to generate a sense of national unity and national pride in that country. It has given that country an extraordinarily strong identity in the world at large. It is something that, a very few years after the event, no single Canadian would have been prepared for a moment to change.

I am sure that a similar process is potentially at work in Australia. It is a debate that needs to take place at this particular time in our history. It is a debate that needs to take place in a rational and sensible way, not by reflex Toryism, reflex reaction, reflex backward-lookingness of the kind that so readily springs to the lips of the Opposition.

This is not a debate that we need to have now in the sense of resolving it now with a triumphant reaffirmation of the values of the ancient past, which is what we are getting from the Opposition. We need to have a debate, a public discussion, spread over an appropriate period of time, culminating, as the Prime Minister said today, in some appropriate test of public opinion. No Australian government, certainly not this one, would act to change the flag without clear evidence of public support.

We are looking for some sensible process, some extended discussion, taking place to enable this debate to occur in the proper, sensible context in which it should occur. This kind of reflex jumping to attention because some pavlovian bell has been rung, because some ancient Tory symbol is thought to be put at risk by some remarks that the Prime Minister has made in a positive and constructive sense, does no credit whatsoever to the Opposition. It does not, in any sense, amount to the kind of matter which needs to be debated under this procedure today. The Government rejects this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather interesting that people talk about forelock tugging. It is many years since I was able to tug any forelock, as honourable senators will see.
—Tug your beard.

—Perhaps I should tug my beard. I agree with the Opposition to the extent that in many respects I was disgusted and absolutely appalled at the remarks made by our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Indonesia. I will return to that in a moment. However, having said that, the Australian Democrats feel that we cannot support the suspension of Standing Orders at this time for several reasons.

PARA.TAB: We agree with the Government—with what Senator Evans has said—in that this should be a long and detailed debate in which the public at large is involved. It is not—as, unfortunately, Senator Hill's motion suggests—for this Senate to determine what sort of flag this country should have; it is a matter for the Australian people.

The word that keeps emerging is `identity'. The Australian people have to determine what sort of identity they want and what sort of symbols they want to represent that identity. That will require quite a long and detailed process of consultation and participation by the public.As it will require legislative change to alter the flag, it will require at least two referenda. It will require a referendum to determine whether in fact the Australian people want to change the flag, and, if so, it will require a referendum on what that flag should be.

Nor should we stop with the flag as a symbol of our national identity. When one looks at the words of our national anthem, one finds that they do not reflect, in many respects, the national identity that I think is important. For instance, they totally disregard the Aboriginal heritage of this country. We talk about a young country, but we ignore the fact that Aboriginal people have been here for 40,000 or 60,000 years. That is a symbol that we could well change. That would also go very much to the heart of what sort of identity we want.

Secondly, the Prime Minister's raising this matter at this time is very much a diversionary tactic. There are far more important things to be debated and decided by this Parliament at this time than whether we should change the symbols of our national identity, including the flag.

That brings me back fairly and squarely to the remarks made by the Prime Minister in Indonesia. It is totally inappropriate for the Prime Minister to parade—in fact, I would use the word `flaunt'—his insecurity regarding his identity as an Australian before foreigners. If the Prime Minister has some concern about his identity as an Australian, it is appropriate to discuss that in Australia and to involve himself in that debate, but it is quite inappropriate—and I agree entirely with Senator Hill on this point—for him to go to Indonesia and discuss those matters before other people. That should only occur, if it occurs at all, long after the Australian people have decided what sort of identity and symbols they want to reflect that identity.

It seems to me that Mr Keating is also misunderstanding the nature of Asian nations by lumping all Asian nations together, as if Asia is one monolithic block, which it is not. There is probably more difference between the Asian nations than there is between the nations of Europe. To replace, as he appears to be doing, the tugging of the forelock to Great Britain with the tugging of the forelock to `Asia' again seems to misunderstand entirely the way in which Australia will relate later to those many nations.

I simply conclude by saying that we support the notion of a wide-ranging and long term debate on these issues of national identity and national symbols, but it is not appropriate at this time. Therefore, we believe that the half-hour debate given to the suspension of Standing Orders is quite adequate to deal with it at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion by Senator Hill to suspend Standing Orders to promote the Australian flag. This is my flag; it is our flag; it is the Australian flag. It is something that I personally have had a lot of pride in over many years, and for very good reasons.

PARA.TAB: To support the suspension of Standing Orders, I thought I would indicate what this flag means to me and I know to millions of other Australians. It has on it, of course, the Southern Cross.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it should stay there.

—That means many things to many people. Senator Collins should stop blabbing. For instance, it represents to me the timeless land. It was also used, as we all know, by the navigators before modern technology came to pass. Thus it is truly representative of this great country.

PARA.TAB: In the top left-hand corner is what is commonly called the Union Jack. The Union Jack represents the three flags of St George, St Andrew and St Patrick. So apart from its long historic traditions, the flag also represents to some degree some religious connotations. In fact, it recognises that this is a Christian-based country with Christian ethics and Christian morals. Much of our law is based on that Christian background.

The seven-pointed star represents the six States and the Territories of Australia. When this flag, with all those combinations—the Southern Cross; the Union Jack, representing the three crosses of St George, St Andrew and St Patrick; and the seven-pointed star—was introduced after a long competition and accepted in 1903, we became one Australia.

There has never been an identity crisis since. Senator Zakharov shakes her head. She does not know who she is. She is like Paul Keating, he does not know who he is either. So he has to run over to our neighbouring partners and say, `We want to be friends. We want to do business with you'. They say, `What have you got to offer?' He says, `I'm going to change the flag'. They say, `Beauty. Overnight our balance of payments will change because you are going to change your flag'. That man and what he said was an absolute and thorough embarrassment to every nationalistic Australian who has pride in this country. Not only that, but he also made us the laughing stock of South East Asia.

I heard Senator Evans say in here that it was an idea for promoting a change in attitudes or a symbolic change. As Senator Evans well knows, before I came into this place I spent a lot of time overseas promoting Australian products, and I can tell him that that does not matter one iota. It might matter if one is wandering around the cocktail circuit in the various embassies around the world, but—

TALK.START.PARA: —In Europe.

—Yes, when one is buying French clocks maybe. To the rest of the world it does not mean a damn thing but it does mean one hell of a lot to we Australians who do not have an identity problem; we have not had one since 1903. In fact, that particular flag—
—Rubbish.
—Senator Collins says `Rubbish'. He does not know who he is either. No wonder this country is in the abomination of a mess that it is in.
—You know we need a new flag.
—This country—
—You don't believe a word you are saying.
—I saw the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country kiss the ground at Kokoda. People gave their lives there. What was on the coffin of every one of those people? The Australian flag.
—A different flag.
—Senator Schacht should not interject on me. My father was one of those, as was an uncle of mine, the man who was promoted—
—It was the red ensign.

—Senator Schacht says that it was a different flag. This is the flag that we in Australia have come to love. It is the flag that causes the chill up the spine when someone at an Olympic Games wins a gold medal and the flag goes up. Let us not denigrate it. This Labor Party is in the process of attempting to re-educate the Australian people so that it can destroy our flag.

—I do not think anybody should attempt to trivialise this debate about the flag, as Senator Parer and Senator Hill attempted to do, by trying to link a very natural desire to have our own individual symbol with an attempt to rewrite history, or with the fact that servicemen who gave their lives in previous military campaigns for this country fought under that particular flag, as Canadian servicemen did and, indeed, as did United States servicemen—a former British colony—when it was part of the British Empire.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to trivialise the debate because it is an important debate and because the flag is the pre-eminent national symbol of this country, and national symbols are important. I would like to contribute briefly to this debate because I, along with Senator Tambling, come from the one part of Australia where we do have a symbol. If I could be forgiven at this point for referring to the Northern Territory as a State—or at least equating it with a State, as it will certainly one day become—we have a State flag in the Northern Territory which is the only flag in Australia that does not have the Union Jack on it, and a very attractive symbol it has become.

The decision deliberately not to have a Union Jack on it was taken, to his credit, by the now President of the Queensland Liberal Party, Paul Everingham, when he was Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Indeed, he took that decision with a great deal of obvious public support. No doubt when the Territory does become a State that flag will take us into statehood. It will not be done by calling for a competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with the national flag?

—It has a lot to do with it because the history that those who want to see a change in the flag, as I do, are accused of constantly rewriting, is reflected, of course, in the way in which this country was brought into nationhood 90-odd years ago.

PARA.TAB: I put the fundamental view—and I do not think it is an unreasonable one—that since the flag is our pre-eminent national symbol, then 90-plus years after officially becoming an independent nation it is about time we had a flag which was a truly independent, pre-eminent national symbol. It is an irritant to me—and I freely confess it—that 90 years after gaining so-called independence from Great Britain we still, as the most prominent feature of our own flag, fly the flag of another nation. That would irritate me if it were the flag of Canada or New Zealand or Yugoslavia or anywhere else; it just happens to be Great Britain's flag.

At Question Time, by way of interjection—indeed, with my tongue in my cheek, and as a little jest, if I could be forgiven for that—I said that we do need our own flag; either we should have our own flag or the Poms should stop using the corner out of ours. That was said only slightly tongue in cheek because I think it is important that we have a distinct national symbol.

I am proud of the Northern Territory's flag. I commend Paul Everingham. Indeed when I was the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory at the time I publicly supported him for having a flag that did not have—and it is the only State flag that does not have—the Union Jack on it. We did not have a competition to design the flag. The Northern Territory Government simply employed a very prominent Australian, Robert Ingpen, to design it, and there was our flag—black, white and ochre with, I am pleased to say, the Southern Cross still on it. I support Senator Parer there; the one thing I want to see remain on our flag is the Southern Cross, which is so distinctive and internationally designates this country and New Zealand. We retained that on the Northern Territory flag.

To express a personal preference, I do not think we should have international or national competitions to design a new flag because, like a lot of other people in this country, I have my own views about what it should be. I am horrified by suggestions that we should cover it in boomerangs, kangaroos, emus, echidnas and various other symbols. I personally favour the suggestion by the National Flag Committee of removing the Union Jack from our Flag and lifting the Commonwealth Star into a central position and then leaving it as it is. It would then be a matter for debate as to whether it remains the existing blue and white—which I would not worry about personally; I think they are quite appropriate colours—or whether we should have the green and gold which in recent years have come to symbolise Australia.

I conclude by stating that my personal preference is for the Union Jack to be taken off the flag, for the Commonwealth Star to be lifted into a central position on the flag, and for the colours to remain as they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear Senator Collins's points in the debate relating to the suspension of Standing Orders, and I am very pleased to know that at least he is proud of one flag. However, I would like to read the thoughts of another Northern Territory resident, Frank Alcorta, who has written the following in today's Northern Territory News:

SPEECH.PARA: A few days after the carnage of the Battle of Long Tan on August 16, 1966, my platoon went back to the site to pay homage to the dead.
. . . after hooking up the flag on a branch, the bugler played the Last Post while 16 ragged soldiers, wet to the skin and covered in mud, presented arms.
We did not care a lot whether Charlie was listening, or about breaking our orders.
We did it for our mates and never has the mournful sound of the Last Post (played against the backdrop of a small flag hanging limp under rain and thick canopy) been more soul-stirring.

PARA.TAB: Mr Alcorta has expressed very eloquently the feeling that so many Australians felt on ANZAC Day as thousands of Australians marched through the streets, proudly bearing the Australian national flag, and proud to say that it is the flag for which comrades have died. I am sorry for members of the Labor Party who have no identity, who feel that they are wandering lost souls. I am sorry that we have sent the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—a boy on a man's errand—to try to negotiate and strengthen our ties in our own region. I am ashamed of this boy on a man's errand who does not know the difference between diplomacy and being able to speak with the voice of authority of a nation that respects him. TALK.START.PARA: —I am Irish, Senator, not English, in my ancestry.

—Senator Collins is not Australian; how interesting. Senator Collins tells us that he is not Australian, he is Irish—in which case he has no business in this Parliament. TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senate Hill) and pursuant to contigent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to General Business order of the day no. 40 standing in the name of Senator Parer relating to the Flags Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is taking this further step in relation to the preservation of the existing national flag because it is deeply concerned about the situation that the Government, in particular the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), has created about the future of the Australian national flag and what the Government has in mind in relation to the flag over the next year or two.

PARA.TAB: In the short space of time that the Prime Minister has held office, he has raised the issues of Australian nationalism and the monarchy and he has now raised the future of the Australian national flag. Apart from the extraordinary and despicable way in which he has raised it in the last few days—namely, in the course of a visit to a foreign country—he has definitely placed on the agenda for the immediate concern of the Australian people and also, I would have thought, of this Senate, what the Government's intentions are.

This afternoon we endeavoured in the Senate to find out the order of the Government's program in relation to the future of the flag. We have clear evidence of that from not only the Prime Minister but also from the behaviour and comments of a number of Government senators, including the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). The Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, and Senator Collins have both indicated clearly that the Government has an agenda to change the national flag, and to do so without necessarily having a referendum.

Any change to the flag would require, of course, an amendment to the Australian National Flags Act. This Parliament would have to make a decision before the flag could be changed. The flag can be changed by this Parliament and such a decision would not require a referendum of the Australian people. Senator Parer's Bill is designed to ensure that a referendum would be required before the Australian national flag could be changed in any respect.

This is a very important matter. It is important that this principle be established. Senator Collins has agreed that the flag is our principal national symbol. The flag is not, in effect, part of our written Constitution. But it is clearly part and parcel of our Constitution and any changes to it should be treated in the same way as are changes to the Constitution.

We endeavoured today to obtain an undertaking from Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Senator Evans made clear in answer to a question from Senator Hill how he sees this process proceeding. As I have said, Senator Collins, who has spoken on this matter in an earlier debate, indicated that the Government is engaged in a process of changing the flag.

Incidentally, I asked Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence, whether he would affirm support for the flag. He gave a very delphic answer in which he referred me to the Australian Labor Party constitution. It seems to me that this is a very roundabout way of saying that the flag would be part of a process which would culminate by the year 2001 in a new Constitution for Australia. However, I am not clear what in fact Senator Evans has in mind.

So this chamber and the nation are left in a complete state of limbo. We know from past polling that a clear majority of Australian people are at present opposed to changing the flag. The Government is equivocating on the way in which the Australian people will be consulted on this most important matter. It is vital and urgent that Senator Parer's Bill, which clarifies this matter, should be brought on for debate forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this second motion to suspend Standing Orders for the reasons that I thought were put very succinctly by Senator Coulter, the Leader of the Australian Democrats. This is an important debate. I think I clearly affirmed that when I spoke in an earlier debate on the suspension of Standing Orders. It is going to be a long debate. I hope that as many citizens of this country as possible will participate in this debate which I believe will continue for a significant time. This is what happened in the case of the citizens of Canada. It is instructive to look at the public record of the debate in that country. In 1964 Canada moved to adopt a flag which I personally think is one of the more attractive and distinctive national symbols that exist today.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter is quite right—it is going to be a long debate. There will be endless opportunities to debate this matter in the Senate and I dare say that every one of them will be taken up. But this matter does not need to be debated this afternoon.

For the record, I would like to correct a number of assertions we have heard that are quite wrong. Just a moment ago Senator Durack said that I had indicated some government agenda to change the flag. Of course, I did nothing of the sort. I could hardly have made it more clear that I was simply speaking personally, as I hope most Australians will, on this issue. I was indicating a personal preference for a flag. I thought it was appropriate to point out that in a debate which, I must say, was not fiery at all, we adopted a flag for the Northern Territory. For the first time in Australia the flag of a political entity in this country did not contain the Union Jack. That flag is a very attractive and appropriate national symbol.

We have heard the nonsense put forward in this debate—and it will continue to be put forward—that nations, for some strange reason, are fixed in time and place. We are told that things never change. This is nonsense. Honourable senators who want to dispute that should refer to the development of the Union Jack itself. They should look at why it came to be called the Union Jack. The same sort of debate—if one likes to call it that—took place when that flag was being put together. They should look at the historical facts. It is nonsense to seriously suggest that an attempt is being made to rewrite Australian history by changing the flag to a more appropriate national symbol. It is also nonsense to suggest that this is some kind of betrayal. I must say that this is one of the cheapest—

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you mouth this pathetic rubbish?

—Well, I may be pathetic but the honourable senator is Ian Macdonald, and that is infinitely worse. It is a piece of utter nonsense to cheapen the debate and reduce it to the lowest common denominator—and this has been done here again this afternoon—by suggesting that this is some kind of betrayal of the service men and women who died while serving under the present flag. Of course, the symbolism contained in the current flag will not be altered. The symbolism will not be removed from the historical record because people think that a change in the flag is more appropriate.

PARA.TAB: I repeat, for what it is worth: I think it is a significant irritant to a great many Australians—and I am one of them—that 90 years after we became independent we still have as the most prominent feature on our own flag the flag of another nation. It is absolute nonsense.

I just want to correct the record in respect of one other matter. In his opening remarks to this debate, Senator Hill made the point—and obviously Senator Hill has not availed himself of the work that has been done in recent years—that we should not be ashamed that this country began as a British colony. I want to point out that, of course, is an absurd piece of nonsense. That, in one sweep of the brush, omits 40,000 years of recorded human occupation of this continent by Aboriginal people. This record can be set against the mere 200 years of European occupation of this country. Indeed, as anyone who has taken the trouble to have a look will know, we are talking about a complex and sophisticated community involving interrelationships, extremely complex languages and ceremonial customs that have existed for thousands of years prior to European occupation of this country.

I simply conclude by saying again: I am glad that this debate is continuing in Australia. It is going to be a long process. I hope that everyone will have a contribution to make. But no case has been made out that it needs to be dealt with this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there were one reason why it is urgent to bring forward Senator Parer's Flag Amendment Bill for debate, that reason was contained in the answer given today by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, to a question asked by Senator Parer. Senator Button was asked to give an unequivocal commitment that the Australian flag would not be changed without there being a referendum held of the Australian people. He was given the opportunity twice to commit the Government to that course of action. He deliberately and very obviously refused on both occasions to give such a commitment. That is what the core of Senator Parer's Bill goes to. The purpose of the Bill is to prevent changes to Australia's national flag occurring without the prior consent of the Australian people through a referendum.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that an identical Bill was passed by the Senate in 1984. It was a Bill introduced by Senator Durack. Its passage through the House of Representatives, of course, was frustrated by the then Hawke Government. It did not want to have a bar of the Bill but this Senate did pass that Bill in 1984. I introduced an identical Bill in 1987 which lay on the table until after the 1990 election. Senator Parer's Bill is the third, if you like, of the trio.

What we are doing here is not introducing a new piece of legislation; what we want is the Senate to reaffirm the very strong endorsement it gave in 1984 to the simple fact and request that the Australian flag, the primary national symbol of this nation, should not in any way be changed without the will of the Australian people being registered through a referendum. I find it beyond comprehension that a government of this country could even contemplate changing the national flag without putting the suggestion and proposal for change to the Australian people in the form of a referendum.

One has to ask why the Government is refusing to allow such a course of action; why it is refusing to allow debate on a Bill to do just that at this time. The reason appears to be tied up very much with the actions of the new Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in terms of the way he seems to want to run his government and the directions in which he wants to lead this country because what he is doing, almost every time he gets to his feet—be it in Australia or in foreign places—is raising issues which divide this nation.

Mr Keating, in the three or four months he has been Prime Minister, has been the most divisive Prime Minister we have had in this nation in many decades, if not ever. Why he wants to divide the nation is beyond me. Whether he thinks that for cheap, populist, political reasons he can use tactics like that to divert the attention of this country away from the misery and the hardship his economic policies have caused and whether he thinks he can hide the underemployment and unemployment of two million Australians behind such divisive diversionary tactics I do not know. This is regardless of what one thinks about the Australian flag.

I am a great supporter of the Australian flag the way it is. I believe it reflects properly a history and heritage I am intentionally and deeply proud of. The one thing I would have thought all Australians would agree on, whether they like the existing flag or whether they do not, is that they would not be prepared to see the primary symbol of Australia's nationhood changed without the reflection of the will of the people obtained through a referendum. That is precisely what this Bill is about. That is why it is urgent that it be debated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the suspension of Standing Orders. I agree with the remarks Senator Collins made in this debate half an hour ago. I must say that his description of what would be a very good flag for Australia is one I almost entirely agree with: the Southern Cross, the Star of Federation, replacing the Union Jack.

PARA.TAB: I want to remind senators opposite about the present flag. First of all, this myth that every Australian soldier from 1901 died under the present flag is an absolute furphy, an absolute fraud. If the soldiers in the First World War had a flag when they stormed Gallipoli, it was purely the Union Jack. It was not the flag of Australia. If they had another flag, it would overwhelmingly have been the red ensign—not the flag with a blue background. Through most of the First World War it was very seldom, if at all, that Australians fought under the present flag.

In the Second World War, the blue ensign flew on a few occasions. I must say that Sir Robert Menzies, when he was Prime Minister, did give an indication that he thought it would be appropriate. But, overwhelmingly, Australian servicemen in the Second World War fought under a different flag from the one we have today. They were under the red ensign or the Union Jack again. So it has only been since 1953 that the flag those opposite all want to die in the ditch for has been the official flag of Australia.

I want to point out to honourable members opposite the design of the present flag with its structure of the Union Jack in the top left-hand corner. This was a condition of the competition for the design of the present flag in 1901 which every competitor had to take note of. The rules of the competition stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The flag should be based on the British ensign, as the flags of the countries added to its folds, signalling to the beholder that it is an imperial union ensign of the British Empire.

Of the British Empire! The Opposition is supporting a flag of an empire that no longer exists. They were the rules that were given. They were the competition rules that had to be applied in 1901. Not even the British Commonwealth exists any more; just the `Commonwealth' exists. Those opposite are going back to the nineteenth century to being people of the British Empire. Those are the people they are hankering to. Six weeks ago John Howard said, `Let's go back to the `50s, to the golden age'. Now the Opposition wants to go back to the nineteenth century. Talk about a party that is out of date and nowhere near the aspirations of modern Australia! Those opposite are it.

PARA.TAB: One of the interesting things I have noted in recent times is that at sporting events when Australians want to hold up a symbol of Australia, we end up with all sorts of other symbols—not the Australian flag. For the America's Cup in 1983, it was a kangaroo on a green background. That was shown all over the world as Australia's flag. Even in the recent cricket World Cup, people were showing bastardised versions of the Australian flag in other colours because, at the same ground, British supporters were waving the Union Jack. I want to remind people opposite that about a year or so ago when the Australian netball team won the world championship in Sydney, there was a photograph in the paper the next day showing the victorious team standing in front of the Australian flag. The only thing you could see was the Union Jack. It was as though Great Britain had won the world championship, not the Australian team. That was the photograph that went all around the world; an image of another country.

This re-run Bill, put up by Senator Parer, is an absolute stunt. No wonder the Opposition put it up today. Today the coalition had to sack one of its frontbenchers. Mr Braithwaite resigned. The coalition is falling apart on tariff policy. This Bill is a diversion of attention from the fact that the coalition is being wagged by the Queensland National Party. Braithwaite has resigned, Ronny Boswell has won the day, and the coalition is falling apart. It is 1987 all over again and we will win the next election as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the suspension of Standing Orders because there is a great deal of urgency here. We have a Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who is out of his mind and is racing around seeking votes from wherever he can find them. In the few minutes I have, I would like to deal with some of the nonsense that Senator Schacht talked about. He seems to know as much about Australian history as the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: The college I lived in when I was an undergraduate had as one of its treasured mementos the flag that flew over Australian Army headquarters in France the day the Armistice was signed in 1918. I can assure Senator Schacht, apart from the fact it had a red background, that it was exactly the same as the Australian ensign.

I was privileged to be at the America's Cup at Newport for one of the races that we won in 1983. One of the really moving moments of my life was to come into the harbour at Newport at the end of the race to see one of the biggest Australian flags I have ever seen flying from the masthead of one of the ships at the quay side.

The matter of urgency relates to the behaviour of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is taking Australia back to the isolationist xenophobia of the Labor Party's origins. As Senator Coulter said earlier in the day, he finds the behaviour of the Prime Minister absolutely inappropriate; the way he is flaunting his personal insecurity. I agree with that completely. I have never seen a public figure make a public display of personal insecurity the way this man is doing. It is certainly correct when Mr Keating says he does not feel an Australian. He certainly is not an Australian if we judge him by his actions.

He certainly has no knowledge of the subtleties of Asia. To go and run what is a very personal argument of his about our national status and standing when he is a guest in another country—and in Indonesia in particular—is absolutely indescribably counterproductive for Australia's interests. He cannot claim that it is probably the first time he has been to Indonesia. He should have been advised by people like Senator Evans and Foreign Affairs officials that Indonesia, with its Javanese culture, is a country above all others where the subtleties of behaviour are of prime importance. To do what he did has put Australia back in its relationships with that country for decades.

This is all about a perverse nationalistic argument. I can remember a time 20 years ago when John Gorton—who was a great Australian and a great Australian Prime Minister—said of our relationships with other countries, said that we were not going to roll over like puppy dogs and let people tickle our tummies. Yet this is exactly what Paul Keating does when he goes overseas. He is rolling over like a puppy dog so that they can tickle his tummy.

The objectives of what he is doing are purely political. Keating has learnt from his well-funded research programs that in the marginal electorates—which those in the Labor Party are masters of winning and dominating in an election—there is a high migrant population of non-British stock. The Prime Minister has put two and two together and made five. He has decided that, if he opposes everything that is associated with the United Kingdom and our history, then he will win votes in the electorate at the next election.

I have a little bit of advice for Mr Keating. In February this year I wrote to every newspaper, radio station and every other media outlet in Queensland. I enclosed a form asking people to write to me stating their views on the retention of the Australian flag. I received more than 2,000 responses and they are still coming in. They came from all age groups, all ethnic groups and all parts of the State. The result was that, out of over 2,000 responses, a staggering 84 per cent of people in Queensland were in favour of the retention of the Australian flag; 16 per cent wanted it changed.

The advice I would give Mr Keating is that, if he wants to change the flag in the face of all the polling results, he must go to a referendum. If he finds the majority of people want to change the flag, then he can run his design competition. However, until he holds that referendum, any change is not in the interests of the Australian people and I believe will be opposed by the majority of them to his political detriment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that this is not a case for the suspension of Standing Orders. By the time this debate is concluded, it will have gone for one hour and the length of debate indicates that this is a matter of considerable and proper concern to all senators in the chamber.
—Barney, you would agree with a referendum?
—Senator Walters asks me if we agree with a referendum.
—What used to be called a plebiscite, Barney.

—Or a plebiscite. Why should we have a plebiscite to decide whether we abandon our present flag and take on a new flag? There never was a referendum or a plebiscite—and I am looking at the symbol above your head, Mr Acting Deputy President, as I say this—to decide whether we should have the kangaroo and the emu rather than the lion and the unicorn. Why should we adopt symbols like the kangaroo, the emu, the waratah and the wattle? Why do we not have the same devotion as we have to the present flag to the lion and the unicorn, or to the rose, the leek, the thistle or the shamrock? Why did we not have a referendum when we adopted the statute of Westminster or the Australia Act?

PARA.TAB: No matter what we do now in terms of the flag, the change we made when we adopted the Australia Act was a much greater change than we will ever accomplish by changing the flag. What concerns me as we debate this matter is why we should be debating this important symbol and whether we should have a referendum about it when we did not have a referendum about the Australia Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you go to war? Would you serve?

—To be fair, Senator Bishop was not here when the Australia Act was passed unanimously, but many other honourable senators opposite were here. As we rise to discuss whether this is a matter of urgency, it concerns me that the great issues that were relevant for the Australia Act were passed without a referendum or a plebiscite. Why should we have passed an Act which—
—Because we care about it, Barney.

—Senator Bishop, why would we have passed an Act which said that the jurisdiction of the Queen in the States would be limited only to the times when she was there, and that all appeals to the great Privy Council that advises the Queen would be abandoned? Why did we do that without a plebiscite or a referendum?

PARA.TAB: We are now talking about our flag and, if one looks at the history of England, one will see that from time to time England has changed its flag. If honourable senators think of the great battles of Hastings, Crecy, Agincourt, and the Armada where England turned back the attack from Spain, none of those battles were fought under the Union Jack. The Magna Carta was not signed under the Union Jack nor was the Bill of Rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that was signed under a tree.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, it was signed under a tree. I thank the senator for supporting me in this. The point is that the flag symbolises history. The Union Jack symbolises the history of the union of the countries of Scotland, England and Ireland. Great Britain itself was not shy about changing its flag without a referendum or a plebiscite when the new flag better symbolised the history of which England and the United Kingdom can be so proud. If the symbols that we need to represent Australia—which is a great nation with a great history—can be improved, then we should think about it.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this motion, Senator Collins said that we were going to engage in a very long process and one which would give us endless opportunities for future debate. I draw his attention to a statement made by his ministerial colleague the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) in a radio program this morning. He was asked:

SPEECH.PARA: How many have you got in the warehouse?

I think the flag has served its purpose over the years. But even if we do have some in stock, I am sure that they could be quite useful as memorabilia in places.

I think, basically, the situation Australia's in at the moment is that we are quickly moving towards a new flag and I welcome it.
Senator Bolkus does not mention the long process that Senator Collins promises and none of the endless opportunities for debate.

PARA.TAB: I would certainly draw the attention of many people to the actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Indonesia, in Papua New Guinea and in Australia in recent days when he invited children to design new flags and look at them differently. It is very obvious that Prime Minister Keating is only placating the Left faction within his own Party. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH INSURANCE (1991-92 GENERAL MEDICAL SERVICES TABLE) REGULATIONS
The Opposition's concerns with these regulations arose from the changes in the Medicare Benefits Schedule to the fees for optometrical and ophthalmic items.
There are two major changes in the regulations that concern the Opposition.

First, the regulations provide for a reduction in the Medicare Benefits Schedule rebate paid to ophthalmologists to the same level of reimbursement paid to optometrists. Where a consultation is performed by an ophthalmologist and a refraction test is involved, the rebate will be the same as for a refraction test by an optometrist. This means a reduction in the rebate in cases where a consultation by an ophthalmologist results in the issuing of a prescription for glasses or contact lenses.

The Government defends the change to bring the payment for refraction testing by ophthalmologists into line with that for optometrists on the grounds that it is in line with the principle of equal pay for equal work and that there is little justification for the difference in the fee. Our concerns stem from the greater legal liability and educational qualifications of ophthalmologists.

Ophthalmologists follow a similar pattern of training as other medical practitioners and complete a six year medical degree followed by six years of specialist training. Optometrists undertake a 4 year degree to achieve a Bachelor of Science with study in clinical optometry and general medicine. The fourth year includes clinical experience.

It would also appear that there is a greater legal liability on ophthalmologists. As medical practitioners, ophthalmologists are subject to the same legal liability for medical misdiagnosis, misconduct etc.

The second item in the regulations causing concern is that from 1 December 1991 a new item number has been included in the optometrical schedule. This enables initial consultations to be separated from second consultations when carried out within a 24 month period of the first. Previously, both consultations were claimed under the one item number.

This means a rebate for a second initial consultation can be claimed within 24 months of the initial consultation where the patient has one of the conditions as set down in the Medicare Benefits Schedule.

The Coalition is concerned that a number of the categories of ocular conditions covered in the regulations are outside the scope of optometrists. There is doubt as to whether some of the medical conditions are within the scope of both the educational and legislative ability of optometrists. However, optometrists have argued that this change only formalises the circumstances in which they have been operating.

It is for these reasons that the Opposition gave notice of a motion for disallowance to give it greater time to consult with the industry, the Minister and his department, and also to give the Opposition the opportunity to debate the matter in the Senate.

What a mistake we made in thinking that Minister Howe would respond to our concerns regarding the provision of ophthalmic and optometrical services. We received no response to our concerns, but instead the Minister issued a news release claiming our move was a threat to Medicare and we were playing politics with patients.

However, the Opposition's move has met with success as I believe the Minister has consulted with the profession in relation to the concerns the Opposition hold regarding the second initial consultation for optometrists.

At no time did the Opposition ever intend to disallow the regulations and prevent the payment of medicare rebates to Australians. Our intention and concerns had clearly been outlined by both Dr Woods, Shadow Minister for Health, and Dr Hewson. The only one trying cheap political stunts was the Minister, Mr Howe.
In fact, only the Coalition's concerns were directed at ensuring the best delivery of ophthalmic and optometrical services.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be familiar with a report that was tabled on the last sitting day of the Senate by the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs concerning the consideration of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991. That senators' report was very important.

PARA.TAB: I draw attention in particular to the dissenting report of my colleagues Senator Brownhill, Senator Calvert and Senator Crane. SPEECH.PARA: We further note that the reports requested by Senator Brownhill during the hearings, namely, the Resource Assessment Commission Final Report into the Forest Industries and a report of the Inter-Departmental Committee on Resource Security, which was presented to Senator Button and other Ministers about February 1991 had not been provided to the Committee at time of writing this report. PARA.TAB: We now have presented to the Senate the Resource Assessment Commission report on a forest and timber inquiry report which is also a very important document. The report of the Resource Assessment Commission is a comprehensive document and should be considered in detail by all honourable senators, and in fact by all people interested in this debate. In particular, I draw attention to Volume 1 where, under the heading `Improvements in Intergovernmental Processes', paragraph 1.269 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Forest Conservation and Development Bill, if it is enacted, should help to simplify assessment procedures, but only for selected projects. The Inquiry's main concern with the proposed legislation is that it applies only to projects with a threshold value of $100m.
Further on the report states:

The Inquiry is concerned that the project-specific assessments provided for in the legislation could divert government resources from more comprehensive assessments that could provide a basis for planning and management of all uses of forested lands on a regional basis.

That quote certainly underpins the reservations that were made by honourable senators on the legislation not only in the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs but also by Senator Walters, Senator Newman, Senator Archer and myself in the debate in this place.

PARA.TAB: There are, of course, many other references in this Resource Assessment Commission report which also substantiate the views and opinions that we took and the debates that we injected for important consideration. Yet at that time the Government seemed intent on pushing through legislation without thorough and proper consideration, without considering the issues and certainly at that time without the value of understanding and knowing what was to be contained in this important Resource Assessment Commission report.

There are many quotes that could be given to underpin the views that we took at that time. There is certainly a need for the Government to comprehensively pick up many of the recommendations of the Resource Assessment Commission. Senator Cook, in his summary on the legislation at the end of the second reading debate, alluded to many issues that the Government wanted to address. But at that time we knew that the Government wished to pursue ahead at all costs without amending this legislation. That action is now seriously called into question.

I note that the legislation is listed on today's Notice Paper and will come back before the Senate again either today or later this week. I would hope that the Government accepts the challenge of the reports of the Senate Standing Committee and the Resource Assessment Commission to pick up the necessary amendments and to look very seriously at the areas that we have offered, namely, the comprehensive amendments that the coalition and the Opposition have presented to the Government, and that in the consideration of this report all of these things will be taken fully into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pleased to hear Senator Tambling's remarks because it is certainly true that the Resource Assessment Commission has some very harsh things to say about the so-called resource security legislation, which I believe will be debated this evening. However, I must point out to Senator Tambling that the Resource Assessment Commission has actually said that this legislation is unnecessary. If one reads the report comprehensively, one will note that it indicates that the legislation really is unnecessary and should not be supported. So I hope that the Opposition will continue with its opposition to this legislation as it outlined repeatedly with every speaker ad nauseam during the second reading stage of the debate on the resource security legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Resource Assessment Commission report that is before us now is, of course, a long awaited and very important report. I do not doubt that Senator Tambling is incorrect at all in his assessment that this report was kept from the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs at a very important time because it said things about the legislation which would have been embarrassing to the Government that was hell-bent on pushing it forward.

The report is without doubt the most comprehensive and detailed review of the Australian forests and timber industries yet conducted. For well over two years, the Resource Assessment Commission has listened to and thoroughly explored the arguments of advocates from all corners of the debate. It is a report which should be taken very seriously by the Government. It is to the great dismay of the Australian Democrats that this report has so far been totally ignored by the Government.

In this report, the Resource Assessment Commission is thoroughly dismissive of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 now before the Senate—the so-called resource security legislation. Yet negotiations between the Government and the Opposition are still going on in an attempt to secure its passage. I can only hope that these talks are just a continuation of the charade of the past few weeks, with the Government and Opposition desperately trying to avoid being blamed for the likely and inevitable defeat of this Bill. If, however, an agreement is about to be reached, then this report will have been a total—and I stress total—waste of resources and we can kiss goodbye to the ecologically sustainable management of our native forests.

The Commission concluded that the Forest Conservation and Development Bill, if passed, `will entrench the current practice of reactive project-by-project assessment'. This is the fundamental flaw in the legislation. The Commission's preferred alternative is `cooperative, integrated, prospective'—and I stress that word prospective—`regional assessments' of natural values.

The key word here is regional. So rather than frantically examining a forest area only when it is proposed to be logged, we need regional assessments which are divorced from specific project proposals. Only then will we have a solid basis for the ecologically sustainable management of our forest resources. Indeed, this approach should underpin the management of all our natural resources.

The Commission has dealt another blow to the resource security legislation in its finding that, `the establishment of a bleached eucalypt craft mill seems a prospect only in Tasmania', and even there it would preclude other uses of the very large areas of forest needed to feed the mill, possibly including saw log production. The Commission notes that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . forest management agencies would face strong pressure to apply short-rotation, intensive methods of silviculture, and this would significantly change forest structure and ecosystem processes.

There are aspects of this report that the Democrats have considerable difficulty with, particularly the findings that logging in native forests should continue and that State forest management agencies have implemented sustained yield management strategies. If they have that is certainly a very recent development.

PARA.TAB: I make this point to highlight the fact that the Commission did not adopt the conservation movement's agenda in reaching its conclusions. Indeed, the Commission has remained at arms' length from all parties to the protracted national dispute over forest policy. Nevertheless, it has found nothing to commend the Forest Conservation and Development Bill, and has proposed a comprehensive and realistic alternative which would seem to the Democrats to be a substantial step forward towards ecologically sustainable management of our native forests. Accordingly, I look forward to this evening's debate and to the Opposition joining with the Democrats to defeat this very flawed legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final three volumes of the report of the Resource Assessment Commission are substantial by any assessment that any person might make. Mr Justice Stewart, the Chairperson of the RAC, suggests in his preface that it was clear from the outset that the Commission's task was demanding and complex. He said that never had such a wide-ranging inquiry into forest and timber matters been commissioned before.

PARA.TAB: In my view this report debunks a few of the popular theories about forestry in Australia; for example, the definition of old growth forests. The report says that there is no generally agreed definition of what constitutes old growth forests and that the inquiry had attempted to clarify the use of the term. The report then went on to recommend that the use of the term old growth be reserved for forests that are both negatively disturbed and ecologically mature and have high conservation and intangible values.

That definition will put into perspective the countless dozens of forests that conservation groups like to term old growth. But the Resource Assessment Commission also supports continuation of timber production. The Commission also made the point that, on its definition, very few forests can be classed as old growth.

It is also suggested in the report that all forest management agencies have in place sustained yield management strategies. This is not the view of conservationists; it is the view of the Commission at an inquiry regarded as the most comprehensive yet undertaken, so it must be given a great deal of credence.

The inquiry also acknowledges that plantation forestry will come on-stream under normal marketing conditions. That is something that we must all understand. In talking about plantations, the report also said:

SPEECH.PARA: Unless the community is prepared to accept significant dislocation of regional industry and employment it will not be feasible to accelerate the replacement of native hardwoods with softwood resources.
That is an argument that has been going on for quite some time.

PARA.TAB: As far as resource security is concerned, the inquiry was of the view that the Commonwealth Government's Forest Conservation and Development Bill—which we are going to debate later tonight—is largely irrelevant to the majority of producers in the forest industry since it applies only to projects worth more than $100m. In relation to resource security, the report states that, regardless of the possible passage of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill through the Senate, the inquiry's preferred approach to resource security is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to strengthen and revise agreements between forest management agencies and industry, particularly through the development of enforceable contracts that make clear provision for compensation.
That is something that we have been arguing about for quite some time. The report goes on to state:

The Inquiry considers that governments should carefully consider a system of long-term rights incorporating periodic review. The question of Commonwealth involvement in these processes is best dealt with through the intergovernmental institutional arrangements proposed by the Inquiry. . .

Let me reiterate: the cessation of wood production activities in native forests is not justified on the basis of the evidence before the inquiry. While the inquiry stressed that additional research and forest assessment is required, and that forest management and monitoring must be carried out very rigorously, it concluded that all forest management agencies have in place sustained yield management strategies and that these strategies are appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The forest and timber inquiry of the Resource Assessment Commission is undoubtedly the most thorough investigation that there has ever been on this matter. The appointment of Mr Justice Stewart made sure that the matter was going to be dealt with absolutely thoroughly, almost to the point of exhaustion. It is very heartening just to look over the list of witnesses who gave evidence. Anybody interested in the subject could not but be impressed by the list and be satisfied that the industry, the resource conservation groups, the academics, foresters, primary and secondary industries, scientists and ordinary people have all had an opportunity to make some input. I am sure that they will also agree that on the basis of the intensity with which Mr Justice Stewart customarily proceeds with these things the findings must be in accordance with the facts as he has put them together.

PARA.TAB: We only have to look for half a moment at the position of Australian forestry today to see that something is wrong. Throughout the whole of the country the industry is in limbo. We have had bad government interference. We have had bad non-government interference. We have had bad legislation. Now we are left in a position where there is absolute and total uncertainty. There is no employment, no investment, no certainty of any description. The Bill before the House does not provide that either.

It concerns me greatly that at a time like this when we have the Bill before us, even though the report has only been available for about three weeks, I have seen not one member representing the Government make one comment about it in any way, shape or form. It is not going to go away by not making comment about it. It is not reasonable to be trying to whack through second-rate legislation at a time when we have available to us the most valuable report that we have ever had.

I call on the Government either to make some comment about its intentions as far as the report is concerned or withhold dealing with the legislation until there has been time to consider it. I do not think that that is an unreasonable request at all. The evidence that came before the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs in the course of dealing with the Bill a couple of weeks ago so closely resembles the main findings of this report that surely the Government must take it into account. It cannot ignore areas which happen to comprise the same evidence as was put before the Committee a few weeks ago.

The legislation is important for the future of Australia and its regional areas. The Opposition wants to see resource legislation and it wants to see resource security. It needs to be as secure as it can possibly be. If the recommendations that were made in this report were taken into account and acted upon, there could be and would be security for the industry. We could then see such things proceed as the pulp mill in northern Tasmania that we have been talking about as well as works in other parts of Australia. We want to see them proceed but under this sort of legislation it is absolutely impossible. I would certainly be asking the Government to make some comments about the report and to incorporate the suggestions and conclusions of this report into the legislation in a form that could make it work.
