Secondly, the report says that, regardless of the possible passage of the Bill through the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Inquiry's preferred approach to resource security is to strengthen and revise agreements between forest management agencies and industry, particularly through the development of enforceable contracts that make clear provision for compensation.

Again, we have pressed very clearly the need for, at the very least, the abolition of the no compensation clause that the Government has in its legislation; and that if, at the very last minute, a piece of flora or fauna that is considered endangered is found, an additional resource be made available to take that place. How can we possibly expect any industry to invest large sums of money and then not give it the security of the resource it needs to make that investment work? How can we expect industry to invest when we tell it that if, at the very last minute when it goes in to use that resource, some flora or fauna is found, it will be denied that particular resource and it will not be offered any other resource or any compensation?

PARA.TAB: This Commission report comes down very clearly on the side of the Opposition, on the side of the amendments that we have been pushing for some time. As Senator Tambling said, every single person giving evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs—except those from the Government and the conservation groups—supported our amendments. It did not matter where they came from—the unions or industry—everyone supported our amendments and most said that the legislation was quite useless without them.

The Government commissioned this report which has come down very clearly saying that we are right. I sincerely hope that the Government will heed the recommendations contained in the report—after all, it has spent a lot of money on it—and will alter its legislation to fit the final report.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of my colleagues said, I was a member of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs which considered the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. In our minority report we pointed out that it would have been very nice to have had the Resource Assessment Commission report as part of the process of assessing the Bill. Nevertheless, we did not have the report. We came down very strongly, as has already been said, on trying to look after the concerns of the industry and the unions.

PARA.TAB: There has been a fair amount of politics involved in this all the way through, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, being a Tasmanian. At the conclusion of the Committee hearing examining this Bill I was rather heartened by some of the comments made by Senator Cook. Nevertheless, at the end of the day, there was nothing solid enough to make us change our opinion and, therefore, we presented this dissenting report.

Now we have this Resource Assessment Commission report which was brought forward by Justice Stewart. As he said, never before had such a wide ranging inquiry been commissioned in relation to forest and timber matters in Australia. I have here only one of the three volumes of the report and I suggest that quite a few trees were involved in just putting the report together. It has taken three years to produce—it is almost as big as one of Cecil B. De Mille's epics, such as The Ten Commandments.

In fact, the commandments are in here. The report justifies the stand we have taken and it justifies the need for security of resource for this very important industry. It points out that even with Australia's resources of timber and the plantation timber that is coming on stream, we export only about one-third of our forest harvest—mainly hardwood chips—and we run at a very significant balance of payments deficit in forest and timber products. In 1990-91, we exported only $596m worth of timber products, yet in that same period we imported in the vicinity of $1,928m worth. So we have a $1,332m deficit in that area and I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that is something which needs to be corrected.

As previous speakers have said, one of the key recommendations of the report concerns the need to guarantee the wood supply. The report also points out that, in relation to aspects of forest management, the inquiry was of the view that the private sector should make the decisions on the basis of its own assessment of commercial opportunities, risks and investment projects. In other words, it was suggesting that the Government butt out of the whole situation as much as possible.

I was quite interested to hear Senator Coulter's contribution to this debate. I suppose that when we have a report this big, we can expect everybody to put their own slant on it. As to his particular slant about the conservationists not being in favour, when I was looking through the report a while ago I noticed that it said that the conservation movement generally did not oppose the development of a vigorous forest and timber industry.

In fact, the Australian Conservation Foundation, though advocating an accelerated plantation program, was willing to accept native forestry harvesting until the year 2000. That also came through to us in the evidence we received. However, there was a fair amount of stretching of the truth. One thing that disturbed me about the whole thing was that, in my own State of Tasmania, it was put to me that the thylacine had become extinct because of logging operations; I believe that that is very hard to prove, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the Senate I present a resolution of the Legislative Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory relating to a request by the Assembly that the Commonwealth Parliament amend various Acts relating to the judiciary.
—I present a letter from the Premier of Western Australia responding to the resolution of the Senate concerning the filling of a casual vacancy in the Senate for the State of Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter from the Premier of Western Australia, Dr Carmen Lawrence, states:

I regret that the Senate is misinformed. The delay in appointing Senator Chamarette resulted from an anomaly in the drafting of section 15 of the Australian Constitution. I suggest that the Senate might usefully turn its attention to that anomaly.
I would like to draw attention to three features of Dr Lawrence's letter.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I must state that the Senate was by no means misinformed when it expressed disapproval of the Western Australian Government's failure to provide electors of that State with their true and full representation for the opening of the autumn sitting of this Senate and the disrespect this afforded to the Senate. The Senate was certainly not misinformed regarding the failure of the WA Government to expeditiously fill the casual Senate vacancy of Senator Vallentine. On the contrary, it appears from her letter that the Premier herself was not fully informed as to what occurred.

Secondly, the facts regarding the delay in appointment are as follows. The Premier confirmed on 3 November 1991 her knowledge that Senator Vallentine intended to resign on 31 January 1992 and that, following a ballot, the Greens of Western Australia had nominated a successor, namely myself, to the State Government to follow Senator Vallentine when that casual vacancy arose. As recorded in the State Hansard of 5 February 1992, when the official notification from the President of the Senate was transmitted to the Western Australian State Parliament, both upper and lower houses of the State Parliament were sitting. There was therefore nothing to prevent a joint sitting being called in order to proceed with the appointment. The most charitable interpretation that can be made is that it represented a failure of knowledge rather than a lack of political will on the part of the State Government not to proceed at that point.

Thirdly, difficulties arise when Parliament has long gaps between sittings without being prorogued. Across the States there have been varied ways of interpreting section 15 of the Australian Constitution. Page 149 of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice presents the information that on at least three occasions in the past Western Australia has adopted a more liberal interpretation than it chose to adopt in this instance. Therefore, the anomaly which the Premier uses to justify the delay may well warrant the attention of the Senate.

For this reason I have presented notice of motion No. 758 to address the problem that States are not bound by any time limit in the filling of a vacancy. This is discussed on page 150 of Australian Senate Practice. Unfortunately, the Opposition has not seen the importance of a time limit being recommended by the Senate to the States in order to expedite full State representation. Without this motion being declared formal, it is at risk of falling off the business agenda of this sitting of the Senate. I urge Opposition senators to reconsider their position on this matter.

I conclude these comments with the hope that the letter from the Premier of Western Australia urging us to address this issue will encourage the Senate to make a recommendation to the States which can prevent this failure in democratic representation arising at some future time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a brief comment about Dr Lawrence's letter because I find it most extraordinary for it to be said that there been some anomaly in the drafting of the Constitution. The Constitution is crystal clear. Section 15 of the Constitution—the part which is particularly pertinent to the issue at hand—states:

SPEECH.PARA: But if the Parliament of the State is not in session when the vacancy is notified, the Governor of the State, with the advice of the Executive Council thereof, may appoint a person to hold the place until the expiration of fourteen days from the beginning of the next session of the Parliament of the State or the expiration of the term, whichever first happens.

There are options open that Dr Lawrence refused point blank to act upon. This saw Senator Chamarette sitting in the wilderness for quite some time. I think the point is that not only has the State Government goofed on this once but it has now goofed on it twice. The Parliament was not in session when the vacancy actually occurred, but it was in session when it was notified of the vacancy. It was in session after Senator Chamarette had effectively taken over—she had not been sworn in—after former Senator Vallentine had disappeared from the scene. The Parliament did have an opportunity. For Dr Lawrence to say that the Senate is misinformed is the absolute height of hypocrisy. Dr Lawrence should read the Constitution and have her Executive Council understand it. It would be helpful if she, as Premier of Western Australia, also understood the Constitution.

PARA.TAB: I wish to direct some of my comments to what Senator Chamarette said about the Opposition's support for her notice of motion. I suggest to Senator Chamarette that the Opposition has supported her position right from day one. We have not baulked at that fact. We thought that a grave injustice was done to her by the Western Australian Labor Government. Those few people who support her are nonetheless still entitled to their voice in the Senate. I would suggest that Senator Chamarette, instead of trying to beat us about the head, should try to look at this Government, which is the same political colour as the Government in Western Australia, to see whether it will see reason—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have agreed; it is your Party that has not agreed.

—It certainly has not agreed over the delay. It thought that the delay was reasonable. It did not seem to think that there was anything wrong with it. It is absolutely crazy. The Labor Party is in government in Western Australia. Why is it that the independents and the Democrats always believe that we as the Opposition will change the world from opposition? While we got more votes at the last election, we are still not in government. I am the first to recognise how frustrating it is to have more votes at an election and still not be in government. If, on the basis that we did get more votes at the last election, Senator Chamarette is asking us to change the world, I suggest that she get her supporters to vote for a Hewson government at the next election.

—The letter from the Premier of Western Australia has been taken note of. I have listened carefully to Senator Chamarette's remarks and I support the sentiments she has expressed. I would need to take some advice on the proper legal interpretations of the Constitution, a matter on which I, as a layman, do not feel able to reach a conclusive view.

PARA.TAB: I wish to direct some of my remarks to what has been said by Senator Knowles about political blame. There is always a tendency in these matters to seek some sort of political conspiracy as to why things occur. Governments are organisations which take advice from their legal officers. My understanding of what happened in the case of the Western Australian Government is that it received advice from its Crown Law Department that the procedure it entered into was the proper procedure. That advice may not be right, but a government in receipt of that advice is bound to pay attention to it. If it did not, I can well imagine that the political supporters of Senator Knowles in Western Australia would belabour the Lawrence Government, in the context of all that is going on in the Royal Commission in that State, for ignoring the advice of the Crown Law Department and the legal officers who are retained for the purposes of giving that advice.

I do not see a political conspiracy in all of this, I do not see any desire to disadvantage anyone, but I see a desire to try to understand the correct procedures. If there is a breakdown in the procedures—that is something that I will take note of and duly raise in the proper quarter—or if there is a misunderstanding in the States about what those legal procedures are, it behoves us to pay some attention to how they can be resolved.

In the meantime, I believe that to make petty political capital out of this is a fairly sterile and worthless exercise. Any one of the parties in this chamber could have been affected by that procedure. As it happened, an independent was affected. Nonetheless, it does not in any sense mean that the electors who are responsible for a particular senator being in this place should not be properly represented. But these were unusual circumstances. I certainly indicate that I am prepared to pursue the matter within the Government on the basis of seeing what can be done to—

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been done at a midnight meeting in a hotel if it were one of your blokes.
—I beg your pardon, Senator?
—You heard me. You hear everything else.
—I did not hear that interjection. I hope, to the extent that I ascertained some sort of unparliamentary language in it, that it is not picked up in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that I do not see in this any sense of political conspiracy. I am advised that the Government acted on its best legal advice. But if that best legal advice is in error, that is something that our Attorney-General or, indeed, the Senate, might wish to raise with the Western Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In seeking that the Senate take note of the letter, I wanted to clarify what I believed was an inaccuracy on the part of the Premier of Western Australia. I also wanted to take some constructive steps rather than make any political mileage. I perceive, though, that people do not fully understand the position. I quite understand that because we have not had a chance to debate it.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that the facts are as I presented them to the Senate. It is very difficult actually to alter the Constitution in such a way as to rectify the anomaly that has been used to justify the delay. There is a much easier path and that is the one that I have proposed in my notice of motion.

There are three points in the notice of motion. First, it addresses the need for casual vacancies to be filled expeditiously so that States have their full representation. Secondly, there is a need to recognise that there may be a difficulty in the interpretation of section 15 of the Constitution. Thirdly and finally, there is a recommendation that all State parliaments adopt procedures whereby their Houses, if they are adjourned when a casual vacancy in the Senate is notified, are recalled to fill the vacancy, and whereby the vacancy is filled within 14 days after the notification of the vacancy.

A further anomaly arises in relation to the Constitution in that a motion to fill a vacancy has to be followed by a joint sitting within 14 days if notification occurs when Parliament is sitting. There is an elastic period between notification and actually putting a motion for a joint sitting. This interpretation of the Constitution has allowed the State Government to delay its appointment and to be rendered powerless to fill the vacancy.

I have requested that my notice of motion be treated as a formal motion. I have received support from the Government and the Democrats. But the Opposition has expressed the view that unless only the word `expeditiously' is used and unless there is no time limit, it will not accept the motion as formal. I merely took the opportunity to point out that this motion actually addresses the concern that Dr Lawrence is raising.

People may feel concerned that the Senate is not in a position to make recommendations to the States as to how they should act. I believe that this letter gives us a full invitation to do so. It would have been enormously useful to me if in 1970, when this sort of thing previously occurred, the Senate had passed a motion recommending that a specific time limit be imposed or be taken into consideration by States in order to fill a casual Senate vacancy expeditiously.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to say a few words about report No. 27 of 1991-92. This project audit report by the Auditor-General on the Retirement Benefits Office deals with the effectiveness of the information campaign which was conducted by the Retirement Benefits Office in 1990-91. That information campaign stemmed from the changes to superannuation provisions applying to the public sector.

PARA.TAB: On 1 July 1990 a new superannuation scheme for public servants—the public sector superannuation scheme or PSS scheme—was introduced. Eligible persons were given 12 months to elect to transfer to the new scheme or to remain with the existing scheme—the Commonwealth superannuation scheme or the CSS. During this period the Retirement Benefits Office conducted an extensive information campaign to assist members in their choice—namely, whether to stay with the existing Commonwealth superannuation scheme or whether to move across to the new scheme. As I said in my initial remarks, the Australian National Audit Office, as outlined in audit report No. 27, undertook to report on the effectiveness of that information campaign.

Of course, it has not been possible to examine the report in detail. But, in summary, the audit report discloses that although the information campaign was generally effective in providing members with sufficient information to enable them to make an informed transfer decision, some categories of members received unreliable information owing to shortcomings in members' contribution records.

There were also some problems in respect of that part of the campaign related to the development by the Retirement Benefits Office of what was called a ready reckoner, which was a personal computer program on disc designed to permit members to project their benefits under each scheme. There were apparently a number of errors in the first version of that ready reckoner and that, of course, detracted from its usefulness. The second version was due for release in November 1990 but it was not in fact issued until April 1991, which was just two months prior to the end of the year during which contributors to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme had to elect whether to stay or whether to change to the new Public sector superannuation scheme.

It was also found by the Auditor-General that information leaflets designed to provide guidance to members were not properly checked and edited. As a result, the examples in some leaflets which were intended to assist with the choice were in fact misleading.

The Auditor-General's report brings up some specific criticisms of the exercise conducted by the Retirements Benefits Office. As I understand it, the Retirement Benefits Office has accepted and is proposing to take action on the majority of the recommendations that the Audit Office has made in report No. 27 to prevent such an outcome occurring in future. Hopefully the recommendations also relate to the provision of information by the Audit Office in terms of its own record system, which does not have the unreliability that some of the existing information was found to have when this matter was being examined.

I do not want to say too much more about it other than to point out that at the recent Estimates hearings the Department of Finance told Estimates Committee B that 69 per cent of Commonwealth superannuation scheme members had been expected to transfer across to the new public sector scheme but that in fact only 37 per cent have actually done so. That is a very significant difference between expectation and actuality.

This much lower than expected rate of transfer is no doubt due, at least in part, to the errors in the information and the late information to which the Audit Office has drawn attention and to which I have already referred. I think that is unfortunate. I think it is a matter that we in the Senate ought to be looking at in greater detail. An opportunity to do that will occur at the next Estimates hearings following the next Budget. But that is a small comfort for those contributors who may have not elected to change schemes on the basis of unreliable information. The Auditor-General's report is very salutary in drawing attention to those difficulties and one would certainly hope that the Retirement Benefits Office in future will not be subject to the same criticism as it was on this occasion.

I also very briefly take this opportunity to comment on the recent retirement of the director of the Retirement Benefits Office, Mr Geoff Vanthoff, who has retired after a very long Public Service career which stretches back into the late 1940s. He has been a very senior officer in a variety of senior and important Public Service positions over those decades and I take this opportunity to publicly congratulate him on the contribution he made to the various positions he occupied over those many years and to wish him well in his retirement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure relating to developing satellite launching facilities in Australia and the role of government, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure welcomed the opportunity to conduct an inquiry into proposals to develop rocket launching facilities in Australia. Rocket launching was once a field of activity in which Australia ranked only second to the United States.

PARA.TAB: In 1947 Woomera became operational as a guided weapons testing range and Australia, with the United Kingdom, tested a variety of rockets at the range. In 1957 the United States also established a presence there to support its Mercury manned space missions. From 1961 the European Launcher Development Organisation, ELDO, used Woomera for its launching activities.

Australia launched its WRESAT satellite from Woomera in 1967 and thereby became only the third nation to launch a satellite from its own soil. By the late 1970s, for a variety of reasons, Woomera declined as a centre for space related activities, having in its heyday been the world's most heavily used space launching facility apart from Cape Canaveral. Australia has, nevertheless, been involved in the satellite tracking industry for nearly 35 years and its expertise now in space technology for communications and remote sensing is widely recognised. Apart from that, Australia is not regarded as a leading participant in space-related activities.

There is, however, in an increasing number of countries, a growing recognition that there are substantial benefits to be gained from space industry endeavours. It is therefore encouraging to see that there is an acceptance of this fact in Australia and that proposals are coming forward to develop the country's space-related capabilities.

The proposals to develop satellite launching services on Cape York Peninsula and Woomera are positive steps. The Cape York service is intended for equatorial launches of payloads into geo-stationary orbit while the Woomera proposal is to provide launches of small satellites for communications, global positioning and remote sensing into low earth or polar orbit. The Committee's report deals in detail with the proposals.

The Committee also addressed the role of government in the development of launching services, the space industry and other aspects relevant to Australia's approach to space matters. It is generally acknowledged that the world market for the provision of launch services is very competitive and that there is no launching service which is not either government owned or heavily government subsidised. Given this situation, and while accepting that the decision to develop any Australian launch service ultimately rests with the proponents, there will be a continuing role for government participation in the Australian development of such services.

The Committee has commended the roles of the South Australian and Queensland governments for assisting the respective launching services proposals in those States. As the report shows, there are legislative, regulatory and international negotiation responsibilities for the Commonwealth Government in progressing the development of the proposals. In addition, the Committee considers there are other forms of assistance the Government should examine and the recommendations in its report are directed to this purpose.

The Committee has welcomed the proposals for developing launching services and considers that if further studies by their proponents confirm them to be viable undertakings they will be a valuable addition to promoting and expanding Australia's space-related activities and industry. I take this opportunity to convey my appreciation to all the people who gave the Committee their assistance throughout the conduct of the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Developing Satellite Launching Facilities in Australia and the Role of Government, which has just been tabled by the Chairman of that Committee, is the product of 12 months work by this Committee and its supporting secretariat. As Deputy Chairman of the Committee, I want to place on record my thanks to the Committee Secretary, Mr Tony Magi, and all those associated with the general work and research undertaken by the Committee in regard to this particular inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The terms of reference for the inquiry were advertised in April last year in newspapers with a nationwide coverage and in several regional newspapers in Queensland. Invitations for submissions were also made to companies, associations and individuals participating in the space industry and those involved in space-related activities. The Australian Government and the State governments of Queensland and South Australia were also invited to participate, especially due to our interest in the Woomera and Cape York space sites. In all, 36 submissions and several supplementary submissions were received by the Committee.

The Committee commenced its program of inquiry in early July last year with an inspection of the coastal and inland area around Temple Bay on Cape York Peninsula. At the time of the inspection Temple Bay and its hinterland was the only publicly declared preferred site for the possible development of a rocket launching facility by one of the two proponents of the Cape York launching service. The Committee also held public hearings in Cairns in July, followed by hearings in Brisbane and Sydney. In August the Committee received a private briefing from the Australian Space Office in Canberra.

Hearings were also held in Adelaide in October, followed by an inspection of the British Aerospace Australia facilities at Technology Park in South Australia and that company's space manufacturing facility within the Defence Science and Technology Organisation site at Salisbury close to Adelaide. The Committee also visited Woomera for a briefing and inspection of installations, rocket launching areas and instrumentation buildings in the town. Another hearing was held in Brisbane, followed by hearings in Canberra in November which concluded our hearings on this inquiry. In all, some 78 witnesses appeared before the Committee.

The major conclusion reached by the Committee is that a high priority must be given to reviewing what Australia's future attitude and approach will be as a participant in space related activities. The Committee also recognised that there is a growing recognition in an increasing number of countries that an involvement in space endeavours will bring substantial benefits. It is, therefore, important that the Commonwealth Government take a leadership role on space matters to determine a national strategy and to implement positive measures which will provide direction, impetus and assistance for the indigenous space industry to develop in a cohesive manner. To achieve this goal it is important that all sectors of the Australian space community and potential participants are consulted and, if the Government fails to adopt this approach, its lack of commitment to space related developments will be clearly shown at both local and international levels.

The proposals to develop commercial launching services located at Woomera and Cape York are at the stage where their commercial viability has not yet been firmly established. The final decisions on whether to proceed with the developments will be up to the commercial judgments made by the respective proponents. The Committee is of the view that this will not take place without some form of support from governments, and that is particularly so in regard to the proposals for the Cape York space base. It may well be that the Woomera proposals have a much greater chance of getting off the ground successfully without the need for any significant government involvement or intervention. However, I am very sceptical as to whether, in fact, anything can occur at Cape York without significant government involvement.

It is on that basis that the Committee made eight recommendations relating to the development of satellite launching facilities and these were supported by all members of the Committee. The recommendations relate to the satellite launch vehicle project, the South Australian Woomera rocket range and the Scramjet project, which I believe is the most exciting project that is currently under way concerning the development of space facilities and space projects in Australia. From all the evidence that we took it seemed to me that strong emphasis should be given to the development of this particular technology for the launching of space facilities. Of course, this is particularly relevant to the Woomera location because the Scramjet project relates to the launch of low level satellites for communication purposes. This technology and this project offer the best opportunity for Australia to become more actively involved in a space program.

There were also recommendations with regard to the role of Commonwealth bodies, the legislative and regulatory framework that will be required, third party insurance liability, the establishment of a national space council and government assistance for the space industry. The Committee also recommends that if current industry assistance schemes are found to discourage or inhibit space industry development proposals, they should be reviewed and, furthermore, that such reviews should not be confined to the space industry, but should be conducted to encourage development proposals from other industries.

It seems clear to the Committee that it is unlikely that Australia has the opportunity to become significantly involved in the development of a space industry without substantial government involvement, particularly in terms of purchasing payload provisions for the launch of rockets especially in regard to the Cape York base proposal. It is really up to the government of the day to make a final judgment about whether it really believes that its involvement in the space industry is of general benefit to the Australian community and is in the national interest.

The general conclusion of the Committee was that there certainly were substantial benefits to be gained by Australia becoming more actively involved in the space industry. Therefore, I would urge the present Government and future governments to give very serious consideration to the way in which they could become involved in assisting that development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on developing satellite launching facilities in Australia and the role of the Government. I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee and, at a personal level, I found that the evidence we received was fascinating. In particular, I want to make a few remarks about the proposals that affect my own State of South Australia about which Senator Foreman and Senator Chapman, who are also South Australian Senators, have also commented.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, credit should be given to an organisation called Australian Launch Vehicles, which is based in South Australia. That company took the initiative to start a proposal to reactivate Woomera as a launching site for low orbiting satellites. The company approached me as a South Australian Senator even before this inquiry started and asked for support. It outlined the possibilities concerning the Motorola Iridium program and the possibility that some of the Motorola satellites could be launched from Woomera. Unfortunately, that possibility did not eventuate and the main reason for that was that even though technically the preparation of the proposal from Australian Launch Vehicles was very good, in the end Motorola declined to put the consortium through to the final list because it could not actually demonstrate a launch vehicle, that is, it did not have a workable rocket.

Throughout the evidence that we received about Woomera it was clear that the bottom line is that, to get the project off the ground—if Senators will pardon the pun—the Australian Government or governments will have to, as an article of faith, put up money for the design and construction of two rockets and launch them from Woomera with a scientific payload. CSIRO has indicated plenty of interest, and has plenty of ideas as to how it could use a rocket to launch a low orbiting satellite for some of its research. However, the total cost of that will be in excess of $30m and in these times of tight budgetary constraints all governments will cough a bit when they see that sort of figure.

If we really are serious—and the Committee's report shows that Australia should be very serious—about being involved at an appropriate level in space technology, that sort of contribution will have to come forward. If it is successful and if Australia can establish a facility at Woomera to launch a range of low orbiting satellites, the benefits to Australia in terms of technology and employment will be enormous.

I have a particular interest in the communications side. The Motorola program raises the issue of new communications technology. In the latter part of this decade and into the next century the emphasis will be not so much on geostationary satellites stationed 30,000 kilometres above the earth in a permanent position but on many low orbiting satellites at only 100, 200 or 400 kilometres above the earth's surface—a whole network of them continually moving in orbit around the earth, always having one over head and, therefore, always being able to be contacted. The view is that with those low orbiting satellites a message from a mobile telephone device will be able to go direct to the satellite without a dish and then be transmitted anywhere in the world to another telephone. Apparently, the market for such devices is very big indeed. In the maritime area, in the civil aviation area, in remote areas of the world on land and in mining companies exploring in remote areas, there is a strong desire by all to have access to that sort of communication.

I believe that our report dealing with Woomera shows a real opportunity, but I admit that it has a $30m price tag. I also commend the Australian Space Office for putting forward further money this year, with the South Australian Government and the consortium of firms based in South Australia, to do a further definition study on the possibility of getting small satellites launched from South Australia. That report will come down in the latter part of this year and it may be that at that time State and Federal governments will have to be asked to contribute the sort of money it will take to get a couple of rockets launched. I, like Senator Chapman, have wider doubts, though, about the possibility of the Cape York venture taking place. The investment there would be massive, running into many hundreds of millions of dollars. Whether the Cape York option is a goer commercially is, in my view, more debatable than the Woomera option which needs much less investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Kernot interjects, the environmental concerns at Cape York Peninsula, I suspect, are more difficult than those at Woomera.
—Rubbish!

—No. I do not want to start a cross-debate between the Australian Democrats and Queensland Liberal senators over the environment of the Cape York Peninsula. I am no expert, but in both the Cape York and Woomera regions one has to admit there are environmental concerns; Aboriginal land rights and claims cannot be ignored. But, all up, the proposal for Woomera seems to me to be a better chance for us. I think Senator Chapman is right: in the end, to get the Cape York Peninsula launch site operational will require a very substantial government investment in infrastructure. I do not think we need anywhere near that investment to get Woomera operational.

PARA.TAB: Irrespective of that, I believe the report and the evidence we received shows that there is a considerable interest in Australia, in both the private and public sectors, in the need for us to be involved in space research and technology and that Australia should make the commitment—a commitment I support—to invest the money to get ourselves back to being not a major player but a modest although significant player in space research.

I pay tribute to the Committee, chaired by Senator Foreman, and to the secretariat for their diligent research work, much of which was quite technical, in helping us to prepare what I hope will become a benchmark report for the future. Hopefully, in 10 years time, other senators in this place will say that this report led to the re-establishment of a decent space industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a senator who was a member of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure until October 1991 but a member when the majority of evidence relating to the Cape York proposal was heard, I congratulate the Committee on what is a fair and balanced report. I am not opposed to the development of a spaceport on Cape York as long as I can be convinced that the concerns of the Aboriginal communities and the environmental considerations there are all taken into account. That is leaving aside the whole question of the economic viability which, as this report says, is very questionable at this stage.

PARA.TAB: I focus for a moment on what is happening with the STS consortium and the notion of preferred developer status which it has had conferred on it by the Queensland Government. The Committee has been particularly thorough here in updating the information in this section: pages 48 to 53. We were told by former Queensland Premier, Mr Mike Ahern, at our hearing back in July last year, `Any minute now, within two weeks, we are going to be able to tell you who is going to come to the aid of STS; there is going to be a huge Australian injection of capital into this

SPEECH.PARA: project'. I thought that that sounded a very exciting possibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you have to knock it all the time?

—I am not knocking it. Then we were told that this preferred developer status would have to reach its first milestone by December and tell us where the finance would be coming from. It was to obtain $20m by the end of December 1991. This milestone was not met. The Committee was then informed by STS in February 1992 that, although that milestone had not been reached, arrangements were being finalised with a Euro-American financial syndicate for the funding of the project.

PARA.TAB: I am making the point that we have been told time and time again that an announcement about Australian backing in this project is imminent, and it just has not eventuated. We really have to ask the Queensland Government why it continues to give preferred developer status to STS when there is another consortium, headed by another former Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, which claims that it can put the deal together. I find it one of those delicious ironies of Queensland politics that we have two former National Party Premiers competing in consortia to fund the spaceport proposal. However, I think it really suits the political purposes of the Premier of Queensland to make it appear that this project is bubbling along nicely whereas in fact I do not think that is the case at all.

I support the Committee recommendation on page 53 that if a Cape York spaceport proposal is to proceed a high priority must be given by the proponents to consultations on a regular basis with the Aboriginal communities affected by this spaceport. I also support the endorsement of Senator Chapman of the Scramjet project, which is mentioned on page 109 of the report. This is a project developed out of the University of Queensland. I have been out to the university. I have seen the wind tunnel developed by Professor Stalker and his team there. I have seen the prototype of the Scramjet.

It has always seemed to me that we have here an absolute prime example of something which could benefit from the attention of the task force which this Government has set up—a task force on the commercialisation of Australian research. We have the example here of an Australian firm with the leading edge internationally in this technology, and it has been unable to find $1m of government support to take it to the next stage. I think we in this country should acknowledge that there is a structural problem, a lack of development capital, but this is a very worthwhile project which I would like to see the Government support. I commend the report. It recommends that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . senior officers of the ASO—
the Australian Space Office—

during their regular visits overseas, Australian diplomatic missions and Austrade representatives based overseas, be directed to actively assist WBM-Stalker to promote the development of scramjet technology.
I agree with previous speakers who have concluded that there is much to be gained from responsible forays into space technology. The scramjet is an obvious way to begin.

PARA.TAB: I commend the work of the secretariat. We had some enjoyable times; we had some informative times. For someone such as Senator Macdonald to trust a Democrat at the wheel of a light aircraft was a unique experience for me. I congratulate Mr Tony Magi and his staff for the synthesis of some particularly technical information in an informative and readable way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to direct my remarks mainly towards the Cape York space launch facility proposal. Before doing so, I join with my colleagues who were on the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in thanking all of those people who gave evidence and who spent quite some time and, obviously, money in preparing evidence and making submissions. The Senate committee system can function only because people take the time and effort to inform and advise members of those committees.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to all of those who made submissions to this Committee. Some of those who made submissions to us, at quite considerable cost to themselves, have, like many people throughout Australia's history, had an idea, put a lot of money into it and, regrettably, it has gone nowhere. Some of us on the Committee who have never been in business and have never had to invest money in a project cannot always understand what it is like to have a dream, put millions of dollars into it, find that it goes nowhere and have that dream shattered. Some of the people who appeared before the Committee were in that category. I thank them for what they have done.

A very highly qualified aeronautical engineer—I think that is what he was—who gave evidence to us in Adelaide did so as an unemployed engineer. He is the sort of person that Australia cannot do without. He is without a job at present. I suspect that that is because the incentive to go ahead, to take risks and invest money has gone out of this country. It is a shame that that talent, that quality, is sitting there, unable to be employed, because of the way the Government has organised the economy in Australia in recent times. There is just no work for those sorts of people.

A lot of positive things came out of the inquiry. I commend the Australian Launch Vehicle organisation and the South Australian Government for the work that it has done in relation to getting Woomera going again, with the low orbit jets. I, like Senator Kernot, was particularly interested in the scramjet proposal being developed by a private consortium in Queensland, in conjunction with the University of Queensland. It is a very exciting project and one that I hope will proceed. I commend to the Government the recommendations we have made in our report along that particular line. We made recommendations about the establishment of a national space policy council. There was quite a lot of evidence and discussion amongst the Committee on what Commonwealth organisations or advisory bodies should be involved. Again, I hope that the Government will look at that and very seriously consider some of the matters that came before the Committee.

I am a little disappointed that my Queensland colleague, Senator Kernot, appears to be knocking the project—she denied that in response to my interjection. Sometimes it seems to me that we always emphasise the bad aspects: the difficulties, the problems, timetables not being met and where the money is coming from. Those are the things which seem to be highlighted, rather than what I would have hoped from my Queensland colleague. I hoped for a bit of encouragement, a bit of enthusiasm, a bit of saying, `Well, you might not have all of the t's crossed and the i's dotted, but good on you, keep going, get ahead. How can we help?'.

The question of the Aborigines and the environment were mentioned. They are problems that need to be addressed. They took a prominent role in all of the submissions that came before us. I am sure that they will be properly addressed at the appropriate time. I believe that in nearly every case it is an issue that governments should look after and that it should not be left to private developers. In relation to the Cape York project, it is very difficult for the developers to have to go out and make the arrangements, make the ground rules, with environmentalists and Aboriginal groups. Very often, the guidelines are not even there. At times, it is very difficult to know who you should be making the agreements with. I urge the Federal Government and the Queensland Government to take on a more up-front role in determining the issues relating to Aboriginal heritage and environmental matters and not leave them all to private developers.

All the way through our deliberations, when we were talking about the Cape York space base, it was emphasised by all those talking to us that this was to be a private enterprise organisation; it was a commercial organisation. Some of my colleagues who have spoken before me have cast some doubts—regrettably and in a negative way—upon whether that project will go ahead without massive government support. The people who appeared before us were at pains to say that it was entirely commercial. There are differences in definition of what is `entirely commercial' and I might mention some of them a little later. It was intended to be a project with minimum government interference, minimum government involvement and minimum government money. It was to be directed and advanced by private capital from people who were prepared to take the risk and be entitled to the rewards if the project succeeded.

I refer more specifically to the Cape York space base, without in any way down playing the other aspects of our report and the enormous amount of good work, evidence and examinations that the Committee and its members were involved in. The inquiry and report originated from a suggestion by my colleague Senator Panizza with respect to satellite communications and how they might help, particularly with telephone communication in the outback. That was the impetus for the report. It then became a very detailed examination into all aspects of the space industry, particularly looking at satellite launching facilities in Woomera and Cape York.

As the evidence came out, it became quite clear that both of those proposals were not competing; they were complementary. They related to different launches. Using very basic terms, one was a very high launch in a geostationary orbit and the other was a low earth orbit. They were looking at different markets and different users. Both could complement each other. In fact, once we get a space industry going, the expertise, learning and material we gather from that will help the space industry in Australia.

The Cape York proposal was an initiative of the Queensland Government in 1987 when the Government called for expressions of interest. From there a lot of work was done. The basic part of the proposal for a Cape York space base was in relation to the use of a Russian Zenit rocket to launch it. The payload would be the payload of the customer who was organising it. A lot of work was done on the commercial viability of the proposal. The original front-runner on it, Cape York Space Agency Pty Ltd, did a detailed series of figures showing how it could be commercially adopted. A competitor in the activity on Cape York, Space Transportation Systems Ltd—STS—is now the preferred operator in that area. As I say, both of them have given a lot of thought to the money needed and the commercial reality of their proposal.

As recently as earlier this month, and as our report says on page 51, an international consortium consisting of groups of companies from Holland, the United States and the United Kingdom was looking at wanting to get involved in STS's proposal for Cape York. They are obviously the people with the money. I can only encourage them to proceed with what I see is a very exciting and far-sighted project.

Should the Cape York space base go ahead, the benefits to Australia and Queensland will be absolutely enormous. In the area that I come from in north Queensland it will mean a new direction for our higher education places such as the James Cook University, and the proposed university campuses in Cairns and Brisbane. There will be new industry build-up. It will provide a lot of work for engineering places. I specifically mention the NQEA—North Queensland Engineers and Agents—a company in Cairns that has done a lot of work on the space project. It is a company that is involved in high tech manufacturing of that order, and a company that could well do a lot towards developing a space base in the cape and do it very well and at world best standards. It is a project that would give enormous benefits to north Queensland.

At page 70 there are some particulars from NIEIR, which is a research institute, of what a space base in Cape York could mean to Australia. It suggests that the added GDP could be $430m in 1988 dollars. It could bring about a reduction in the current account deficit of $184m in 1988 dollars. The added employment to Australia, a matter that is very important in this day and age with one million unemployed, could be in the range of 4,500 jobs in fairly high technology industries.

Whilst these are to be commercial activities, they do require the support of governments in the way of foreign contracts, and treaties with the Russians and the Americans in relation to the transfer of technology. In general, with the rules of operating in space, these things can only be done at a government level so, of course, whatever happens with Australia's space industry, there will need to be government regulation there.

However, many people suggest that if a new industry is started in somewhere like Brisbane or Sydney it will already be taking advantage of a huge government infrastructure in roads, water, sewerage and transport facilities which a group that is setting up a greenfields industry does not have to pay for if it goes into those areas. Some submissions put to us, with which I agree, suggested that in the case of an establishment in the Woomera or Cape York areas, there would be a reasonable argument for asking the Government to look at helping in the way of some infrastructure assistance—not direct grants on the commercial viability of it, but help in the infrastructure that could be expected if a new industry was being set up in other places in Australia.

I enthusiastically support the renewal of a space industry in Australia, irrespective of whether it operates out of Woomera, Cape York or anywhere else. I am enthusiastic about the proposals that came before us, both from ALV and STS. I certainly hope that they continue. Those companies are prepared to take risks and invest their money. If they succeed, it will be of enormous benefit to Australia and that is what I am interested in.

The Government can help. I congratulate Senator Button for his very positive attitude towards this issue so far. I urge him to continue that positive support. I offer any assistance I can give to anything he or the Government may do in that way. I also recognise that Queensland governments, both past and present, continue to offer support, as does the South Australian Government. That is very good to see. They deserve recognition and they certainly have my appreciation. I commend the report to the Government and urge the Government to accept the recommendations positively.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this late stage before dinner I am very happy to support the recommendations of the report entitled Developing Satellite Launching Facilities in Australia and the Role of Government. When the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure finished the VFT inquiry, we were casting around for a new reference. At various stages I had spoken to the previous shadow Minister for transport and communications in this place, Senator Richard Alston, about my desire to provide better communication facilities for outback Western Australia—indeed, I suppose I should include all the Australian outback.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston mentioned one evening when we were talking together that satellites would be a good reference to consider the next time we were looking for a reference for the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. So probably the honour for getting this recommendation up started with Senator Richard Alston. I took the matter to the Committee where three or four other references were mooted. I must also thank Senator Peter Walsh, who happened to back mine. So away we went and got the reference up. Having thanked all those honourable senators for their support, I am very happy to be speaking about it.

As I said before, my interest lay in being able to provide Australia with regular and reliable communications in the outback. Safety is a prime reason for having such communication systems, as are commercial reasons involving mineral exploration and the pastoral areas. I always knew and believed that satellites are the only way that we will provide communications for every square metre of Australia. Geostationary satellites can provide that direct communication but, unfortunately, it comes at a cost. These days, people can have completely mobile telephones with just a disc on the top of their cars, but it comes at around the $50,000 or $60,000 mark. We have to look at other cheaper ways to provide communication.

As Senator Schacht mentioned, the Iridium project was developed. Instead of having one big geostationary satellite, a band of satellites was used at a much lower cost. Basically, it consists of 77 light satellites in a polar route—in other words, going from south to north—with 7 bands of 11 across rotating around the world. In other words, they are not geostationary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting, I was explaining to the Senate how the Iridium project will work with the low-band light satellites. That will lead us towards personal communications which will be a feature of the future. Rather than having a telephone with one number in a house all the time, we will carry a number with us anywhere within Australia, or within the world for that matter. That will come in time. The Iridium project with the low-band satellites will give a lot of competition to the optic fibre system. The optic fibre system is relatively new in world technology, but this is probably the first project on the horizon that will give it any competition.

PARA.TAB: I refer to Woomera which the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure spent a day visiting. The Committee spoke to witnesses in Adelaide and then spent a full day out at Woomera. I believe that Woomera does have a future; more so with the Iridium project since the satellites will have to follow the polar route.

While at Woomera I was very impressed with the existing facilities, although they may be a little run down. The Government has to look at the idea of bringing back to suitable standard that which belongs to the Commonwealth. Certainly I was impressed with what has been left. I am sure that at some stage, with the facilities that were there, Australia would have been amongst the world leaders of satellite launching.

As Cape York is suitable for the equatorial route—it could also be used for the polar route—its future lies mainly in launching the heavier satellites, the geostationary satellites, which cost much more. That is where the big money will be for Australian technology and Australian personnel who will be able to work there when it does get going, and I believe that it will.

While in Adelaide I was impressed with the technology and the work being done by BAe there. I certainly did not think we had such advanced industry in satellite technology as exists in Adelaide. With BAe being in Adelaide, we have a certain amount of technology transferred to Australians, which is a very important consideration in any of these joint projects with overseas nations. I was very impressed.

The Committee has recommended that the Government look at some sort of support through either infrastructure or whatever for the Scramjet proposal. I believe that it is an Australian first and a world first and, fortunately, it results from Australian technology. I believe that in years to come we will see its benefit.

I do see a future for a proposed launching facility at Cape York. We have been told by an Australian Democrat senator that there will be environmental problems. But the environmental problems that the Democrats talk about will be found if it suits them whether they are at Cape York, Woomera or anywhere else. I do see a future for both of those places, especially Woomera, where a lot of the infrastructure has already been provided.

One of the big advantages of both places is that they are located in a country with a very stable government, which cannot be said about many other places on that particular route. There are not too many places in the world where one can launch satellites for the equatorial or the polar route. There are many considerations. Firstly, the satellites do not travel too far over populated areas and, secondly, the satellite route has to be within so many degrees of either the equator or the north-south meridian as the case may be.

Australia is very well placed both geographically and due to it having a stable government. I see a future for both those places. Mention has been made of a polar route for the satellites if the launching facility at Woomera is not proceeded with. The Albany-Esperance regions of Western Australia have been mentioned. Much as I would hate to see any of the infrastructure at Woomera fall into disuse, I would certainly support launching facilities in those areas.

I thank all the people who put submissions in front of the Committee in Canberra, Brisbane, Adelaide and Woomera. The submissions came mainly from very professional technology people. We heard from the environmentalists in Brisbane, mainly organised by Senator Kernot. I do wish to tell her that I quite enjoyed myself that day when we met with those environmentalists in Brisbane and questioned them to see whether they were dinkum in what they were saying.

I also thank the secretariat for its work in putting the report together and in understanding the technological terms which were simplified in the report. Finally, I urge the Government to take up all the recommendations contained in the report. I believe that they are very sensible recommendations. Australia has a big future in space technology and satellite launching.

As I said earlier, there is a lot of money to be made should we put the right technology and facilities into place and should either this Government or any future government arrive at the right treaties with foreign countries that want to launch satellites from those areas. So I do hope that the Government takes up all of these recommendations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the following two reports: eight performance audits and Social Responsibilities of Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a few comments in relation to each of the reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two reports that I wish to comment upon are report 314, eight performance audits, and report 315, Social Responsibilities of Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. On report 314, the eight performance audits, under the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, the Committee is required to examine all reports of the Auditor-General, including reports of efficiency audits. In report 314 the Committee examined eight reports of the Auditor-General covering the period May to November 1990.

PARA.TAB: These Auditor-General's reports cover a variety of programs and departments, including the Department of Veterans' Affairs; the Department of Employment, Education and Training; the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services; and the Department of Social Security.

As regards departmental responses to the Auditor-General's recommendations, the responses by departments to the Auditor-General's report and recommendations were encouraging with most of the recommendations being accepted by auditees. Only two matters are highlighted in the Committee's report as needing further attention, and both relate to the use of internal audit by government agencies.

On this matter of internal audit, the Committee notes that a major activity currently being undertaken by the Australian National Audit Office is the survey of internal audit in the Commonwealth public sector. The Auditor-General has reported on stage 1 of the survey with the second and final report expected in June of this year.

The survey found that about 70 per cent of Commonwealth departments and agencies had internal audit units and that overall internal audit activity resulted in improved efficiency within departments. The Committee considers that internal audit activity is critical to the efficiency of a department and its accountability to Parliament, and has recommended in this report that new financial administrative legislation require that all Commonwealth organisations establish effective internal audit functions. A second recommendation relates to the need for the Department of Employment, Education and Training to strengthen its internal audit activity. I regret to note that we have commented on this matter previously.

In regard to the follow-up of the Auditor-General's reports, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts plays an important role in stimulating the efficient and effective use of public moneys through the scrutiny of the Auditor-General's reports and departmental responses to his recommendations. The Committee believes that systematic follow-up of performance audits by the Audit Office is an essential adjunct to the Committee's scrutiny of performance audit reports. The Committee in its Report No.296 made it clear that the Auditor-General should accept responsibility for the follow-up of his own recommendations. The Audit Office has accepted that recommendation, as has the Government by providing additional funds to the Audit Office for efficiency audits. The Committee notes with approval that the Audit Office has embarked on a program of follow-up audits, conducting four in 1990-91, and planning a further six in 1991-92.

I now wish to comment on the Committee's 315th report—The Social Responsibilities of Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises. This report is the result of the Committee's investigation of how statutory authorities and government business enterprises—GBEs—measure and report to the public and the Parliament on the performance of their social responsibilities. The report also records the Committee's conclusion that most government agencies still have some way to go before they perfect the use of performance measures, and recommends ways in which this might be done.

I now address the question of social responsibilities. Social responsibilities are defined in terms of the responsibilities of statutory authorities and GBEs towards their clients, their employees and the environment. Their responsibilities towards their clients include making their services as accessible as possible, having means available by which clients can provide input to the operations of statutory authorities, and by freedom of information. The social responsibilities of statutory authorities and GBEs towards their employees include equal employment opportunity, occupational health and safety, training, and industrial democracy.

Some of these responsibilities are imposed on statutory authorities, while others are undertaken by them on a voluntary basis. Whether they are legally required or voluntarily assumed, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts believes that the nation's statutory authorities and GBEs should act in accordance with the highest possible standards. The Committee recognises that there may be pressures on commercially oriented agencies to concentrate on their commercial performance at the expense of their social responsibilities. It is essential, however, that this does not happen.

In regard to the social responsibilities to be included among corporate objectives, to ensure that government organisations act in a socially responsible manner and can demonstrate this to the public and the Parliament, the Committee is recommending social objectives be included among the corporate objectives of these organisations, and progress in meeting all these objectives to be reported in annual reports.

As to measures and reports of performance, the Committee recommends that in making their reports, whether annual reports to the Parliament or reports for other purposes, statutory authorities and GBEs should compare performance with a standard or target; focus on the outcomes; use several indicators for each program, retaining the same indicators over a number of years so that changes over time can be monitored; choose information to suit the needs of the user; and use both qualitative and quantitative information. While recognising that there are limitations on the use of performance information, the Committee believes that agencies should strive for the best possible performance information and develop expertise among their staff in the development and use of performance information.

The Committee's report provides detailed recommendations about the nature of the information that should be reported in relation to equal employment opportunity, training, access to services, activities that impact on the environment, and the activities of consultative groups, including those of statutory marketing authorities. A social responsibility summary is advocated by the Committee as a means by which each organisation can outline its progress and achievements in the performance of its social responsibilities.

On the topic of scrutiny of reports, requiring an organisation to define its social objectives and to measure and report on its performance focuses the organisation's attention on its social responsibilities. If its reports are scrutinised and regular responses provided, the pressure on the organisation to observe its social responsibilities is enhanced. Scrutiny of and providing response to its reports are therefore of the utmost importance, whether they are provided by Ministers, the Parliament and its committees, review bodies or the public.

In relation to the value of social responsibilities, the Committee also considered the means by which values could be attached to social responsibilities. This was a difficult task. The value of social responsibilities may be financial or non-financial. They are of value to individuals, the organisation providing them and the wider community, but their impact cannot always be fully assessed. Most of the information received by the Committee about the value of social responsibilities concerned the cost of providing them, particularly the cost of providing community service obligations, such as telephone and mail services to remote and isolated areas of the country. How the costing should be carried out has been determined by the Government in relation to Telecom's—the new AOTC's—provision of telephone services. The method of least avoidable cost is to be used and it is expected that other GBEs will use the same method. The Committee noted that criticism has been expressed about the validity of estimates of community service obligation costs. We recommend that the way in which estimates are made should be monitored and improvements sought.

On the more general level of dealing with the values and costs of socially responsible behaviour, the Committee endorses the use of cost-benefit analyses. Such analyses should consider both the quantifiable and qualitative aspects of any proposal and take as wide a view as possible of the impact of the proposal on the community and the environment.

In conclusion, the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the social responsibilities of Commonwealth statutory authorities and GBEs is important, and I suspect that in time it will prove to be of great significance. Both this report and report No. 314, which reviews eight of the Auditor-General's performance audits, focus on increasing the accountability of government agencies to the Parliament. I commend both reports to honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
