TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on radiological services in relation to Medicare benefits, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report addresses the current operation of Medicare benefit fees under the Medicare schedule for radiological services and the restructure of the Medicare benefits arrangement for diagnostic radiology proposed by the Minister. The restructure proposes to amend sections of the current table for radiology services contained in the Medicare benefits schedule of the Health Insurance Act 1973.

Essentially, these amendments would create two separate categories of radiology practice—`comprehensive practices' and `other practices'. These would be categorised according to the number and type of modalities provided, the hours the radiologist works in each facility, and the attendance of the radiologist at the provision of certain items. Practices classified as `comprehensive' would receive 103.5 per cent of the current schedule fee for diagnostic radiology services, while practices classified as `other' and general practitioners providing radiology services would receive 75 per cent of the schedule fee. Although this would retain the existing fee for general practitioners, it would mean a drop of 25 per cent in the current fee for specialist radiologists.

The main proponents of the restructure—the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists, and the Australian Medical Association—are concerned that there has been a dramatic and unnecessary growth in plain diagnostic radiology services which places at risk the provision of affordable, high quality procedural radiology services to the community. They see the problem as basically twofold.

The current schedule is said to overcompensate practices providing only a limited range of diagnostic radiology services with low radiologist input and basic equipment. At the same time, it undercompensates practices providing a comprehensive range of procedural radiology services with substantial radiologist input and high-cost, state-of-the-art equipment. This is not only seen as a misallocation of Medicare benefits, but also is alleged to have allowed so-called entrepreneurial practitioners to overservice for financial gain, instead of providing services strictly for medical reasons. Compounding these concerns is the fear that overservicing and inadequate supervision by radiologists of services increases radiation exposure, and thereby poses risks for patients.

The restructure was based largely on the costing models of `comprehensive' and `other' practices defined by Coopers and Lybrand Consultants. These models were supposed to have shown the differing costs of practices, the disparity in remuneration under the current schedule between comprehensive and plain X-ray practices, and the need for adjustments to various items on the radiology table.

The Committee believes that the supposed problems behind the recent growth in radiology services have not been demonstrated conclusively, that the real reasons for this growth are more complex than the Department or College would admit, that the Coopers and Lybrand costing models are not representative of a range of practices, and that the proposed solutions have been insufficiently worked through.

The Committee is not convinced that the growth in radiology services, as reflected in Medicare data, can be attributed simply to overservicing and the profiteering of so-called entrepreneurial practices. The evidence presented to the Committee suggested that a multiplicity of factors underlies the perceived expansion in radiology services. These factors range from population increase, demographic change, patient expectations, advances in imaging technology and the more technical/scientific approach of younger medical practitioners, to medico-legal defence concerns of doctors and cost-shifting from the State public health sector to the private health sector covered by Medicare. These factors were glossed over or downplayed by the proponents of the restructure, which suggests a less than thorough approach to this issue.

Trends of fairly recent origin, such as the higher incidence of sports injuries and the expansion of radiology services to cater for hitherto underserviced, if not unserviced, needs in lower socioeconomic areas have also contributed to the increase in radiology services. As these factors do not appear to have been taken fully into account, claims of overservicing may well be exaggerated and based on an inadequate understanding of recent developments. Furthermore, if overservicing does occur, legislation is already in place to take action against this practice. It is the responsibility of the Department to utilise this legislation effectively and promptly and to provide new legislation if the current provisions are deficient. The Committee does not believe that the proposed regulations are the most effective means of limiting unnecessary services.

The Committee is not convinced that the restructure will result in improved radiological services for the community. We consider that there is a serious possibility that dated equipment will be purchased, and that complex services will be provided by inexperienced persons in order for `other practices' to qualify for `comprehensive practice' status. There are many reasons why `comprehensive practices' may not be the most effective and efficient providers of services at present. Comprehensive practices may, for instance, be encouraged to maintain businesses which are not needed. Evidence was also presented to the Committee which indicated that `comprehensive' type practices have been established in areas in order to win greater market share from rival practices, rather than to meet real community needs. The proposed restructure does not address such problems.

Another likely repercussion of the proposed restructure is that there may be a serious decline in the availability of all types of diagnostic imaging services, especially for certain sections of the population. Currently, extended hours services may well be meeting a need. This need may exist because hospitals are busy or do not provide services after hours, or because other practices are not easily accessible in terms of transport, cost, or available hours. If `other' type practices, or marginal `comprehensive practices', either go out of business or charge higher fees in order to survive, other services may not change to meet real needs.

This highlights a number of major issues that need to be considered thoroughly if radiology services are to be restructured in a systematic and effective way. The Committee believes that the role of hospital services requires greater consideration, especially in terms of the extent of cost-shifting from State health systems to the Commonwealth and the extent to which patients are expected to use Medicare services in the community to obtain X-rays and other radiology services prior to admission to hospital. It is also necessary to clarify the involvement of general practitioners in radiology, especially in so far as they may provide essential services to rural and remote areas.

The Committee emphasises that the consideration of these and other issues must take place within a planning context that allows for wider consultation than appears to have occurred in the preparation of the proposed restructure. It needs to be remembered that changes of the order envisaged under the restructure can have a substantial effect on the provision of services, on the viability of businesses, on the capacity of people to practise their profession, on the maintenance of health and on the operation of State hospital services including the attendance of private sector radiologists at such hospitals.

The Committee therefore believes that the Medicare Benefits Consultative Committee, which provided the formal decision making context for the restructure, in future should publicise proposed changes widely. It should also accept written and oral comment on them so that groups other than radiologists have an opportunity to demonstrate the likely effect of changes and to question the evidence of those who may be seen to benefit most from change. While this may add to the time taken to effect changes, it is considered preferable to take such time as is required at this stage rather than have delays at a later stage.

Overall, the Committee believes that, on the evidence and submissions provided, neither the Department nor the College has demonstrated an objective assessment of the issues. Consequently, the Committee is opposed to regulations which are based on information clearly biased towards one section of providers of medical services. The solutions suggested through the regulations could destroy business, deprive a number of communities of required services, exacerbate health problems and, overall, have a detrimental effect on the community.

The Committee has recommended that the Health Insurance (1991-1992 Diagnostic Imaging Services Table) Regulations (Amendment) be disallowed at this stage and that, to avoid any difficulties arising from the fact that the commencement date for the regulations is 1 May 1992, the Minister be asked to repeal the regulations. The Committee has also recommended that the Department undertake further research, that it consider any changes to radiology services in a wider context of health policy and flexible service provision, and that the Medicare Benefits Consultative Committee and the Department consult more widely on matters which impact on patients, State government services, medical practitioners and other professionals.

Three members of the Committee have presented a dissenting report stating that the cessation of bulkbilling for all persons, except pensioners and health card holders, would discourage the provision of unnecessary services and allow a reduction of waiting periods for those who require the services as a matter of necessity, and they have added a brief supporting statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the interesting facets of this inquiry into radiological services in relation to Medicare benefits is that two weeks ago all doctors in Australia were circulated with a 38-page booklet informing them of the changes that were to be implemented on 1 May before the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs brought down its report. The Department of Community Services and Health had adequate knowledge that this Committee was meeting. It was forewarned of the fact that there would be a delay in implementing the report. It showed scant regard for, or knowledge of, the processes of this chamber to expend those funds and promulgate the report and the effects of the regulations without in any way taking into account the findings of this Committee. I want that on record.

PARA.TAB: I understand that this has occurred in the past. I believe that it is a significant reflection on this chamber. It should be brought home to the Department that, irrespective of the time constraints, it should be aware of the fact that it is not within its rights to do so purely because of constraints of time and the fact that a committee is looking into this matter in great detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) deals with a wide range of issues and amendments to the taxation law. I will come back to some of these in more detail later. The purpose of the Bill is to make various amendments, including those flowing from the Government's industry statement of March 1991—not March 1992, but March 1991, more than a year ago. The amendments cover a very wide area ranging from depreciation provisions to anti-avoidance measures; roll-over relief; dividend rebates; deferral of deductions for trading stock purchases involving prepayments; amendments to the tax file number system; capital gains tax roll-over relief for partnerships so far as publishing indexation factors are concerned; the taxation of foreign sourced income; foreign exchange gains and losses; rehabilitation of mining, quarrying and petroleum sites; research and development; fringe benefits tax; education entry payment and one or two others. There are amendments covering 16 areas in total.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing about the Bill is that it has come in so late after the announcements by the Government, particularly so far as the amended depreciation provisions for capital equipment are concerned. I will come back to that later. The depreciation amendments are to give effect to the announcements made over a year ago on 12 March 1991 in the Government's industry policy statement. The Senate may recall that this statement was initially to be put out by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, but when the then Prime Minister Hawke saw his position as Prime Minister under threat, he moved in, took over the statement and was the main presenter of that statement.

Apart from the fact that that did not work and that as a result Prime Minister Hawke is no longer Prime Minister Hawke, the most significant element was that the amendments to which this Bill relates in the main were introduced that long ago. In many ways that is symptomatic of the malaise that we have in the taxation system in Australia today. We have enormous problems in the area of taxation. The taxation legislation and its regulations have grown over the past couple of decades from a mere few hundred pages to several thousand pages.

Indeed, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 itself comprises 86 pages. The explanatory memorandum comprises 193 pages. If that were not bad enough, if such was the inefficiency with which this legislation was introduced, we now have from the Government no fewer than 16 major amendments to the original Bill. Although 16 perhaps sounds not all that much, in terms of complexity and comprehensiveness 11 pages of amendments are now required. So we have a continuing situation in the area of taxation legislation and, indeed, in many other areas of Government administration, of what would appear, at least at first blush, to be sheer administrative incompetence.

I think it is absolutely unacceptable that we have a situation in Australia today—and we have had it for many years now—where we virtually have legislation by press release. The Government announces that changes will be made to this, that and the other, particularly in the area of taxation but also in a wider range of areas. It then puts out a press release. More often than not this is done during a time when Parliament is not sitting. So these announcements are made by way of ordinary press release and they do not come into the Parliament at all. Then we find that a year or more later legislation is introduced to give effect to the Government's decision at the time that the press release was put out. More often than not, we find that the legislation that is introduced does not accord in all respects with the press release that was made.

During the last couple of sitting weeks a minor Bill relating to amendments to superannuation was introduced into the House of Representatives. These amendments are consequential to changes which the Government made two years ago to principal legislation relating to public sector superannuation. It is only in the last two weeks that consequential legislation has been introduced to catch up with changes that were announced and made as long as two years ago. To a somewhat lesser extent, but nevertheless more significant in this respect, we have a similar situation with the legislation now before the Senate.

People in the accounting profession, and many others—particularly those who have to fill in taxation returns—know just how difficult and complex the area of taxation in Australia is today. It is almost impossible to know and to understand the complexities of taxation law. Even if one is a taxation expert, it is almost impossible to comply fully with all the requirements or not to make at least some errors of judgment or interpretation simply because of the sheer volume of rules and regulations. With the increasing movement, desirable perhaps in itself, towards self-assessment, the penalties for getting one's self-assessment wrong, even for the most innocuous of reasons, are increasingly steep and are making life increasingly difficult for ordinary taxpayers.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) does nothing at all to simplify taxation laws. Instead, it makes them more complicated. It tries to patch up a manifestly crumbling system of law. It tries to paper over the cracks. As I have said, it will put another 86 pages into the legislative framework. As I also said, as if to draw attention to the confusion and complexity of the law, the explanatory memorandum to this Bill runs to 193 pages. Any average businessman would find the legislation very difficult to follow; so would, indeed, most accountants.

The legislators have a basic responsibility in this area. That is why Bills such as this worry me greatly. The law should be simple, it should be straightforward and it should be easy to follow. It should not be so complex that it ties up valuable resources in trying to understand and comply with it. Indeed, more often than not it is incomprehensible even when taxpayers concentrate hard and try to find out what it is all about.

This country needs people to concentrate their efforts on creating tradeable goods and services and improving living standards. We do not need to have those resources enmeshed in red tape. To that extent, this Bill is obviously going the wrong way. It does nothing to make the taxation system simpler, fairer or more efficient.

The depreciation arrangements flow from the industry statement announcement of 12 March 1991. As I said earlier, these are very important arrangements. The amendments to the law that we are debating were first announced on 12 March 1991. They were supposed to contain measures to kick-start the economy. At that stage the economy was in the depths of recession. It was hoped that introducing some increased and improved depreciation arrangements, particularly those relating to the definition of `effective life', would somehow or other stimulate confidence and therefore increase investment in the economy.

We have found, firstly, that as a result of fiddling with the rules and regulations, this has not worked. There has not been increased investment. This is because of the continuing uncertainty as to just what the definition of `effective life', which is the essence of this Bill, actually means in practice. Secondly, of course, if one is going to take so long to get things right in terms of definitions for taxation purposes, one automatically stalls any potential investment growth that might otherwise occur.

It seems that the Government did not realise, and still does not realise, that business investment is largely a function of confidence. No-one can have confidence in a government that operates administratively the way that this Government does. The administrative incompetence of this Government exceeds that of any government—certainly any government in living memory.

The Government seems to find it so difficult, if not impossible, particularly in the areas of economics and taxation, to provide through the Parliament to the nation as a whole certainty as to what it is doing and how it is going to implement its policies. This major factor is stalling any prospect of recovery in this economy. This is on top of or additional to the fact that the Government cannot control its own spending. It says that it is going to accumulate $20 billion of additional Budget deficits over the next three or four years. As we found from Senate Estimates hearings last week, already the figures for 1991-92 are going to be much worse than those that have been forecast either in the Budget or in the Government's economic statement as recently as 25 February. Last week during the Senate Estimates hearings we found that revenue collections to the end of February this year are at least $600m—and probably more than that—down compared with what it had been estimated they would be.

The Government is still unable to tell us what the expected revenue shortfall for the year as a whole will be. The larger the shortfall, the larger the Budget deficit will be and, therefore, the greater pressure the public sector and the Commonwealth part of the public sector will be putting on capital markets and therefore on interest rates over the months and the year or more ahead.

When one considers the impact that that will have on the private sector which will be competing with the public sector for funds in the marketplace, one starts to realise the enormity of the imposition the Government's incompetence, both in administration and in the carrying out of its policy, has on the state of the economy and what would otherwise be the possible resurgence of the private sector. No-one can have confidence when there is a government acting as incompetently and inefficiently as this Government is. This situation is exemplified in this Bill.

The March 1991 industry statement included a revised depreciation regime based on self-assessment that allowed businesses to write off assets over their effective life. After widespread confusion over the operation of the regime and the definition of effective life, the Treasury put in place strict definitions which met the objective of conserving revenue but at the same time failed utterly to meet the objective of a more internationally competitive depreciation regime. The result of all of this has been, as I have said, that many corporations have actually delayed rather than brought forward their investment programs. The Government's contribution to an already weak investment climate has been to add to the uncertainty.

We found that, having made its industry statement last March, the Government in its economic statement of 26 February this year made yet further changes in the area of depreciation. That, of course, has just compounded the confusion. As a result, the Government is now seeking very significant amendments to the Bill before us. We on this side of the House and of the Parliament agree with many of these amendments but it is significant and must not be overlooked that the effect of this is to add to confusion and uncertainty in the private sector and to set back further the potential for economic recovery that might otherwise exist.

As well as being an administrative nightmare, the current tax system is a disincentive to investment and it damages the competitiveness of our exports. Those disincentives have been highlighted recently in a number of reviews of business taxation. For example, in November 1990, EPAC, the Economic Planning Advisory Council, said that Australia's `mongrel' tax system was so disjointed that investment in productive activities was most heavily taxed whilst speculative property investment was taxed the least.

When the Government and other critics go around hammering the property speculators of the 1980s—and I guess we all do that—they ought nevertheless to bear in mind that it could well have been that many of those people were simply responding rationally in terms of economics to the incentives which this Government had created through a very distorted and biased tax system. That is something the Government has a great deal to answer for.

That same EPAC study found that investment by a corporation in plant and equipment faced an effective tax rate of about 60 per cent for five to 25 years whilst investment in running costs such as maintenance faced a tax rate of just 31 per cent if the returns were spread over five years. That report also showed that, in terms of the overall tax impost, the Australian system imposed a higher effective rate of tax on those parts of the economy the Government was supposedly trying to expand. It showed that the depreciation system contained a large distortion in that it undercompensated for long-lived assets.

In December 1991, the Industry Commission recommended that the tax burden on industry be lowered and that tax depreciation measures be reviewed. A report by Senator Button's department, DITAC, prepared at the request of Cabinet and reported in the press in the Australian Financial Review amongst others on 18 February of this year, showed unequivocally that Australia's depreciation regime was less generous than those of our major competitors, particularly for long-lived assets. Some of the provisions we are now looking at in form of the amendments to this amending Bill have been brought in presumably as a result of that and because they were included in the Government's economic statement of 26 February. Yet, again, it is another apparent classic example of a government going about its activities without properly having done its homework.

A report of the Business Council of Australia found that the tax system was a major factor in the decline of Australia's competitiveness. The main problems were found to be in the depreciation provisions and in the wholesale sales tax. Wholesale sales tax, of course, is a tax which compounds right through the whole cost structure of industry in this country, be it service industry, manufacturing, mining or what have you. It is built into the cost structure. That is one of the fundamental reasons why the coalition in its Fightback package is proposing the total abolition of the wholesale sales tax and its replacement by a goods and services tax because a goods and services tax does not get built into the cost structure at all whereas a wholesale sales tax automatically does. The Business Council found that that was an important factor in relation to Australia's lack of competitiveness.

The Business Council of Australia says that, coupled with the tendency of State governments to increase taxes on business inputs, the taxation system increases the cost burden on Australian activity at a time when world competitive pressures have been at their greatest. I agree totally with the Business Council of Australia. That is why, as I say again, we are abolishing the wholesale sales tax. That is why the coalition in government will also abolish the payroll tax which is a major cost impediment on business. It is a tax on jobs.

At a time when we have a situation in Australia of two million Australians either being unemployed or underemployed, it is absolute idiocy for this country to have a payroll tax. We will abolish that payroll tax and we will compensate the States out of the revenue from the goods and services tax and link further growth in the receipts of the States, so far as that aspect is concerned, to growth which will occur in the goods and services tax despite the fact that it will be a fixed rate as the economy grows.

They are some of the factors that fundamentally differentiate the coalition and the Government's approaches to industry policy and industry development and the growth of jobs in this country. We are prepared to take the measures which everyone knows need to be taken to abolish and reduce wherever possible the costs on doing business in Australia.

The Government's so-called One Nation statement is a one job statement and a divided nation statement, given the way this Prime Minister has been carrying on both in his economic policies and in his attempt to continually divide the nation on such issues as the republican issue, the Australian flag issue and in a variety of other ways. What is most despicable of all is that he carried out those divisive actions and statements in foreign countries. He did not do it in his home country but abroad during overseas trips. What must the rest of the world think of us as a result.

It is all part of the division and uncertainty that this Government is creating within the Australian community and economy. It is hardly surprising that more and more Australian companies are investing offshore when one looks at the taxation regime in this country compared with many of our potential competitors. An OECD study released just a couple of months ago showed that an Australian investment has to be 20 per cent more profitable than the OECD average simply to earn the same real rate of return. The reason for that is the punitive tax regime on business that exists in Australia. Also, the anti-corporate bias in our tax structure explains why domestic investment remained so sluggish during the 1980s. It has certainly continued into the early part of the 1990s, despite the recent increase in the share of national income going to profits, although if we look at profits after taking tax and interest charges out we find that at the moment corporate profits are at their lowest since records began 30 years ago.

They are some of the problems that the coalition has seen in the existing tax regime of this Government. We welcome some of the changes that are contained in this Bill. As I mentioned earlier, there are 16 or 18 amendments which have now been circulated, covering something like a dozen pages. Indeed, several of those amendments have resulted from the Government's response to criticisms levelled by the coalition. I welcome that and also take this opportunity to put on the public record my appreciation and the coalition's appreciation for the work done by my friend and colleague Senator Watson in regard to taxation. He is an absolute bulldog both with us and the Government and, as a result of Senator Watson's very hard and competent endeavours, the Government to its credit has been prepared to make some changes in this Bill.

At the end of the day the future of this country and our ability to be competitive in the world and to be able to create the jobs that have to be created if we are to diminish and attempt to seriously tackle on a long term basis the almost criminal level of unemployment that we have in this country will depend on a much wider variety of policy decisions to be taken than in the area of taxation alone. That is why tonight, in the remaining minutes left to me, I challenge the Government—we all challenge the Government and have done so day in and day out with no response—to say why it will not adopt the taxation proposals envisaged and encompassed in the coalition's Fightback proposal.

In summary, those proposals involve a $13 billion reduction in personal income tax; a reduction of between 25 and 30 per cent of the total level of income tax that is paid in this country, particularly by lower and middle income earners. It includes a $20 billion reduction in the taxes on the cost of doing business, that is, producing goods and services in this country. One of the main taxes on business is the wholesales sales tax, which costs business something like $7 billion a year. This is written right into the cost structure of businesses and increases the cost of every activity in which we engage in Australia. Payroll tax costs almost $6 billion a year and is a $6 billion a year tax on jobs in this country, because it is an increase in the cost of doing business. Fuel excise brings in a total of $6.6 billion into the Government's coffers each year, of which almost $4 billion is a direct cost on business. If the fuel excise is abolished the cost of business will be cut by 25c a litre. It is those and other tax measures that are necessary if we are really going to be serious about creating jobs, restoring dynamism and growth to the Australian community and producing the prospect for future living standards for not only this generation but more particularly for our children and grandchildren. It is an indictment on the Government that it is unprepared to pursue that line. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 March 1992, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be opposing the passage of the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. The Bill amends three particular Acts: the Judges' Pensions Act 1968, the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act 1955 and the Family Law Act 1975.

PARA.TAB: Taking first the Judges' Pensions Act, subsections 7(2) and 8(2) of that Act currently provide that pensions payable to the surviving spouse of a deceased judge or a deceased retired judge cease to become payable if the spouse remarries. Those provisions are repealed by clauses 4 and 5 of this Bill. Clause 6 of this Bill inserts a new section 8A, pursuant to which a surviving spouse whose pension entitlement is lost—and it might be perhaps clearer there to say `has been lost'—due to remarriage may apply to the Attorney-General for restoration of the pension.

The Attorney-General may direct that a pension be restored if he or she is satisfied that the applicant is in need or that the restoration of the pension is otherwise justified. In special circumstances restoration may be from a date earlier than the date of application, although that date must not be earlier than the commencement date of this Act. Under proposed section 8B, if the Attorney-General decides not to restore the pension, he or she must give notice in writing of the reasons for the decision and must advise of the applicant's right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.These amendments bring judges' surviving spouses' pension entitlements into line with those of surviving spouses of public servants and politicians. The coalition notes that the number of additional pensions that will be paid as a result of these amendments is expected to be small.

One might ask why, if subsections 7(2) and 8(2) are to be repealed, the new section 8A will say that a surviving spouse whose pension entitlement has been lost due to remarriage, may apply. As I understand it, that refers to persons who have already lost the pension under the existing Act and, under these amendments, they will then be able to apply to get that pension back. It is expected that people who become widows or widowers of judges or retired judges will probably have their pension entitlement continue almost, if not completely, uninterrupted.

The amendment to the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act is a very minor one. It gives the Minister rather than the Governor-General the power to approve leave for members of the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Tribunal. The coalition does not object to that amendment.

The Bill also makes three fairly minor amendments to the Family Law Act. Firstly, the definition of `order under this Act' in section 112AA is amended so that a subpoena issued under the rules of court is an order under the Family Law Act, and the sanctions available to the Family Court for dealing with breaches of its orders will also pertain in dealing with failure to comply with a subpoena.

Secondly, the Bill provides for the repeal of sections 116A and 116B, which are concerned with payments to the States and Territories for financial assistance in family law matters. The sections are redundant as a result of the new legal aid funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. Legal aid services are now funded by grants under section 96 of the Constitution.

Thirdly, paragraph 123(1)(u) is amended to increase the maximum penalty which can be imposed for a breach of the Family Law rules from $500 to $5,000. As I said, the coalition is not opposing these relatively minor changes to the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is discussing the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. The Bill makes a number of largely non-contentious amendments. PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that judges do not contribute directly to a superannuation scheme, whereas politicians and senior bureaucrats certainly do.
