TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill is interesting and important legislation. The Bill deals with a very important subject; namely, that of conscription by Australians for the defence of our country. The legislation has a somewhat long background, going back to the Defence Act 1903. Modern events, which are the background to the amendments to the Act, in relation to conscription are very much influenced by the national service for the Vietnam war, the conscription which took place at that time and the after-effects of that experience, which resulted in a Senate committee inquiry and report. Indeed, there was a private member's Bill on one aspect of the subject by the Minister at the table, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate).

PARA.TAB: As I have said, there is quite a long history behind this piece of legislation. The Bill deals with a very controversial subject, one which has been particularly controversial at times in our history—the period of the Vietnam war was clearly one such period. Of course, it goes back much earlier than that to the conscription debates of the First World War. Despite the very controversial nature of the subject, as well as its importance, I am pleased to say that the Opposition is supporting most of the provisions of this Bill. There is one important exception to that, but we will be supporting the second reading of the Bill. We have an amendment with respect to conscientious objection. Apart from that and one other relatively minor matter, the Opposition will be supporting the Bill.

As I have said, the Bill is an amendment to the Defence Act. The Defence Act tackled up-front the question of conscription. Section 60 of the Defence Act provides that the Government may introduce conscription for service in the defence forces in time of war by means of a proclamation by the Governor-General. In its historical context, that was quite normal. The decision to go to war is a major Executive act. The question of conscripting forces for defence or war of any kind was clearly seen at that time, and since, as an Executive act. However, the Defence Act limited the power of the Governor-General by the issue of proclamation to time of war. War is defined in the Defence Act as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any invasion or apprehended invasion of, or attack or apprehended attack on, Australia by an enemy or armed force.
The power of conscripting Australians for national service is as it has been since the amendments in 1973. That legislation was post-Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: That ability to conscript people for service is very limited. It applies only in the case of an attack or the threat of an attack on Australia by an enemy or armed force. I stress that at the forefront of my remarks on this Bill because it is vital to the Opposition's conclusions on this matter.

The Government proposes to make a number of amendments to bring that basic provision of the Defence Act up to date and to modernise it. Before I deal with that, I refer to the recent history of conscription. In 1951, the National Service Act was passed to introduce national service and to require Australians specified in that Act to be available to perform national service for a time. National service is a subject which crops up a great deal in discussion on defence matters. A view that still commands quite a deal of support in Australia is that all young Australians should perform some form of national service for a period of their early lives. However, I do not propose to go into the position in the Vietnam war period.

The Whitlam Government when first elected substantially repealed that National Service Act. However, it did not do so entirely, because there were people who had certain rights largely as a result of having been called up for national service. Therefore, the National Service Act was not entirely repealed. As a tidying up and modernisation operation, the first thing we should note about this legislation is that it now entirely repeals the National Service Act 1951. That clears the decks so that the piece of legislation which covers the question of conscription, and which should continue to cover it, is the Defence Act.

The Defence Act was passed a long time ago. It set out in some detail who and what classes of citizens of Australia should be liable to be conscripted. As one might expect, at that time the Government was very much thinking of a large army. The view was that it should be a staged process, depending upon the exigencies of the requirement to defend Australia. For instance, it started off by saying that the first people to be called up would be unmarried males between 18 and 35. It then went down various classes to those who were married, those who were married without children and so forth, until finally the last order of people to be conscripted would be males between 45 and 60.

The Government's view, and the Opposition agrees with this, is that this is an outmoded approach. In modern war, with the high concentration on technology and sophisticated equipment, it may not be so necessary to have large numbers of people. Although if Australia were attacked by a determined and powerful enemy, we would certainly need a great conscription of manpower. But with regard to the nature of the threat or the invasion of Australia, it may not be necessary to go that far. It may be more important to be able to conscript in the first place certain people with technical qualifications.

The Government is proposing to scrap those provisions in the Defence Act and replace them with a power to make regulations. In other words, the Government would make regulations which would be more akin to the actual requirements of the day and the circumstances. That clearly is the way to go. No doubt it would be preferable for that to be included in the Act, but the very nature of flexibility that is required precludes these provisions now remaining in the Act. Instead, it is proposed that they should be in regulations.

One other outstanding feature of the existing provisions of the Act is that conscription is limited to males who are British citizens, excluding Aboriginal Australians. These are referred to as the discriminatory elements of the Defence Act. It is proposed that they be removed and replaced by a general requirement that anyone who is a resident in Australia for at least six months and is between the ages of 18 and 60 could be conscripted in accordance with the regulations that we are enabling the Government to make. Again, that is a provision with which we agree. Clearly, the obligation should not be confined simply to males. Certainly anyone who has lived in Australia for at least six months should not be excluded. If such people have made a commitment to Australia and if Australia found itself in dire need of defence, people of all kinds should be available, provided they are within the ages of 18 to 60.

I now come to one of the more controversial aspects of this legislation. Traditionally, imperial powers have felt they needed to conscript people for wider purposes than simply the defence of the mother country. Indeed, that view has been adopted to some extent in Australia from time to time. It has been a feature of laws relating to conscription that people with a genuine conscientious objection to war should be relieved of the obligation at least to serve as combatants. This legislation tightens up and clarifies—in a much better way than did the old Defence Act—the availability of claiming a conscientious objection to military service. Again, as with a lot of the proposals made here, the Opposition has no objection.

In particular, there is a much tighter definition of what is a conscientious belief. The Bill provides that there must be a fundamental conviction of what is morally wrong, not necessarily based on religious considerations. It must be of so compelling a character that a person feels that he or she has a duty to abide by it. It also has to be of a longstanding nature. That latter provision is one of great importance from a practical point of view in how far people would be able to succeed in claiming conscientious objection.

We support what I see as a tightening up of the existing provisions. However, the Bill goes on to provide a new ground for exemption from compulsory service, and that is that the person claiming it may claim conscientious objection to the service in relation to a particular war or warlike situation. The Opposition does not believe that that is an appropriate provision to make in the Bill and we will be moving to delete it in the committee stage.

We see this particular provision extending this area of conscientious objection as arising very much out of the circumstances of the Vietnam war. It was certainly very much to the forefront of the Senate committee which investigated this question and which, in fact, recommended that there should be available a conscience belief in these cases. But I come back to my original point. It has been overlooked that under the Defence Act we are now dealing with, the only power for conscription which a government will have—and has had for some time now—will arise in the very limited circumstances that Australia is invaded or is under the threat of invasion.

So we are talking here about circumstances in which Australians are being asked to defend Australia itself—maybe our territories which are near the Australian mainland. So we will, if necessary, have to conscript people to defend their own country. In these circumstances we think it is unbelievable that people should be acknowledged to have the right of conscientious objection to actually defend their own country. It was much more a problem and much more relevant when Australians were being conscripted to serve way beyond Australia's shores or areas of direct military interest, as they were in the case of Vietnam, although there were many good arguments that they were performing a very important role for the ultimate defence of Australia. But the fact is that we have quite a different situation here. Quite clearly, under the Defence Act we would be conscripting people simply to defend Australia itself.

There may be some debate on whether or not the circumstances of a threat to Australia are justified, but that matter is dealt with by the Government—and it is something that perhaps I should have mentioned earlier—providing in this legislation that Parliament itself should have to agree to a proclamation for conscription. That is certainly an important addition to the existing Act, which leaves that for an executive decision. This Act now will tidy that up and strengthen it, and say that there must be parliamentary approval for any such proclamation. That is important in relation to a government that comes along and says, `We want to conscript. Nobody is about to invade Australia but there is a real threat that there could be an invasion of Australia'. So that will not be left to the Executive but will be a decision for the Parliament.

That having been decided by the Parliament, we believe that a person who wants to claim a conscientious objection would have to be able to establish a conscientious objection to participate in war itself or warlike operations. If the Government's proposal were accepted now to expand conscientious belief in the way this Bill does, we believe that it would be very difficult indeed to sort out whether people had political objections only, as against genuine objections. That would be a practical difficulty.

It would also be very divisive for the community that people could, in fact, claim a conscientious objection when Australia was about to be invaded or, indeed, was invaded. If people were able to say, `No, I object to being invaded by this particular country but not another', that would be an impossible position to maintain as far as the morale of the whole community was concerned in the defence of Australia. To believe that people can pick and choose who would be a desirable or an undesirable invader, where one could have a conscientious objection to one country but not another, would be impossible to sell. Circumstances of that kind would create a tremendous division and affect morale in Australia, which would be very serious as far as the defence of the nation is concerned.

For those reasons we see this situation now as quite different from the Vietnam situation or a similar type of situation. In these circumstances, all these factors which are great improvements and which we support—the modernisation of this legislation, its adequate definitions now of conscientious objection, and the need for parliamentary approval for conscription—are spoilt by this innovation which we will oppose.

TALK.START.PARA: —In following my colleague Senator Durack who has spoken about the conscription, conscientious objection and repeal of the national service aspects of the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill, I intend to cover that part which relates predominantly to military superannuation but also to defence home loans. Before I do, I would like to add to what Senator Durack said about the important removal of the antiquated legislation which only allowed certain classes of people to be conscripted to defend Australia. It is both right and proper that the legislation be amended to include all able-bodied men and women to come to the defence of this country if it is under threat. I believe that no less can be expected of people who enjoy the freedom and the rights that they have in this country than that they must be prepared to defend it if attacked.

PARA.TAB: Before I speak to the specific amendments I would like to speak generally about military superannuation. When the DFRDB was introduced in 1973 it was not at that time a bad superannuation scheme. Most people in those days worked in one job for 20 years or more and the DFRDB scheme reflected this, paying handsome benefits to those who served in the military for 20 years or more. The DFRDB has not kept up with society and the increasing mobility of the modern work force. People these days are more likely to change their job or their profession than not. The defence forces are not exempted.

Most superannuation schemes now accommodate people in a transient work force. The DFRDB remains a good scheme only for those who served 20 years or more with the forces. It offers nothing to those who serve for less than 20 years. In fact, it is not even really a superannuation scheme. In recent years only approximately 27 per cent of DFRDB members have received any benefit at all and of those that do, only a small proportion—one in 194—receives full retirement benefits.

The DFRDB does not meet the occupational superannuation standards. It is a compulsory 5.5 per cent of salary for all Defence Force members, paid directly into Consolidated Revenue rather than into an earning fund. Effectively, therefore, it is a $100m a year interest-free loan from defence personnel to the Government. It refunds members only their own contributions without earnings if they leave before 20 years. It includes a 3 per cent penalty for every year an officer leaves before the statutory retiring age, which means that they receive back less than their own contributions. Members of the Defence Force, by nature of their employment, have not been able to take a stand against such inequities. While the Government is coercing the private sector superannuation schemes into improving arrangements for the granting of employer contributions for those who resign early, the scheme which covers the nation's defence forces is being ignored.

In 1989 the Opposition, in its defence science and personnel policy, announced that it would ensure that defence personnel were not disadvantaged compared to the civilian community in relation to superannuation. In developing our policy, we recognised that Defence Force members were not paid interest on their contributions and that for those leaving before the 20-year mark this was a gross injustice. Fortunately, the Government eventually recognised this too. The Opposition's persistence had been effective, and the Government being in a position to take action did so with the implementation of the MSBS—a considerably better superannuation scheme.

The new scheme is something which I think deserves credit. The MSBS meets all the occupational superannuation standards. It pays interest on contributions—contributions which can be raised from 5 per cent up to 10 per cent as the member requires to suit his or her retirement needs. It has a very handsome government component which rises from 18 per cent to 28 per cent of salary and is fully government-vested after seven years. It includes a retention benefit of one year's salary taxed at the 15-year mark to encourage experienced service men and women to remain in service for another five years. There are many benefits under MSBS and Defence Force members should take the time to acquaint themselves with them.

It surprises me to learn, as I did during the additional Defence appropriations at the Estimates Committee, that there was a lower than expected take-up rate for MSBS. Perhaps they were all waiting until the last minute, until September of this year when they must make a decision on whether to take it up or to stay with the DFRDB scheme. I am sure that an element of the problem is that for years the defence forces have learnt to distrust the Government and to be suspicious of decisions it makes. It has a bad track record and defence personnel are reluctant to believe it this time around.

They only have to look back to 1986 when the Government legislated for a 2 per cent discount to be applied to the 1986 superannuation pension increase applied to government superannuation benefits payable to or in respect of former Commonwealth employees and Defence Force personnel. It effectively reduced the base on which superannuation pensions were to be calculated. Defence personnel were told that the 2 per cent discount of their superannuation pension would be restored once Australia's foreign debt, expressed as a proportion of GDP, was on a falling trend. I cannot imagine the Government trying to get away with doing this to one of the industry groups with union support. In 1989, after much pressure from the Opposition, the 2 per cent discount was restored. Inevitably, however, it leaves Defence Force personnel sceptical. Superannuation is their future and the Government has tampered with it before.

Some who may want to stay in DFRDB because they are nearing the 20-year mark are worried in case they are made redundant before 20 years, at the 19-year mark. They will only get a refund of their contributions rather than a meaningful retirement income. During the Estimates hearing it was highlighted that this could lead to redundancies based on the type of retirement plan a member had rather than on the needs of the Force.

My concern is whether defence personnel are receiving adequate advice. An amount of $2.7m has been budgeted over two years to assist defence personnel in making their decision. This money is primarily being used to fund a superannuation information group to provide counselling to defence personnel, but many do not seem to be aware of it. I am also concerned that some defence personnel are not taking the time to find out what best suits them—and each case is different. It infuriates me that some people misinterpret aspects of MSBS and then circulate the misinformation. What is worse is that people then take the misinformation as gospel rather than checking it out for themselves.

Superannuation is a complex area. People should not listen to rumours, even those that sound convincing and come from senior levels. People should be responsible for their own futures and take the time to find out for themselves, even if it means seeking independent professional advice.

I now turn to the specific amendments that this Bill makes to superannuation. They are basically housekeeping amendments. The first is an amendment to the Military Superannuation Benefits Scheme Act of 1991. Section 47 of the MSBS Act personally indemnifies the trustees of the MSBS Board of Trustees, the Commissioner of Superannuation and the staff assisting the Commissioner from any action, liability, claim or demand arising from the bona fide performance of their duties or functions. These amendments extend the indemnity provisions to cover an acting trustee, a member of an incapacity classification committee, and a member of a reconsideration advisory committee.

The Opposition was initially concerned about this amendment; indemnification from professional responsibility should not be allowed. However, we have since been advised that the amendments relate to personal indemnification only. The amendment does not affect the corporate liability of the Board as a whole, which liability is retained by section 47(2) of the Act.

The second amendment in this Bill is to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973. It amends subsection 14(3) of the DFRDB Act, enabling the deputy of the chairman of the DFRDB Authority to preside at meetings in the absence of the chairman, taking precedence over the deputy chairman. If that sounds like Alice in Wonderland stuff, I believe that it is. But the Bill also ensures that a quorum is maintained—obviously an important matter.

Thirdly, the Bill amends the Defence Forces Retirements Act 1948. Honourable senators will recall that DFRB was the scheme that existed before DFRDB and that it closed to new entrants when DFRDB began in 1973. Given that it did close in 1973, a number of provisions in the DFRB Act are now obsolete. These amendments repeal the obsolete provisions which deal predominantly with fund contributions.

Before turning to the home loan amendments of this Bill, and before I leave the subject of superannuation, I think I should highlight a few of the Fightback initiatives which the Opposition proposes for the superannuation area and which will be of benefit to defence personnel. We will abolish all lump sum tax on superannuation pay-outs, abolish the absurd reasonable benefits limit, provide a 25 per cent tax rebate to all individuals who contribute or have contributions made on their behalf to superannuation funds up to $6,000 per year, and reduce the tax on employer contributions from 15 per cent to 5 per cent for those on incomes up to $55,000 per annum.

The other amendments in this Bill relate to defence home loans. Firstly, the Bill makes amendments to the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act 1990. The Defence Housing Authority Act, which establishes a home loans assistance scheme for members of the Defence Force, makes special provisions for incapacitated persons. The current definition in section 3 covers incapacitated persons who are discharged because of a compensable disability on or after the commencing day, which is 21 January 1991. An unintended consequence of this is that some incapacitated persons who joined the Defence Force after 14 May 1985—the cut-off point for eligibility under the old defence services homes scheme—and were discharged before 21 January 1991 are not covered by either the old or the new scheme.

The Bill amends section 3 to ensure that the definition of `incapacitated person' includes persons who are not currently covered by either scheme. The Bill also amends section 4 of the principal Act so that incapacitated persons who are affected by the amended definition have two years to exercise their entitlement. That is the same entitlement of all service personnel under this new Bill.

Further, to have an entitlement to a home loan under the Act a member must be issued with an entitlement certificate. Section 13 enables certificates to be cancelled where they are found to be issued as a result of false or misleading statements or where entitlement did not exist. However, there is no provision to vary or reissue certificates in order to correct errors or omissions. The proposed amendment will enable the Secretary to the Department of Defence, who issues certificates, to vary or reissue them, effective from the time the original certificate was issued.

Finally, the Bill amends the Defence Housing Authority Act 1987 by amending the appointments by the Governor-General to the Authority to include the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Personnel) as the fourth member of the Defence Housing Authority. This move reflects a change in ADF higher structures. This, like all the previous amendments, will be supported by the Opposition.

Before I conclude, I must emphasise that I remain dissatisfied that in introducing the new defence home loans scheme the Government removed the entitlement to a home loan for war service. The fact that it did so at the same time the former Prime Minister was waving the troops off to the Gulf war adds insult to injury. As it remains, Australians who enlisted since May 1985 and on operational service are killed, or injured and invalided out of the Services no longer have an entitlement to a war service loan and nor does their surviving spouse. This is the first time since 1918 that Australians in war have not had such an entitlement, and the Government should be ashamed. This will now be the case for our personnel serving in Cambodia.

What of the personnel serving in Cambodia? In the litany of rough deals meted out by this Government to service men and women and ex-service men and women during its nine years in government, the treatment of the Cambodian peacekeepers takes the cake. If these people were unionists, peace would be on strike now in Cambodia. Our people went to Cambodia believing they would be dealt with in the same way as those who served in Namibia. Not so. Once the first two detachments had been deployed to Cambodia, the truth leaked out.

The salaries of the Australian UNTAC peacekeepers in Cambodia and their $60 per day Cambodia allowance are to be taxed once the UN ceasefire has been called. Cambodia, like the Namibia peacekeeping involvement before it, will have our service men and women peacekeepers operating in dangerous, unmapped minefields, constantly subject to the threat of injury and disease, long after the ceasefire declaration. Yet the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, will not let them have the same tax-free status that was given to the Namibia peacekeepers.

Determination No. 108 of 1991 made by the Department of Industrial Relations and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill soon to be introduced into the House of Representatives confirm what I say. This Government has long had a shabby record regarding the treatment of Australian servicemen, as I said before. Yet we heard the Government's hypocrisy in our Anzac Day speeches about remembering the bravery of Australian servicemen, their sacrifice and their willingness to lay down their lives for their country. I cannot believe that it is anything other than disgraceful that a Prime Minister can deliver words such as he did in Papua New Guinea when he is prepared to savage the compensation of those doing just that in the dangerous conditions of Cambodia—willing to lay down their lives for their country.

The Prime Minister also said in his Anzac Day speech that the Australians who went to two world wars or to Korea, Malaya or Vietnam, went to secure a place in the world for their country and for its ideals. If we are not doing that with these service men and women who have gone to Cambodia, what are we doing? They are there to secure a place in the world for their country and its ideals, just as much as their fathers and grandfathers did before them. Yet this Government is prepared to make fine speeches a substitute for proper action for those who risk their lives in the service of this country.

These personnel will lose the tax-free status of their pay after the ceasefire, which will be an artificial declaration if ever there was one, because the minefields will still be there; there will still be the gung-ho chappies with their rifles slung over their shoulders ready to run off a burst when they feel inclined. Also, these service men and women will be given a lesser degree of coverage under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Once they are no longer declared to be on operational service, the proof required will be more demanding under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The proof required is not just that they are serving in an operational area any more, but that their disease or injury was caused by that service. Sometimes, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would know from constituents who come to see you, years down the track when the effects of disease or injury incurred in war finally start to show their long term effects, it is often quite difficult to prove the connection with the war service, the operational service, which caused the problems the veteran is enduring.

It may not be of great moment to the Government of this country, but it is of considerable moment to the men and women and their families who have been sent away with bands and speeches to preserve the peace for our region, the reason that our Prime Minister tells us—and rightly so—is important to our future as a country. We send them away to preserve the peace in our region and we play this shabby trick on them as soon as they have left our shores. The Government should be condemned for its hypocrisy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before us tonight is the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. In general, this legislation makes amendments to the provisions concerning conscription and conscientious objection. It provides for the appointment of an assistant Chief of the Defence Force to the Defence Force Housing Authority and makes some changes to the provision of defence retirement benefits and the home loan assistance scheme.

PARA.TAB: I do not propose to take the time of the Senate tonight to refer to the provisions of the Bill relating to the Defence Housing Authority and the defence retirement scheme. I wish to confine my remarks briefly to what I find wrong with the Bill. What I find wrong with the Bill is, firstly, the 90-day requirement and the lack of flexibility that that confers on the Government of the day; and, secondly, the quite ludicrous proposition that, somehow or other, one can have the right to object to a particular war.

I will comment briefly on the history of conscription in Australia. It is not generally realised that conscription has been a factor in Australia since Federation for very many years. It existed before the First World War; it existed in the 1920s; it existed, I think, in the 1930s after the Labor Government was thrown out of office after having given us the first Great Depression that it has given us this century; and it existed on two occasions—in the 1950s and in the 1960s—with two separate schemes. I am one of the few people in this Senate who have discharged a national service obligation and I value the experience that was afforded me by the obligations that were placed on me by the Government of that day.

It is quite wrong to say that conscription was always a controversial issue in Australia. For example, the period of conscription from 1949 to 1959 was a period when there was no dissent about conscription of the Australian youth. There were no protests in the period before World War II, as I understand it. But the myth has been created by the Labor Party in light of the Vietnam experience that, somehow or other, conscription is always controversial and totally destructive of the good order of Australian society, so it cannot be entertained at all.

There is a place for conscription in the life of a nation when it looks to its own defence. I do not think it is a high priority today. I think we have higher priorities in providing a basic defence force than conscription today. But I place on record that the view that is sedulously cultivated by the Labor Party that conscription has been a very divisive issue and an issue which has divided the Australian community is a false one, like most of the Labor Party's views of Australia's military history.

The fact is that in today's climate around the world, of high technology weapons systems, we do really need a high degree of professional ability in the defence forces. We need specialist training to operate those systems and the short term commitment that national service or a conscription program provides really does not suit itself to the provision of highly professional, highly trained forces that the countries of the Western world have now adopted.

It is interesting to note that the United States and the United Kingdom have moved away from conscription. Switzerland and Sweden are probably the only countries in the European theatre that exercise conscription. I would forecast that with the winding down of the Cold War, Swedish conscription will probably disappear in the foreseeable future. The Swiss will probably maintain it.

What goes on in the Asian region, of which we are part, is another matter. Conscription is practised by Singapore and various other Asian nations will practise it from time to time. While I agree that there is no need for it for Australian defence requirements at present, I have enough knowledge of history to have a very strong desire for flexibility in our planning. I certainly would not exclude the fact that the need for it might arise in the future.

As I said before, I have a marked concern about the 90-day requirement for notification to be given, which I think limits the flexibility of the Government. Part of that relates to the definition of `war' contained in the Act. It defines `war' in terms of threats to Australia and an imminent Australian invasion. There are a couple of problems with that. The first is that countries seldom declare war these days. The old convention of a declaration of war, followed by the outbreak of hostilities and a peace treaty after the surrender of one side—sometimes unconditional surrender—has all disappeared. That is not the way armed conflict between nations is now conducted.

We have to recognise the fact that we live in a world where there will not be formal declarations of war and we should not be constrained legally to the fact that Australia is facing imminent invasion before acting. Clearly definable and demonstrable threats of that nature may well be impossible to demonstrate. It might well be an obligation on the Government to take prudent steps to reinforce Australia's defence capacity in the light of what are intangible threats. In certain circumstances some sort of conscription may be required to meet that threat adequately.

I want to deal with the point about the objection to a particular war. It has been a basic part of our cultural values that we have always accepted the right of a citizen not to serve in the armed forces on the basis of sincerely held religious and moral beliefs. The presumption is that they are long term. The introduction of this clause, which allows a person to have a particular objection to a particular war and therefore not serve, is absolutely impractical and wrong-headed in my judgment. It would expose Australia to the risk that we would be very much divided on religious grounds. If we were being attacked by a Muslim force, the Muslim community may decide, for example, that it was not going to enter into armed conflict with its Muslim brothers.

That would be extremely divisive for Australia because we have certain cultural values which do not admit those distinctions. We admit that someone on a sincerely held conscientious belief against the violence of war has a right to claim exclusion from conscription. As part of our cultural values, we also hold the belief that it is the business of all to defend the country in times of great need. I would respectfully suggest that this is one of the further examples of what we are seeing from the Government as part of its long history of an inability to cope adequately with the needs of Australian defence.

Senator Newman said some things about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who is exhibiting all the old isolationist tendencies of the Australian Labor Party. He is also demonstrating not only a profound ignorance in international affairs but a profound ignorance about Australia's military history.

TALK.START.PARA: —On which, of course, you are an expert.

—At least I take the time to read. I do not sit there and look into space. I have an interest not only in military history but in political history. I find that increasingly I spend more and more time doing so because history has a way of repeating itself. The sins of the Labor Party are not new or novel in any way at all. They have been manifested in this country ever since the Party got together as a bunch of striking shearers in 1890, and they keep on coming back.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at a statement made by the Prime Minister last week in an interview with Mr Greg Sheridan. He made accusations against Mr Menzies, Mr Page and the other members of the United Australia Party and its predecessors in the early part of the Second World War, before Menzies was pulled down by the Country Party revolt and Artie Fadden was put in as Prime Minister in 1941. As part of the Anzac Day celebrations last week, we were celebrating the New Guinea campaign. The Prime Minister makes the claim that it was Curtin and the Australian Labor Party that saved Australia, and that the predecessors to that Government had done nothing to contribute to the defence of Australia. Nothing could be further from the truth. In the 1930s under the Lyons Government, the United Australia Party started the rearmament program—in the face of intense opposition from the Labor Party. Eddie Ward, who bore an uncanny resemblance to the present tendencies of the present Prime Minister, was always saying, `We want to take that money from defence and spend it on welfare; it is criminal to be spending money on defence'.

The United Australia Party, the predecessor of the Liberal Party, started the industrial expansion of a country that could not even build cars beforehand. It gave us the ability to build our tanks, engines, aircraft engines, ships, armaments and munitions. That was all up and going in 1941 when the Japanese attacked. It raised something like 12 divisions; there were 10 divisions in Australia when Japan attacked and two overseas. It raised an air force, which ultimately was the fourth largest in the world, and a sizeable navy. All of those things were done. And not one of them would have been done by a Labor government if it had been in power in the 1930s. The proposition that is being run before the uninformed people of Australia that somehow or other the Curtin Government and the Labor Party were the great saviours of defence is a travesty of the truth. I am not prepared to put up with the Prime Minister telling lies about the military history of this country. The matters are far too important for that.
On the subject of Cambodia, I do not want to go into much detail, but I did not get the opportunity to speak on that matter when it came before the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not relevant to this Bill, so why should we?

—It is very relevant because it relates to defence. I am trying to educate the Minister. That might be an exercise in extreme optimism, but I am prepared to try. He should stay awake and listen to me.

PARA.TAB: On the Cambodian issue, the Prime Minister said that Australian troops will not be at risk. They are at very great risk. It is very possible that some of those Australian troops, sadly, will be injured and some may be killed. I believe it is quite wrong for the Prime Minister to tell the Australian community that we are sending troops over there and that, if there is any sign of trouble, we will pull them out. That has two implications. It is misleading the Australian public to the extent that the Prime Minister is saying that those troops are safe and secure—as safe and secure as if they were in mainland Australia. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The other side of the proposition is absolute nonsense. Our troops are integrated into a United Nations force. They provide a crucial function—communications. If things get difficult, if the Khmer Rouge, for example, play up, revolt and start the tricks that they have been at for the last 20 years in terms of armed warfare, does the Prime Minister really believe that the vital communications functions of the Australian Defence Force are going to be pulled out, that the Australians are going to cut and run and leave to their fate the Indonesians and all of the other members of the United Nations, who are probably in a combat role trying to quell what the Khmer Rouge are up to? That is a ludicrous proposition.

The Prime Minister should be adult enough to say to the Australian people, `We believe that we have an obligation to the community of nations to support the United Nations in this effort. We will do all that we can to minimise the risk to the Australian contingent up there. But we must recognise that there is a risk and that they may pay with their lives on some occasions'. The Australian community is adult enough to accept that. Instead, we have all this dissembling from the Prime Minister that they will be pulled out if there is any trouble. The other misapprehension that the Prime Minister has created in the Australian community is that somehow or other Lieutenant-General Sanderson, an Australian general up there, will look after the Australian troops. Lieutenant-General Sanderson is the United Nations force commander. His obligations are to the United Nations; they are not to the Prime Minister of Australia. The commander of the Australian contingent up there is Colonel Stuart. He is the person who has the responsibility. He is the person who is answerable to the executive government of this country for the safety and welfare of the Australian troops. Again, it is misleading to say that because we have an Australian general up there, somehow our troops will be looked after.
With the exception of those two clauses, to which we on this side of the Senate will be moving amendments, I support this Bill. I look forward to voting for the amendments moved by Senator Durack.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill is important legislation which seeks to amend the Defence Act 1903. The Bill is essentially about conscientious objection and conscription. This is one of those rare opportunities—perhaps this has happened only once in this decade—when there has been a philosophical debate about defence. To a large degree this major piece of legislation happens to have the support of all senators.

PARA.TAB: The Defence Act provided for conscription in terms of the immediate defence of Australia. It was conceived at a time nearly 90 years ago when attitudes and ways of doing things were quite different. In the 1950s the National Service Act supplemented the Defence Act and provided for the calling up of Australian men for compulsory service. In particular, during the Vietnam War national servicemen were conscripted to serve overseas. This led to a heightened and increased interest amongst many in Australia about the questions of conscription and conscientious objection.

Subsequently, in the 1980s a number of senators who were members of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs and who still had in mind the public debate that took place in the 1960s and the early 1970s helped produce a report entitled Conscientious objection to conscripted military service. This is in many way the point of departure. It is the basis on which the Government has introduced this legislation.

The Government has taken the opportunity to pick up many of the recommendations of the Senate committee inquiry and to completely repeal the National Service Act and the National Service Termination Act 1972. I should note that the latter Act effectively did make null the National Service Act of 20 years earlier. But because there were certain provisions in the National Service Act that gave a benefit to those who had served as national servicemen, the Act was not completely removed from the books. Only the operative ongoing parts of that legislation that actually affected national service and call-up were terminated by the National Service Termination Act. After 20 years, neither of these pieces of legislation are of any further relevance. The legislation now before the Senate completely repeals these two Acts.

I think any Australian reading section 59 of the major piece of legislation covered by the Bill now before us—the Defence Act 1903—would agree that it is completely outdated. Section 59 provides that all persons liable to serve in the Defence Force in time of war are male persons. Clearly, Senator Newman has said, the Opposition believes and the Government proposes that all persons, both male and female, would serve this country in the Defence Force in time of war. In fact, persons liable to serve now include all persons aged between 18 and 60 who have resided in Australia for not less than six months. So it is not only citizens but also permanent residents of this country who are in this category.

Section 60 of the Defence Act sets out the classes of persons who would be, subject to proclamation, called up. This would perhaps happen in order of priority. It would be based on whether someone is single, married, or a widower and also a person's age group. I believe that it is quite appropriate not only to amend section 59 in the ways that are proposed in this legislation but also to remove the rather Aristotelian classifications of section 60—to allow classification to be appropriate and defined appropriately to meet the particular needs of any proclamation that would be used to call up persons. So the categories of priority for call-up in any defence of Australia from immediate invasion in the future will now be subject to regulation and will no longer be defined as they are in section 60 of the present Act.

So far so good. These changes are supported by the Opposition. The other broad area of this legislation relates to the defence force retirement and death benefits scheme, the Defence Housing Authority Act and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme Act. My colleague, Senator Newman, directly addressed these aspects of the legislation. My colleagues and I readily agree with what she has said about the Act and about the Government's inadequacies. However, the Opposition agrees with the Government with regard to the precise legislative initiatives that are now before us.

The matters that remain and which are contentious flow on from the agreed definition for `conscientious objection', the setting up of tribunals and the need for parliamentary approval for conscription proclamation. There is contention about conscientious objection to a particular war and to the provision of a 90-day limit in terms of any parliamentary approval. I will need to speak to these matters when the Senate resumes debate on this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 14 April, Irene Greenwood died after a long illness and after having been for four years in the Alfred Carson Nursing Home in Claremont in Western Australia. She was in her ninety-third year and had been dynamic, active and energetic, keenly interested in current affairs generally and the status of women in particular from very young womanhood until she suffered a stroke which severely disabled her and led to her death.

PARA.TAB: Irene Adelaide Driver was the daughter of a prominent member of the Womens Christian Temperance Union when that organisation was significant in persuading the Western Australian Parliament to extend the vote to women in 1878. Her mother, Adelaide Driver, was widely known as a prominent and effective woman of her time. Irene herself enthusiastically embraced her mother's feminism and activism. Her long life was dedicated particularly to the enhancement of the status of women, and no less passionately to the cause of world peace and disarmament long before it was fashionable or even acceptable to work as a peace activist. We sometimes forget that even the Womens International League for Peace and Freedom, of which Irene was a long time member, was considered seditious for many years. It took courage to be a member.

As a young woman, she spoke in the Domain in Sydney at a rally supporting Egon Kisch, the Austrian pacifist whom the Menzies Government sought to exclude from Australia but who literally jumped from a ship, broke his leg and was spirited away by the peace activists to avoid deportation. This occurred in the mid-1930s and Irene told me much later that the organising committee put her on the platform because it needed a woman and she was conspicuous because of her red hair.

Her ebullient nature, which she believed was inevitably associated with her red hair, kept her in the forefront of a wide range of activities especially associated with women and peace. She wrote for and edited Dawn, the official organ of the Western Australian Council for Equal Pay and Opportunity for many decades and collected feminist writings which, with her own voluminous records of her committee work, were acquired as the Irene Greenwood collection by the Murdoch University in the late 1970s.

Many Australians would recall the regular broadcasts that she made for years conducting a program embracing all aspects of cultural activities and local and international affairs, in a time slot intended for women at home. The session was sponsored by a Perth milliner. Irene's beautifully prepared scripts for radio, heard by large and loyal audiences, constituted the bulk of her own writings and their quality was recognised in 1975 when she was awarded a life membership of the Guild of Australian Writers.

Her red-gold hair had become nearly white before I got to know her well when she was in her 70s. She frequently expressed frustration that she had not written her own life story, simply because she had not had the time. There were endless demands upon her, even up to the time of her stroke. Fortunately, in her latter years she had been systematically interviewed for the Battye Library oral history collection. A previous set of recordings which she herself had painstakingly made had been stolen, probably by children looking for tapes to play with.

A compulsive correspondent, her letters will probably one day be collected. She was corresponding with people like Manning Clark and the Whitlams until she became sick and disabled in 1988. An internationalist, she made friends and contacts in many countries during an era in which that took a lot more time, effort and resources than it does today.

Through the Women's Service Guild of Western Australia, of which she was an honorary life vice-president, Irene contributed her energy and talents to the International Alliance of Women, a non-governmental organisation established 90 years ago when Vida Goldstein of Victoria attended its inaugural meeting in Washington. As a result, the Australian League of Voters became an early affiliate and later the Women's Service Guild. It was at Irene's insistence that the Women's Electoral Lobby affiliated with this prestigious NGO in 1982.

Irene was one of the first professional women to be employed by the Western Australian Government in 1919, and she maintained an intense interest in the International Labour Organisation for many decades. As in all her activities, she was unceasingly determined to disseminate her knowledge and experience and imbue other women with enthusiasm for the United Nations and such agencies as the International Labour Organisation. For many years she was the leading force behind the celebration of International Women's Day in Perth. She has shown me programs dating back at least 40 years. The United Nations' Declaration on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women, which used affectionately to be called DEDAW, was the focus of much of her formidable proselytising from the time of its genesis in 1948 until it became a convention in 1979.

As the second wave of feminism reached the shores of Western Australia Irene, then in her early 70s, threw herself wholeheartedly into the organisation and education of those who came newly to active feminism through Women's Lib and the Women's Electoral Lobby. She instilled in us a sense of history. `Herstory' was the word which was coined to describe the knowledge of and respect for the work of our foremothers, hidden from history until the last decade or so.

I can never adequately express my debt to Irene for many things: her support, her wise counsel, encouragement, affection and her pride in womanhood and sisterhood. I could go on. However, Irene's greatest gift to me has been that sense of what has gone before: the struggles of generations of dedicated feminists against the barriers of entrenched bias against women, and social attitudes which denied them economic and political equality with men. For example, it is less than 20 years since the typical response of the media to issues concerning women was to sensationalise, trivialise, and/or ridicule. How wonderful that Irene lived to see the journalistic and editorial transformation that now ensures that concerns and achievements of women are treated as a matter of course and usually with dignity.

When the United Nations Year of Women was announced, the Whitlam Government appointed an advisory council to guide the Australian Government's contribution to the celebration of that momentous occasion. Elizabeth Reid, adviser on women's affairs to the then Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, recognising the wisdom and energy of Irene, was instrumental in her inclusion on that committee. As ever, Irene's generosity with her time and expertise was completely at the disposal of the Government as she committed her heart and soul to the activities centred upon that occasion.

She was offered the opportunity of travelling to Mexico for the United Nations conference in 1975 but declined on the basis of her advanced years and her expressed wish that a younger woman should go instead. It was as a result of her insistence that I was invited to go on the delegation to the Tribune in Mexico in 1975—an experience which was described by all those who took part in it as quite extraordinary and unique.

Honours came to Irene late in her life. Between her seventy-fifth and eighty-fifth birthdays, she worked for a chair of peace studies at the Murdoch University and was awarded, amongst other things, an honorary life membership of the Guild of Writers, an Order of Australia, a doctorate honoris causa by the Murdoch University and a Silver Peace medal by the United Nations Association of Australia and, perhaps what pleased her most of all, a State ship was named after her.

Many women in Western Australia, in the rest of Australia and internationally will celebrate the life of Irene Greenwood with me and with my daughters. Her daughter and grandchildren were sources of great joy and pride to Irene. To them I extend loving sympathy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak briefly about something that I think is a success story and the sort of story that unfortunately does not enjoy much publicity in our media. I am talking about the Australian best practice demonstration program and the satisfaction—if not pride—that I took from being asked to present the cheque for $200,000 as the first payment of a total of $420,000-plus grant to a firm called Hendersons Automotive in South Australia. I made that presentation in December last year and tonight I want to place on record one of the reasons why that firm was short listed for the prize under the best practice management program awards.

PARA.TAB: It is probably best summarised by giving a small history of the firm. In 1985 the parent company of Hendersons Automotive South Australia recommended closure. Hendersons was paying big workers compensation bills, losing an average of 300 hours a month to injuries, 32 per cent of the work force was injured annually, staff turnover hit 120 per cent a year, absenteeism stood at 8 per cent and the company was facing substantial loss by the end of June 1986. Despite strong growth in the industry, this firm was unable to improve sales or make a profit. Under threat of closure, the 200 people in the firm committed themselves to rapid change.

The indicators which forecast doom in 1985, today point to success. The firm is profitable, only one worker has suffered injury in the past 27 months, and that was a broken finger, absenteeism is well below 2 per cent and staff turnover has been slashed to 9 per cent. Each year this firm is spending $500 per employee on training, which is well above the national average, and there has been a 25 per cent boost in skilled labour without an expansion in the work force.

The work that has gone into restructuring, and moving from what was the story in 1985 to the extraordinarily good performance in 1991-92 at Hendersons Automotive, has seen it become one of the international suppliers of its principal product, that is, seats for cars. It actually achieved a quality rating that allows it to compete successfully in the American car market—a quite extraordinary achievement for a small firm in South Australia. In September the firm received confirmation of contracts to supply seating components to three US car makers, Chrysler, General Motors and Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac. These contracts are the result of that drive to quality, the introduction of better practice management, having the huge expenditure on occupational disease and injury reduced to almost nothing now, a complete change in heart on the part of employees there and an extraordinary turnaround in attitude, job satisfaction and, as a result of that, productivity and performance.

It is one of the many stories that can be told about the work force in Australia which is very rarely told. I am delighted to place it on record tonight. I wish to take this opportunity of congratulating all the workers involved in that plant and Mr Dedrick, the manager, who was in charge of the whole turnaround and certainly of overseeing it. He would say that it has been a combined effort and commitment of all the work force there and I have no dispute with that. I was very pleased to look briefly at the plant and meet with the workers when I was down there presenting the first part of their cheque.

One of the particular points of interest to me were the stories of two women, which were only two of the stories which could be told of the women who work there. Linda Saberton is now 43 and married with three children and one grandchild. She is a former bank clerk who was forced out of her job in the 1960s by bank employment policies which discriminated against married women. Mrs Saberton said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was bank policy that you had to resign when you got married. That was in 1967 and, after five years at home raising three children, I went out looking for a job and started at a car component maker on the production line as a process worker.

Three years ago she joined Hendersons Automotive as a senior production controller. It is her skill in her job and judgment which ensures that orders for car seat frames and slides are completed on time and on the day scheduled.

PARA.TAB: The car industry operates under the `just in time' principle which means that the minimal amount of stock is stored and the maximum amount of stock is delivered as needed. That requires a very fine judgment of having all systems go and arriving at the right place at the right time to ensure that what is promised to be delivered is delivered. It requires a real commitment by all those involved in the work force to get their part of that production line in the right place at the right time. Mrs Saberton's job is to receive and check the orders, input all of that information into the computer, allocate componentry and labour hours to ensure that the company has the people and the parts in the right place at the time. She says it is very demanding because she has to be right. She cannot afford—and neither can the firm—to get that wrong. She said that as well as the satisfaction from doing that, doing it well and being satisfied and pleased with the success that she can contribute to, she was also delighted that she could share some of the stories of her employees with us. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: We've got one guy who started here as a process worker and now, at the age of 29, works in the Production Control Department and has completed the second year of his science degree.

PARA.TAB: I was also pleased to see the number of other staff who have actually had a change of heart and job satisfaction after going to work there. They found a work force that was concerned about other workers and each gained satisfaction from the job and knowing that the person beside them was also provided with job satisfaction.

The other story of a woman that was particularly drawn to my attention—and I am pleased to pass these stories on—concerned Lynn McDonald who is 26 and a personnel officer at Hendersons Automotive. She joined Hendersons from the southern suburb of Christies Beach after high school in 1981 as a junior costing clerk and was working as a receptionist and payroll clerk when management asked her if she would like to study human resource management. In June 1990 she completed her advanced certificate in human resource management at the Adelaide College of TAFE after four years of part time study. She attended eight hours of lectures each week and the company contributed half as time off allowed during working hours. She said herself that she changed her view about what the prospects were for herself and, indeed, her own expectations for herself, as a result of being part of that work force which encouraged her to extend her capacity.

Both of these stories indicate and illustrate beautifully by means of case histories the real, everyday examples of how a change in attitude towards best practice management, in collaboration with the changes in the workers in that firm, has resulted in a huge turnaround. Because of my interest in occupational health and safety, I was particularly struck by the dramatic reduction in accident and injury that has happened in that company. It is important to note that the fall in the number of accidents and injuries is an indication of a work force that is satisfied with what it is doing and feels constructive and productive at work. The number of accidents in the work place can be a measurement of unsafe equipment, et cetera, but very often it is also a measurement of dissatisfaction, less than optimal working circumstances or working climate, or attitude towards workers and what workers are contributing.

This story is particularly significant in terms of the turnaround of occupational health and safety. It is very important to see that as one measure of the effects of best practice management. The other great measure, of course, is the improved productivity and the maintenance in a time of recession of all the 204 employees in the work force—that is the same number that has been there over those six years. While we are hearing stories of gloom and doom, we sometimes fail to note the success stories of the very sort that this Government's policies have been aiming to see implemented. Here is a really stunning example of the sort of thing that can emerge from best practice management. I am pleased to put on record the story of what has happened at Hendersons Automotive and also my congratulations to all involved in that success.

Many instances have been reported to me where relevant authorities have been informed of these events. More often than not the reports have been ignored, discarded or covered up.

When I mention particular cases of these incidents especially to country people, almost inevitably there is an understanding and a recognition of the sort of thing that I have described. I am astounded at the number of people who have been affected themselves and who then go on to describe somebody else who has been affected. I continue to receive these types of reports. I intend to draw the attention of the Senate to some of the stories that people are sending me.

Before doing so, I will refer in this instance to an article that was published last week in the magazine New Idea in its issue of 18 April. The story was entitled `In Search of Paradise'. This tells of the experience of Dianne Marshall, now of Queensland's Gold Coast but previously from Coffs Harbour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you buy New Idea very often?

—In response to the interjection, I do not scan the pages of New Idea very often for the subjects of my adjournment speeches, but this one in particular is worthy of being brought to the attention of the Senate. I do not deny it any credibility because I had to go to that source for it. This was brought to me through another forum as well, but it is well explained in that magazine and I will quote from it.

PARA.TAB: In the backyard of her Coffs Harbour house, Dianne Marshall was sprayed with chemicals from a crop-dusting plane. She was pregnant; the baby died soon after birth. Last week I was given an outline of many instances of people, water supplies and rivers in and around Mungindi being sprayed. Mungindi is a cotton growing area in northern New South Wales near the border of Queensland. One sequence of events started in February 1985, and I have been told that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . at 5.30 a.m. a plane sprayed into a strong wind, blowing directly into our house. We could not get the windows closed in time and the inside of the house was like a fog and my face felt as if acid had been thrown on it and one of my children's lips and throat were burning. The spray was Parathion.

For the information of the Senate, I will describe what parathion is. It is a chemical which is used in fruit growing areas throughout Australia. It is also used on some citrus crops and in the growing of cotton. Ethyl parathion distributors have been advised to stop further sales pending the results of an investigation, and a code of practice will shortly be introduced.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Workers Union drew attention to two cases of poisoning last month in the Goulburn Valley where a grower and his wife were hospitalised. They had been using diluted parathion concentrate to spray fruit but they had not worn protective gloves. In the United States there have been 52 recorded deaths from parathion poisoning over 25 years. In Brisbane recently a handyman working at a nursery died after accidentally drinking a form of parathion from a Coca Cola bottle. An inquiry was announced earlier this year by the Victorian Minister for Food and Agriculture, Mr Baker, following complaints from the AWU that uncontrolled use of the chemical in Victoria's fruit growing areas was endangering the health of fruit pickers.
I refer again to the story I was quoting from the New Idea about the children's lips and throats burning and that the spray being used was parathion. The story continues:
I rang the cotton grower and asked if he would spray when the wind was blowing away from the house. His reply was that I was not dead yet.
A month later at six in the morning we had chemical right through the house again. I tried to get the plane to stop spraying. They refused so I got the police to stop them.
There was no authority that wanted to listen or do anything about our situation and the cotton grower threatened to sue if I stopped him spraying when he wanted to.

We have an angora goat stud. The plane would fly over us so low, it sent the goats crazy, so they ran into fences and piled on top of each other. As time went by the does started to abort and have dead kids. Although we had blood tests taken nothing could be found to indicate the cause.
Spraying continued and an increasing number of people began complaining.

In April 1989 24D and roundup mixture was sprayed with the wind blowing toward our property. The garden, and fruit trees were wiped out, as well as all the grasses and herbs on our 20 acres. The Department of Agriculture Inspector arrived two weeks later and said that the place had been badly contaminated but there was not enough evidence to do anything about it.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the tiniest tip of a very big iceberg which I intend to persist with until governments take this issue seriously. A list has been accumulating in my office. The only real option I have is to bring these case studies to the Senate to indicate how seriously people are being affected by the inaction with regard to this problem which persists throughout Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Mr Robert Noel Bonnett

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support a condolence motion moved in the other place earlier today by the honourable member for Herbert, Mr Lindsay, and supported by the honourable member for Fadden, Mr Jull, regarding the death last week of Robert Noel Bonnett. He was the Federal member for Herbert from 1966 to 1977.

PARA.TAB: The people of Townsville will long remember Duke Bonnett, as he was known to all and sundry, for his distinguished war record and the great improvements he brought to the Townsville region during his term as the Federal member. Duke Bonnett enlisted in the Australian Military Forces in March 1941. He served in the south-west Pacific between 1941 and 1943 with the 2/3 Independent Company and 2/3 and 2/9 Cavalry of the Commando Squadrons. He had a distinguished service record and was promoted in the field to the rank of lieutenant.

Duke Bonnett died last week and his funeral service was held last Friday at the cathedral in Townsville. After Duke Bonnett left the Army but prior to entering Parliament in 1966, he was a timber cutter, a cane cutter and worked on many cattle and sheep stations in north Queensland. Immediately prior to his election, he was the field officer for the Liberal Party in north Queensland.

He made a major contribution to the welfare of the Townsville region. Things like the Lavarack Army Barracks, the Australian Institute of Marine Science and a rehabilitation centre for the disabled all became a reality through Duke Bonnett's personal efforts during his 11 years as the Federal member. This period was a time of unprecedented expansion and progress in the Townsville region.

With the support of Duke Bonnett, the James Cook University of north Queensland and the Yabulu nickel refinery were also established during his term in Parliament. He was a tireless advocate for the Burdekin Dam, the construction of which the Fraser Government committed itself to in 1981. Duke Bonnett was the shadow Minister for pensions, repatriation and housing between 1972 and 1974 and the Opposition spokesman for national and northern development. He served on parliamentary committees for Aboriginal affairs, wildlife conservation, public works and Defence Force retirement benefits.

He announced his retirement from Parliament in August 1977 due to ill-health. He lived in Canberra for a little while and then returned to Townsville where he again devoted himself to the City through his involvement with the Returned Services League and other local charities. Duke was always a father-figure at special Liberal Party gatherings. I speak specifically for a member of my staff and on behalf of all Liberals in the Townsville region in extending their condolences and sympathies to his family.

Duke was a very kindly man and one who was loved by all of those who came in contact with him. He helped to put the Liberal Party on the map in north Queensland and will long be remembered by his Liberal colleagues for his work for the Party in north Queensland and in the Federal Parliament.

My personal association with Duke Bonnett goes back to 1965-1966. He was probably my first mentor, one might say, in party politics when I joined the Burdekin branch of the Young Liberals at the time when he was moving in that area as the Liberal Party field officer. He was a very kindly and a very supportive man. I can still clearly remember our great excitement in the Burdekin branch in 1966—in those days Burdekin was part of the Federal seat of Herbert—when Duke Bonnett won the seat, taking it from the Labor Party for the first time in many years. I can still remember the great excitement and parties at the time not only for winning it but also because a person as good as Duke Bonnett had won the seat and would be there to represent us in Canberra.

He was a very genuine bloke and a very sincere person. He was genuinely concerned for people. He worked behind the scenes to get things done to help the little people in his electorate. It was for that reason that he was re-elected time and time again—I think some five times in the 11 years that he was in Parliament. My sincere sympathies, and those of my wife and Liberal Party people in north Queensland, go out to the family of Duke Bonnett who have survived him. The people of the north have indeed lost a great man. We have all been enriched by his contribution to life in the north, by his advice and kindliness and by his selfless devotion to those things he believed in. Well done, Duke.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 25 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the extensive use of the chemical 2,4-D in this country as a herbicide:
(1) Are there dangers associated with the chemical 2,4-D.

(2) Will the continued use of this chemical by our primary producers, their agents and contractors have any ill effects on the health of the public who may come in contact with the operations of these applications.
(3) Are adequate safeguards in place to ensure 2,4-D and its derivatives are used only following advice of its manufacturers.
(4) Has the chemical 2,4-D received a Certificate of Clearance from the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council; if so, what are the requirements of AAVCC to gain such a certificate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) All chemicals whether farm, industrial or household products have potential dangers if due care is not taken with their use. In particular, agricultural chemicals used in pest and disease control are biologically active and can pose a risk to users and the environment if not properly handled including safe application and disposal. Products containing 2,4-D may be safely used in agricultural, industrial and domestic situations provided the directions on the label are observed.

(2) Agricultural chemicals are strictly regulated and must undergo a rigorous assessment and approval process before they can be registered for sale and use in Australia. This assessment involves the review of extensive scientific information by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC), Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) and other expert bodies. The review process is coordinated by the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC).

NHMRC is responsible for the evaluation of the public health aspects of agricultural chemicals. NHMRC has extensively reviewed the toxicology of 2,4-D and various epidemiological studies that have been reported. As a result NHMRC has recommended appropriate label warning statements, first aid instructions, safety directions and permissible residue standards. NHMRC is satisfied that provided 2,4-D is applied according to the approved use-pattern there is little likelihood that there would be ill effects on public health.

(3) There is potential for all agricultural chemical products to be misused. State legislation, however, makes it an offence to use an agricultural chemical product for a purpose or in a manner contrary to the approved label directions which have been determined following evaluation of the products safety and performance. Farmers are continually reminded of their obligation to use all pesticides in a safe and proper manner and routine monitoring of food commodities for pesticide residues by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and State agencies indicates that there is a high level of compliance with label recommendations. Should incidents occur which may indicate misuse or inappropriate use, eg chemical spray drift damage, then these are investigated by State authorities and corrective action initiated. Penalties for misuse can be severe.

(4) 2,4-D has been in use in Australia for in excess of 30 years and products currently available for sale were registered by individual States prior to the commencement of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 and establishment of AAVCC. More recent information on the safety of 2,4-D has been assessed by Council's advisory bodies which are satisfied that continued registration is appropriate.

Companies seeking clearance of an agricultural or veterinary chemical product must provide to the AAVCC extensive technical data as outlined in the Requirements for Clearance of Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Products (1989) issued by AAVCC. In summary, this data package must include information on the chemical with regard to public and occupational health and safety risks, residues in food, environmental impact and effectiveness against the pest or disease. The information requirements of the AAVCC are consistent with those of other countries such as the USA, Canada and the United Kingdom. They are also consistent with international guidelines established by the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations and the World Health Organisation.

Provided that AAVCC is satisfied that the product poses no undue hazard to the safety of persons, environment and non-target organisms, treated crops or livestock, international trade, and is effective for its stated uses, a certificate of clearance in respect of that chemical product will be granted allowing the product to be registered in the States for sale and use.
