TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 2 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to answer to Question on Notice No. 1155 (Senate Weekly Hansard, 14 October 1991, W.1970), in which it was stated, `It is not anticipated any meaningful data (on the evaluation of the black spots program) will be available for at least 6 months', has `meaningful data' been obtained earlier than had been anticipated; if so, will the data be tabled; if not, why did the Government announce, in the week beginning 23 February 1992, a 70 per cent increase in program funds prior to evaluation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Formal evaluation of the Black Spot program has not yet commenced. It has been included in the Department of Transport and Communication's Portfolio Evaluation Plan. State reports are being received and based on these the review, to be undertaken by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics will commence later this year.

There was no need for an evaluation prior to the announcement of a further $70 million funding in the "One Nation" statement. The effectiveness of black spot treatments is widely accepted and documented in Australia and overseas. Because of the nature of the program and the projects, it presents benefits both in terms of road safety and employment opportunities.
The program requires nominated projects not only to have an established history of fatal and serious crashes, but also a minimum benefit cost ratio of at least 2:1.

The Australian Road Research Board has provided a list of cost effective traffic engineering treatments which have either high or medium potential. These are used as a guide by states and territories in framing programs. The majority of the projects have had "high" potential.

The annual cost of road trauma is around $6,000 million. The Government, along with States and Territories, is undertaking a broad range of strategies to reduce the level of road trauma. Apart from reducing the level of personal trauma, the Government's program will lead to the reallocation of resources to more productive areas of the economy.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 24 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has Australia given or offered bindings in respect of the tariff reductions set out in the Prime Minister's statement to Parliament on 12 March 1991, Building a Better Australia; if so, what, in particular, is the nature of the bindings given or offered in relation to the general reduction in agricultural assistance in Australia.
(2) What concessions has Australia given or offered in respect of GATT Anti-Dumping and Countervailing Codes.
(3) What concessions has Australia given or offered on the proposed GATT Code on sanitary and phytosanitary measures.
(4) What concessions has Australia given or offered in the working group on technical trade barriers including in the area of quarantine policies and procedures.

(5) Will the Parliament be given the opportunity to examine and debate the texts of all undertakings and proposed bindings in relation to the GATT Uruguay Round before commitments are given by Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Except for several agricultural products outlined below, Australia's tariff offer in the Uruguay Round, which is in accord with the agreed target for a one third reduction on a trade weighted basis, is based on the binding of tariffs at the end rates announced in the May 1988 Economic Statement.
For agriculture, target reductions in the the draft Framework Agreement in respect of market access commitments are tougher than for non-agricultural products in three respects:
(i) They provide for a 36 per cent simple average cut for agriculture as a whole;
(ii) They require all agricultural tariff levels to be cut by a minimum of 15 per cent;
(iii) They require all agricultural tariffs to be bound.

In respect of the second requirement it has been necessary for a number of agricultural items (around 20% of the total) to draw on the March 1991 cuts, either wholly or in part, to meet the minimum 15 per cent cut.

The concessions and commitments on both agriculture and non-agriculture items offered in the draft schedules tabled at the beginning of March in Geneva are conditional on comparable concessions and commitments being lodged and confirmed by our major trading partners in areas of export interest to us.

(2) Australia has not given or offered any concessions as such in respect of the new draft arrangements for anti-dumping and countervailing duties. The draft texts, which are part of the Draft Final Act of the Uruguay Round tabled by the Director-General of the GATT on 20 December 1991, are elaborations of the current GATT Codes. They have been the subject of negotiations during the period of the Round.

The text aims to balance the interests of importers and exporters aimed at maintaining the effectiveness of these remedies against injurious dumped and subsidized imports, while reducing the scope for trade harassment.
Overall, the draft texts are more detailed in their requirements, in an effort to make them clearer and more transparent for all users.

(3) Australia is one of the countries seeking to reduce all forms of agricultural protectionism in the Round, and this includes constraining the ability of countries to use sanitary and phytosanitary measures as disguised and scientifically unjustified barriers to trade.

There is also a need to prevent commitments on reductions in border protection for agricultural products being undermined by arbitrary or unjustified use of national regulations purporting to protect human, animal or plant life or health.

The draft agreement on sanitary and phytosanitary measures does not involve concessions by Australia. Indeed, Australia's current practices already largely conform with the requirements of the draft. In particular, Australian quarantine controls are based on objective scientific risk evaluation and involve a process of open consultation with affected parties. Australian food standards follow a similar approach.

(4) The new draft text on Technical Barriers to Trade is an elaboration of the current Code of which Australia is a member. Quarantine matters are to be covered by the agreement on sanitary and phytosanitary measures and not the Technical Barriers to Trade agreement.

(5) Parliament has been kept informed throughout the negotiations about progress in the Uruguay Round. The Government will be reporting to the Parliament on the final outcome to the negotiations and its decision on the final package.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) For what reasons is Veterans' Affairs legislation exempted from the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and has the Government considered ending the exemption; if not, why not.
(2) For what benefits would non-returned servicewomen qualify if such an exemption were removed.
(3) How many non-returned servicewomen would be affected.
(4) Are there any other classes of persons who, in light of such a change, could argue that they also should qualify for the same benefits; if so, how many people would be involved.
(5) What would be the cost to the Commonwealth of extending the benefits identified above to non-returned servicewomen.
(6) What would be the cost to the Commonwealth of extending benefits to any other people identified above as having a similarly valid claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) "Veterans' Affairs legislation" includes: the Defence Service Homes Act 1918; the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986; Papua New Guinea (Members of the Forces Benefits) Act 1957; Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940, Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986; War Graves Act 1980 and the War Precautions Act Repeal Act 1920.

The Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986; Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940; Papua New Guinea (Members of the Forces Benefits) Act 1957 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 are interrelated and have been deliberately exempted from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984.

This action was taken by the Government as the inclusion of these Acts would result in the possible cancellation of many benefits available to ex-servicewomen. Primarily, under these Acts an ex-servicewoman can apply for an Income Support pension, subject to the same eligibility criteria as applied to their male counterparts, five years earlier than ex-servicemen. Australian ex-servicewomen who served during the WWII conflict and have qualifying service receive medical treatment at Repatriation Commission expense by virtue of their war time service. Male veterans conversely can only receive medical treatment through the Repatriation Commission if they meet specific eligibility criteria.
Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 all benefits available to male veterans and their dependants are equally available to female veterans and their dependants.

The Defence Service Homes Act 1918; War Graves Act 1920 and War Precautions Act Repeal Act 1920 do not discriminate on the basis of a claimant's gender and consequently are not exempted from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984.
(2) None.
(3) None.
(5) Not applicable.
(6) Not applicable.
